reviewText:
Despite to rather rocky start, X Rebirth 2.0 and greater have fixed many of the issues that made the game unplayable. It is still not as diverse and vast as its predecessors in the X series but I have found the game enjoyable enough to play almost 500 hours in little over a year.

Starting with the graphics, they are satisfactory. Much of the gameplay will take place in the Albion Skunk's cockpit which allows you to look out at the beautiful galaxies and stunning spaceships which the X Series have never seemed to fail in impressing us. Then there is the staion/ship deck veiw... Although walking around in the many ships and station is really cool and the interiors are as great as the galaxies you get to admire, the people are somewhat unimpressive statues that come with one of three different faces. Although getting to walk amongst a station/ship's crew and interact face to face with a trader, the whole experience is lessened by the fact that the people look like they were taken straight from a 2004 pc game and just pasted into a 2013 one. Overall the exteriors/interiors, shadows and lighting are enough to make you overlook the fact that the NPC's are just so awful looking, however I still have a lot of fate that Egosoft will pull through and revamp the npc's appearance.

The campaign storyline is awesome! Fighting alongside the renements of  rebel forces against a massive power hungry corporation always scores big points in my book. Without giving too much away, I would like to just say that storyline introduces you to some fascinating characters (That still look terrible!) that only thicken the plot and further immerse you into the storyline. My favourite part is that you are no longer alone in  the vastness of space, you now have a copilot/partner?/Friend to enjoy space with. Though she is very similar to the other female npcs in terms of appearance (can be fixed using certain mods), she is actually quite comical in the campaign and actually a real good addition to the normally lonely universe we've grown use to in previous X games.

The ships and Stations you encounter and can buy/build will not disappoint you but I know one thing that will! You can't fly them...Any of them, you can dock and tell the captain to take you somewhere but thats as close to flying a capital ship as you will get. I do not mind such, personally I believe it is more realistic in not being able to pilot a capital ship. especially now that you get to hire members of your crew yourself. But I too have spent many hours flying my Thor in X Prelude and blasting Xenon to bits, its just so fun.

The music is okay, it isn't quite up to par with that which we listened to in X3 series but its still not bad, except for the bar music though. I hate the bar music (Did I forget you can visit a Bar while docked in a station?) The voice acting is okay as well though there is a lot of repeatitive dialogue amost NPCs but the small talk mini-game is fun to play when you really want something at a station.

The game as a whole has come a long way since its release, many features have been added (I've left out a lot, I might add them to my reveiw at a later date) and many of the bugs that resulted in crashing have been fixed. I have only had my game crash once since 2.0 and it may have been my fault as I was running a lot of other programs in the background. Despite the poor game rating and hundreds of negative reveiws this game has recieved during its intial release, it has become a VERY enjoyable game to play. There are still many things left to fix but given the amount of work that has been put into fixing and patching the game, my hopes are high.

To anyone looking to buy this game, it is well worth it at this point. There are many mods out there right now that fix many of the issues many people have ingame and some added new features or galaxies which helps keep the gameinteresting while the developers continue to patch and add features themselves. I recommend buy the Teladi Outpost DLC with the gam though, it adds several more ships and fractions that only add to the game as a whole.

reviewText:
X Rebirth is a reboot of the previous X Series games. I first got into the X Series back in X2: The Threat. Being able to command big capital ships was something that was a very memorable experience. Trying to get into big fleet battles was interesting. You had the whole universe of hundreds of systems to play in and play with which is the best part of any X Series game.

X Rebirth was something of a disaster, especially at launch. Many of the bugs were fixed with upcoming updates for X Rebirth but the gameplay and the Freedom that was once there is no more. You no longer have the freedom to fly other small ships or “Captain” Capital Ships in any way or form. You can “Own” many ships but cannot “Fly” any ship. You are locked to a ship named “Albion Skunk”, ♥♥♥♥ poor name in my opinion, and are limited in not only a dozen weapons.

There are only, currently I believe 4 or 5 systems vs the Hundreds of systems previously accessible in the other X Series games. Would rather have hundreds of systems to explore rather than 4 or 5 with smaller sub areas you can visit.

X Rebirth, has certainly improved somewhat in combat and most certainly graphically from its predecessors. There are many new gameplay mechanics, such as the Space Highway System, Bigger Space Stations with multiple dock locations and areas to explore. However, many interiors are identical to one another, faces on all characters are all nearly the same and various other small things just almost don’t make it worth your time to dock and talk to people.

There have been many improvements since Launch, and some great content has been added. But the freedom to do what you want, that made the other X Games so successful, is no longer there.
To summarize this all up without going into a 5 page essay as to why this game is a disaster, I would NOT recommend buying the game unless you got money to blow.

reviewText: If you've been following the release of this game, you may remember how disastrous, buggy, and unfinished the initial product was. The game lacks... a heart and soul, especially when you compare it to its most recent predecessors, X3:Terran Conflict and the expansion X3:Albion Prelude.  Patches are still being released for this game, so if something changes, I'll reconsider my review, but for now... I'd say buy something else.

reviewText:
While the game was absolutely terrible and broken when it got released a long time ago, Egosoft did a really good job of improving the game in many aspects, improving the interface and adding completely new features to the game. I also enjoy the DLCs quite alot (only one is shown in the shop so far, but another one is coming, which is even more worth purchasing).

To be frank, the campaign story is kind of meh, especially the last mission, but the story was (except for the very first X-title X-Beyond the frontier) never a focus point of the games.

As a fan since the beginning of the series, i hated the new highway system in the beginning because i thought making the warp gates more rare and instead focussing on highways was a betrayal to the series, especially since i did not care about the Albion sectors in the X3-series. But after a while i must say that i love the new highway system, its a great way to enjoy the scenery and to take a short break while flying from sector to sector.

It also has great mod support, a really nice mod community and a really great community overall.
And i must emphasize, unlike many developers who have a bad/broken launch and just abandon the game, Egosoft is known for supporting and improving the game even years after it's initizal release, and while almost every title in the X-series was incredibly broken at launch (hence the many bad reviews) Egosoft always did their best to improve the game to make their games great, even if it takes many years of (usually) free updates and patches.

The only huge gripe i have with this game is it's over-complicated and over-complex menu/sub-menu system to do simple things. But after a while you get used to it.

Unpatched on release it was garbage, over time it became acceptable, now i think it's a nice addition to the X-series and i'm always eagerly waiting for Egosoft to put in new updates.
Is it perfect? By all means no.
Is it enjoyable? In my opinion yes (why else would i play it over 500 hours?), as long as you don't have problems with fiddling around with menus.

reviewText: I have owned this game from its initial release which anyone who picked it up back then knows it wasn't as expected and was a very embarrassing release for Egosoft. So this is a much later review.

I prepurchased this game and it is a tale of why YOU SHOULD NEVER PRE-ORDER ANYTHING! at release this was sucha steaming pile. Now the game is a stable and respectable space sim. is it a master peice ? no. but with mods it has become a very enjoyable game. I will give egosoft props, at first i though they where the scum of the earth stealing my money, but their persistance has turned this, into a good game and restored my faith in them.

Will i pre-purchase a game from them again? No. Do i recommend this game as of update 4.0? Yes, try to get it on sale but it is a fun and very good looking game.

reviewText:
BEST X-Game EVER
X: Rebirth is, for me, the VERY BEST GAME Egosoft have ever released, by a HUGE margin!

To put that in context, I'm a LONG time X-phile, having played every game since the very first release: X: Beyond The Frontier (1999). While I've enjoyed each iteration in the series, there have been many things I found frustrating and, ultimately, after Albion Prelude (2011) I decided I'd had more than enough of being punished for my dreams: I vowed never to buy another Egosoft game.

Earlier games were massive time sinks, Pretty and often fun, but requiring weeks if not months of REAL TIME graft to get to the big ticket rewards like capital ships and fleet battles. There was also an inordinate amount of tedious repetition involved in trading between sectors and stations. Worse, items always cost so damned much. New guns for your ship? That'll be hours of monotonous trading, please. New ship? Come back in a week!

At their worst, earlier X games felt exactly like that real life job we are supposed to be gaming to escape from.  Dull, monotonous and frequently punishing. Some like that: for me, it was torture having the dream of a space game so close but unable to achieve it thanks to some obstinate design decisions. Because I love space games, and because Egosoft were producing the ONLY A-grade space games out there for the longest time, I held out like a battered husband, hoping things would eventually improve.

X Rebirth is that game. The improvement I'd always hoped would happen.

It had a very rough start. Egosoft should not, under any circumstances, have released the game in the state they did. By all accounts it was buggy and broken, on top of being a severe departure from earlier games. Not having bought it I sat back and laughed at my bullet-dodging cleverness.

However, a couple of years later, after huge amounts of polish, tweaks and additions by Egosoft, Rebirth is now an absolute gem! A sparkling diamond in place of 1.0's jagged black coal. I've been playing it non-stop since I bought it. I can't stop playing it. This redesigned universe just makes so much more sense than it ever did. Activites make more sense, feel more logical. The graphical improvements are enormous, and a joy to behold (the stations are breathtaking!), but it's the gameplay that now really shines. So much opportunity everywhere! Missions that finally pay out decent rewards! Items priced low enough that a mission or two can afford them! I can repair my ships now without spending a week trading to offset the cost!

I love this game!

Yes, there are still wonky bits. The narrative is compelling but awkwardly told. NPC modelling and animation rarely looks right. Voice acting is average at best, ear-destroying at worst. The menu-driven UI can still be a bit fiddly. And there's so much to [re]learn. But these are now minor complaints considering the rest of the game design now offers so much fun.

I heartily recommed buying X: Rebirth at the earliest opportunity!

reviewText:
Do not be drawn away by then 'mostly negitive'. This game had a bad release...very bad in fact. But guess what, Egosoft dosen't abandon it's children. No, they stay and rebuild, and what they have made out of it is worthy of the price tag.

Honestly there are a few things to note.

1: It's X:Rebirth, and removes a lot of ship controling and other features since X-3. It's more liken to the older X-Beyond the Frontier, in which you only owned one ship to fly, and upgraded it to suit your needs. X:Rebirth has attempted to bring back that feeling.

2: They tried something new and it didn't turn out right. Honestly I hate when these games come out and everyone bashes them for being 'off target' from it's origenal. Do you seriously expect a game to sell if it's just a copy each time and no risks are taken? It dosen't work that way. Even Nintendo, the big daddy of video games, has experimented and gotten smashed. Paper Mario Sticker Star for example... The fact is, you can't judge a game completely on it's predisesor, as everyone is diffrent, the new game that comes will also change.

So the game it's self visualy is breath taking. Giant super structure stations, wonderful space backgrounds, massive fire fights. The AI is also nice (But it's definatly not AGI) they can do some weird things, but are there to bring the automatic ecodemy and atmosphere of thousands to life. Gameplay can be rather dull at times, scaning stations, trading long distence with radios, running around on stations for offers and hidden godies. However, once you get an empire going you have meny things to do. The X series is a trading simulator in space with combat. Not a go shootem all up (that is until rather angry AGI and aliens attack.) My personal experience with the game is good. I've experienced very little problems other then a few scan points being inside the super structures (which you can glitch in and out of if you bounce around enough on it.) I recomend it for X series fans or someone who likes this type of game, but don't take this as the X series greatest impression. Play X-3 and it's expantions to get the full idea of how it works in good practice.

reviewText:
With the Rebirth 4.0 Update, I went ahead and bought the Home of Light DLC -because you deserve money for not tossing the game out and actually making it better (3.0)-, and then started a whole new game.

I didn't actually pay attention to the 4.0 Patchlog, and completely forgot that I'd never seen Trade Deals and Mission lists in X Rebirth before, as well as the awesomely awesome tickboxes in property list. I didn't actually notice that I'd played from morning to morning until I got a surprisingly beneficial CTD (you should stop playing and go to bed now).

This is completely and utterly playable and worth the NZ$48, and a must-buy at NZ$12 Sale. Haven't actually bothered leaving Omicron Lyrae yet, let alone newly explored the six or so other systems.

Only issues are the mind-numbingly boring small-talk to get trade updates in every station because it is the most important thing ever and the -graphics related (AMD?)- crashes and visual glitches, which aren't that bad if you keep autosave on. Also having to manually sell your station wares; kind of wish managers used tradeships to sell as well as buy instead of just letting them wander around aimlessly until they need to buy something.

reviewText:
I waited actual years to buy this. I liked the first games, but was wary because of all the really horrible complaints made about it when it first debuted. So, I waited until it was on an unbeatable sale and picked it up. I still got robbed. Don't spend anything on this at all.

Post BIG 4.0 PATCH! Notes:
* The game wasn't made any better. Not even a little bit. OK, SETA is back, but once you get used to life without it, it doesn't add enough to increase the value of this game. Patch 4.0 is all about selling the new Home of Light DLC. I'm not paying my money for it unless it gets down to $2 or less, so no review from me.
* There's a cool new bug that you sometimes encounter. Egosoft apparently doesn't want you to Alt-Tab out of their game, so they put in an eternally long loading cycle every time you task back in. Well, they also somehow forgot how to make fullscreen DirectX application lock focus. So, sometimes when you start up, every click will switch focus to or out of the app. What that means is when the game loads and you click, you are taken to the desktop. If you click anything, you are taken back to the loading screen. Infinite cycle. The only way I've found out of it is to hard power down. And the best part is that you get this beautiful new bug without even buying the DLC! Yay?

Original review:
I knew about all the changes from X3 up to X Rebirth. I have read all the threads and gotten myself up to date on all the issues and complaints.
They're all true.
This is a very bad space combat sim that has some trade stuff somewhere in it.
I got about 2 hours into the campaign and hit a game-breaking bug. Really, I was about 40 minutes into the campaign but I'm having a very hard time overcoming the horrible controls to be effective enough in the 12-versus-1 combat situations you randomly find yourself in. It's not that the opposing AI is any good; it isn't. It's just that AI boats are high-performance dogfighters carrying 360-degree NeverMiss InstaPwn(TM) cannons stolen directly from LucasArts' worst titles while all you have is a canoe, a paddle, and a slingshot. I've tried both keyboard and controller techniques; both are awful.
After all this time, X Rebirth still is not ready. If you want a space combat sim, find another developer. If you want the Trade Fight Build Think of older Egosoft games, buy one of the older Egosoft games. X Rebirth is just terrible. Except the visuals. You get a long time to look at their pretty visuals on each 10 minute Game Over" screen.

* The main voice actor is a minimal OK. All the rest that I've encountered so far are so bad that it would be a shame if someone didn't make a parody. You will relearn the definition of "annoying" every time your copilot tells your ship to shut up (about every 10 seconds or so).
* Navigation just doesn't ever make any sense. I didn't find the space highways to be nearly as terrible as the complaints made them out to be
date: but I never know where I am or how to get to anything else. The map system just doesn't make nearly as much sense as it did in the ghosts of X past. You'll be flying along and it will tell you that you're 150km away from your destination
recommended: then suddenly things will flash and the wayfinder will shift and your destination will be 20km away in an entirely different direction. It's like the areas are stitched together but the boundaries don't line up
hoursPlayed:
or something. You can't select targets or set waypoints or really do much of anything useful with the maps.
* The controls are just terrible.
* The menu system was made to be exceedingly awful so that the controls wouldn't seem so bad.
* Accessing the various commands for your other assets is so painful that you don't want to do it. The game is deep like old versions but it's almost as if they learned nothing from those experiences. They should have saved some of the money that they spent on the visuals to hire at least one UX expert.
* The exterior visuals on the stations are kind of OK but you're forced to fly around them and scan every little surface. It just doesn't make sense. And after the third station

reviewText:
Not everyone's cup of tea, not for the faint-hearted or impatient, not for those who can't move on from X3!

This game has come a long way since release with a ton of bug fixes, feature improvements and slowly but surely a growing mod community.  Some of the fundamental design changes since the X3 games still haunt it - smalltalk is dull and irritating, customisation options are dumbed down, single ship, badly voiced and poorly scripted lifeless NPCs, slow slow slow progress.....

But - it's addictive and what does work generally works well - it looks beautiful on a decent rig, flight paths are very realistic, scale is huge.

Overall, I'd give it 7 out of 10 as of v3.50 but you can see the potential here and hopefully things will get better and better as more content and features are added.

reviewText:
This game is currently beta-quality, and it has many, sometimes game-breaking, bugs. If bugs and performance issues turn you off, then you should not consider purchasing this game for at least a few weeks. However, this is NOT an abandoned title. The developers are keen on fixing these bugs, and they release regular weekly updates which do improve the game.

If you are coming from older X-titles, then you probably expect more of the same. While many things were carried over from the older games, X Rebirth is very different in many respects (for better or worse):

GOOD (non-exhaustive list):
• The universe feels more alive than in previous X-titles.
• The space-flight visuals are often cinematic, reminiscent of sequences from movies like Blade Runner and The Fifth Element.
• Fewer loading screens. Similar to other open world games, such as Skyrim, or GTA, you can travel vast distances without encountering a loading screen. The highways, for instance, will save you hours of travel, but you are also free to travel outside of them if you wish.
• Capital ships appear much more massive than in the prior X-titles. Dock with one of these ships and walk around on its platform in the middle of a heated battle, and you will feel very small.
• I have not finished the campaign, admittedly due to bugs, but so far I do enjoy it more than the campaigns in prior X-titles.

SORTA-GOOD, SORTA-BAD (non-exhaustive):
• You may only fly one ship. Some people will enjoy the fact that the game has been balanced around the abilities of a single playable ship. Others, especially veterans of the prior X games, may miss the freedom to choose what to fly.
• SETA is gone, replaced by a more immersive system of highways which connect zones together, offering fast (yet still interactive) travel between them. Without SETA, unfortunately, some players will grow impatient as their trade ships lumber toward their destinations.
• You may now walk around inside stations. There is a lot of potential for gameplay-depth here, but the feature is currently not very engaging and appears unfinished.

BAD (non-exhaustive):
• Trades are tedious. Expect to babysit each of your trade ships. Automation made trading tolerable for me in the prior X-titles, but this feature doesn't seem to exist in X Rebirth. Not yet, anyway.
• The NPC models are ugly. I don’t know whether it’s the artificial gravity, or the lack of a proper atmosphere, but human skin apparently doesn’t hold up well in space — expect to either laugh or cringe at the organic sights that await you on space stations and capital ships.
• Stations, although populated with NPCs, feel mostly lifeless. NPCs sit, stand, or weld metal objects, but rarely do anything else — they do not interact with each other, nor do they walk around with any purpose whatsoever. This aspect of the game needs a lot of improvement.

CONCLUSION:
X Rebirth is an incredibly ambitious game, and when it works it delivers an experience you won’t find anywhere else. At times the game is frustrating, but the developer is working hard to address the issues.

I recommend this game to enthusiasts of the space genre who do not mind paying full-price for a game that is still beta-quality.

reviewText: Now tbh I've never play any X games before so X:R is my first impression of the franchise. But i remain strangely charmed by this game. Maybe it's the huge freedom I have in the game universe, or that the game is so mod friendly that players disappointed by it can try to fix it with mods, or that the devs are still cranking out patches and fixes to a game that many think have killed the series. I would recommend this game to ppl that are fresh to the franchise and also old timers who might have rage quitted after the release. It is getting better, slowly.

reviewText:
The game had potential, but at this point in time I wouldn't waste the money on it there are other games that will work far better as a trading/space sim.

Go back to X3 Terran Conflict and Albion Prelude if you want a enjoyable experience.

Sadly as many people expected there are to many bugs and design flaws for this game to be truly enjoyable. The one truly good point about this game is the developers did spend a large amount of time making it stunning visually. The depth of a planet you get close to the stars within the game all the lighting and particle effects are top notch, but the good news stops there.

Unlike the other games in the x series you are limited to one ship with the ability to use drones. The drones themselves have various uses but in the end seem superficial compared to being able to pilot full fighters. The worst part about this feature is your ship many times will get completely destroyed as you try and use the drones even when there was no threats present.
In addition to this the so call reactive/interactive economy" is anything but either. Most of the ships in game are fluff as bots that have no purpose other than to make the space ports and space station's look busy. The ships you can interact with seem to randomly disappear after leaving/docking with stations or ships on some occasion's. its disappointing that such a huge part of the prior X games is regulated to a unusable mess.

Everything within the game from getting your other ships to do as you want to trading bulk items #i.e. energy cells and such# is nothing but a complicated chore that ruins any hope of you having fun or at least feeling like you accomplishing something. In addition to this many of the in game commands and the very ships which made up such a big part of the other X games will not respond
recommended:
or work in any way no matter what you need them to do.

The ability to move around stations is a bit fun but ultimately pointless. It seems the real reason you go from station to station is to rob the lockers of items and get illegal items in air ducts to supplement your cash flow as you cant get anything else within the game to work for making money properly. Though there are workarounds for these issues you should not need them as you spent money on a game that should of been ready after 7 years.

Lastly we have combat something truly enjoyable within the prior X series. Its sad
hoursPlayed: boring
voteText: dull

Wanted to be able to use 8 front mounted plasma throwers? Not gonna happen. You can have one of each weapon but that's ONE only. There are no multiple banks of weapons on your ship and no way to add them. The customization you can do to the ship is very shallow when compared to the other games within this series.\n\nThe final verdict is i would hope and try to believe that this game will be fixed by the developers. If not them than the gaming community at large through many mods that defined other games in this series. Alas i cannot see this happening as most of the issues seem to stem from core portions of this game not something that can be modded or fixed without major changes to the game it self. We will just have to wait for the next true X series game or perhaps the new Star Citizen that seems to have allot of promise."

reviewText:
Don't listen to the non-fanboys.  This is a true spacegame.  It has a few flaws, but what game doesn't?  Tetris; that's it.

If you want to play a scripted, repetitive game, play Elite Dangerous.  That game even lets you put on your boosters to your next waypoint, so that you can go do the laundry, dishes, and prepare dinner before you arrive at the destination.  Truly Immersive.

This game provides freedom, environments with different asthetics, and Workshop mods.  It is obvious that the developers tried to make this an AI social experiment with you thrown in the middle of it.

You don't compete with anyone but your own ambition--so, wait for a sale.

reviewText:
The game really needed an additional year in the oven before releasing. What Egosoft was thinking when they released it in 2013 is beyond me. At its launch, the game was terrible. Barely anything worked, game breaking bugs were everywhere, it felt more like an alpha test for the game than anything else and because of that it suffered.

I decided back then that I wouldn't give it a review back then due to the sour taste it left in my mouth and just put it on the backburner for 3 years. Yea ... 3 years.

When I saw the 4.0 update I decided that it was time I gave the game another chance, a lot of people were praising it since the Teladi Outpost DLC for beginning to show its colors as an X game.

All the bugs that existed since launch have been fixed, I've managed to complete the campaign without hitting any kind of issue. The story has its ups and down, but in my opinion its final act and ending are not what I expected and somewhat unimpressive. The good part about it is that it leaves you wanting more.

The gameplay is what you'd expect from an X game. You start with a ship, some credits and your personal skills. What you do from there (if you don't start with the campaign) its up to you. Either go the route of a pirate and harrass the NPCs till the dawn of time, take on missions that are either combat, trading or exploring, go out on an exploration trip to find rare materials that can sell for a high price or maybe even some derelict ships you can capture or just build up an empire and slowly conquer the galaxy. Yep, just like an X game.

Now there is one thing I need to mention. What is a very big difference between this X game and previous titles is that you cannot fly more than 1 ship. You better get used to the Albion (Pride) Skunk because that's the ship you'll fly till the dawn of time. And yes, you can reconfigure your cockpit so you can have a difference look about your ship, but honestly, its still just one ship.

Right now, the game is worth buying. If you can overlook some minor gripes like the 1 ship only thing, then the game is very enjoyable. Especially the empire building aspect of it.

reviewText:
X Rebirth has come a long long way since it's initial launch. With patch after patch after patch egosoft has managed to make a really enjoyable game out of something that could only have been described as a buggy pile of £$%& on launch.
Had it been pushed out in this form on release day it would never have gotten the reputation that it now has.

I've played a good few hours now & there was absolutely nothing game breaking, very very few little bugs & a decent depth of gameplay. The universe feels alive (with plenty of ships running between stations, trading fighting, policing and everything in between. It's a gem of a game, a rough one to be sure, but the amount of effort that egosoft is putting into it is now coming to fruition.

A great game.

reviewText: Turn, and run.  I played nearly all the predecessors from the series and, assuming this would be another iterative improvement with a new engine and better UI, got sucked into a pre-order.  This is not the X game you were looking for. It doesn't even seem to be an X game, just a console port that was never accepted for its console of choice, and so was sadly pushed into a PC launch wayyy before it was finished.  Ubiquitous bugs aside, the game just isn't done.  Maybe another year of development could have turned it into something special, but then it would have to compete with Elite and Star Citizen, something I sadly cannot see this game ever doing.  You can see what they were trying to do, but oh my did they miss the target, every time.  It just feels like a poorly implemented console game with none of the richness and depth that made the X series what it is (was).  Maybe in a year with a heap of community mods this will be worth 5 bucks on sale, but I hesitate to even hope that much.  You can get WIng Commander Privateer 2 on GOG for 5 bucks now.

reviewText:
If you loved X, X2, or X3, then you probably won't love this failed console port waste of time. What could you do in the other games that you can not do here? Almost everything. They dumbed down about every part of the X franchise for 8 year olds that throw games on the floor with any depth.

Now, all that being said, Egosoft has always had a hell of a community. They were always modding the game, improving it for the better. Egosoft realized this and has in the past released player created content as 'Signed' content, meaning its possible to obtain it without modding the vanilla game.  So could modders do something crazy with this game in the future, I'm sure they could.

Like I hinted at above, they have dumbed down about every aspect of the game here to appease a younger generation with a higher need for instant gratification. You pilot one ship, not a super awesome highly customizable ship that you can really make your own either. There's like 5 different types of components that you can buy for your ship, and maybe a variety of 3 for each component. One engine gives more speed, and less maneuverable thrust, one gives more maneuverable thrust less speed, and one is a 'balanced' option. Could having one ship if dont correctly be ok? I'm sure it could be, but this wasn't it. It's not exciting to buy upgrades for your ship when there really is only a couple ways to go.

Another problem, not only could you not really customize your ship, but you are not worthy of a cargo bay. Modders have attacked this already, but the base game left out your personal ability to trade. To trade you had to take one of your ships that is meant for the ware you are trying to buy and order it to make the purchase while you are there in sector. What a most horrible system. In the other X games you could order your ship half way across the galaxy to do something, true freedom

The weapons made for your player ship are dumbed down versions of the older X games as well. Maneuvering your ship is easy, and fighting is as advertised, but like I said, no customizability. 5 Different weapons, MK1 and MK2 of each, what trash.

I could tell you 100 different woes of this game, just trust me when I say that this is no X game. There are a variety of plays on the word rebirth out there that people are calling this game, and rightfully so. The game was released broken (expected as its an egosoft game, but who cares about that, they always fix their games. It's the game itself that has the problem) and there's no feel left from previous games.

In retrospect, maybe after a year when the modding community tears this apart from the inside out will it be a real game. For now, wait for this to go in the bargain bin for 2.50.

reviewText:
5/10

If they made a good tutorial, it could be a cool game.
If they used better graphics, it could be cool game.
If they world didn't feel cold and impersonal, it could be a cool game.
If they didn't make the management system clunker than a box of rocks, it could be a good game.
It the game didn't freeze up and crash sometimes, it could be a cool game.
If the game didn't feel overly complicated and confusing the first second you try to do something, it could be a cool game.
If it were easy to navigate the world, it could be a cool game.

Really, the only thing that was done right was the cockpit looks cool, the story seems interesting, and the world is very big.

HOWEVER:
They did just release version 2.0, and it looks to be very improved. Also after playing the game allot more, I've discovered it's actaully really cool if you can stick out the steep learning curve, and overly complicated systems. My only new criticism, is that they need to explain more things in game or make them simpler, and the story diffictulty needs to scale.

1.) It took me forever to figure out why I couldn't trade some cargo. Turns out, I didn't have a ship capable of tradding it. (It was canister type cargo, my ship could only hold bulk type cargo.)
2.) I've gotten to a point in the story where I have to enguage in massive combat. I didn't know I needed to upgrade my ship, and now my sheilds are too weak, but I can't afford new sheidls, so back to attempting to trade.

I still play this game, I still like it, but it has it's flaws.


5/10

reviewText:
I am a big fan of strategy games especially those in space.  Clocked up many hours on X3 and two years on Eve.  It took a couple of years for me to buy this but as a trickle of good reviews started to appear (and great value discount over Christmas) then I purchased including both DLC's.  What I like:
- plenty to do
- requires some thought and research (this is not an easy game but help is out there)
- great graphics
- excellent mods that make this even more enjoyable (although I personally avoid the cheat versions)
- space actually seems real due to some good dialog with NPC's (ok some can get repetitive)
- different to X3 in many areas but if it wasnt then why not carrying on playing X3

What I would like to see
- station complex's
- fly more ships (although in X3 once past trader stage I mainly stayed in the same M6 ship)
- greater character development and rewards as this drives me to play more and suspect the same for most gamers as why do so many of the great games have it?

Well worth a try but don't expect it to be easy and thanks Egosoft for making the improvements (although surprised you don't launch Xrebirth 2 to drop the hangover from the poor initial release)

reviewText:
You are the pilot of the Albion Skunk, why is it called the Skunk? Quite frankly because it stinks, this game has tons of potential but so far isn't living up to it, if you are a fan of the X3 games for the sandbox style of play, give this game a wide berth for now until the modding community finishes what Egosoft started. As it stands, you can only pilot the Skunk which might be tolerable if it was a capital ship but no, it's a simple fighter. Also the menu systems bring you to a dead stop so issuing commands in battle may do more damage then it's worth. Drones can be controlled by the player, but what point is there in using drones when your ship sits still for the enemies? I mean, you have a co-pilot that won't actually co-pilot, all she will do is pretty much sit there as a conversation piece. To be honest, i miss my auto-pillock from X3, granted it would crash me into stations now and then, but atleast it MOVED MY SHIP instead of having me sit there doing NOTHING.

Update: Auto-Pillock is back! and the first thing it did was slam me into the station i was undocking from... Artificial difficulty make this less of an actual space sim and more of an FPS. problems from my original review are still present. will do another update at 3.0 or when patching is dropped due to being unable to plug the dam with a finger.

Update: New menu system WOO!!! Game is more tolerable now :D Can also purchase smaller ships so you don't need to keep hunting capital ship crews, Omicron Lyrae has the coolest looking small ships imo ^~^ Short update for now since 3.0 is around the corning, can't wait for the profit oppertunities <3

Update: The new DLC didn't add much imo. Still don't recommend this game in it's current state.

reviewText:
Dreadful step backwards from X3, on which I logged many hours. Every aspect of the gameplay is dumbed down and noticebly worse, which makes this by far the most disappointing game I have ever purchased.

The basic control scheme is poor, the UI is near impossible to use, the game chugs along even on high end systems, it crashes all the time, the character modelling is about ten years out of date, you're restricted to one ship, you can't even switch to an external view... the list is endless.

To make matters worse - despite the UI being dumbed down it's massively more difficult and cumbersome to perform even the most basic trade tasks, which makes the game nigh on impossible to play if you can even get it started up at more than six fps in the first place. Avoid it.

reviewText:
Edit: The below was written at the time of the initial release, and I gotta hand it to egosoft; they never game up on this game and they've done a massive number of fixes, feature adds/changes and content updates. The game was released with version 1.0 and at the time of this edit it is v2.50 - with a v3.0 on the way for December 2014. A lot has changed, and I personally haven't tested the game since. Added that they offered an upcoming DLC free for those that already have the game, it seems Egosoft is trying hard to make up for the launch mess. So there is yet hope that this review might turn into a thumbs up soon.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

If you're a fan of the serries like I am, there is one word to describe this latest installment: disappointment.

The game launched with more bugs than it has features. Added to these bugs are performance issues - but what is really disturbing with this latter is why it's there to begin with: The game is built on directx 9,  and a quick look into the config files, etc shows XBOX 360 commands all around.

Yes, the best way to explain why this game turns out to be so disappointing can simply be understood from that: it's a revamped down X game made having consoles in mind. The menus and controls reflect this (seriously, you don't even have keyboard shortcuts for targetting) and it takes out most of what made the X series what they were.

But it doesn't end there. You pilot one ship throughout the game (yes, only one) and if you have additional ships in your fleet, they can't even be in a different sector than you. So long for massive space empires. Given the AI is next to nothing, these ships stand and look pretty most of the time instead of firing their turrets or trading.

Ah yes, trading. Gone are the days you could dock at a station and trade directly. You have to assign a frigate you can't pilot yourself to do that and wait half and hour for it to dock and do it (you don't have seta). So when the lack of AI and major bugs get in the way, you curse having lost that half an hour and start editing the save file just for the game to keep running on.

Well, you would expect dogfights to be good since you have one ship - it would be optimized you'd think. No chance. Dogfights are sitting duck shoots whether you're fighting a cap ship or a small fighter. Again, it's an AI problem.

The big thing with this X game that we all were excited about was to walk around stations ... guess, how it turned out? Yes. a disaster. All stations have almost the same interior where all walking around adds to the game is to open crates and get minor items. All these crates look the same and you wouldn't wanna do that all the time, trust me. Except, you have to; you can't disable it. Even if you wanted to talk with someone at the station, you have to dock and open some crates and walk around and open some crates and finally find the person to buy a ship upgrade (if you're lucky and it doesn't bug that is).

Granted, the X games were always launched as a mess - and tidied up later on. But this is not the kind of mess that can be tidied up - neither by egosoft nor the modding community. The basic motto is not there: trade, fight, build, think? Can't properly trade, no challenge in fighting can't build wherever I want and all it makes me think about is what good I can write for the game in this review (without any success).

I've already written long and haven't yet touched some major problems (NPCs, highways, etc). I won't either. I believe you got my point. This game is released as an unfinished mess, but even if it is patched up in the near future, what we'll have is not an X game that we were expecting.

The biggest sandbox in the X universe? No it's not. That's an outright false statement.

reviewText:
An unfortunate disappointment.

Broken & Buggy:
While some elements have been streamlined and are more fun than previous entries in the franchise (combat, maneuvering, traveling), the amount of commonly reproduced game-breaking bugs stop that. Launch bugs are to be expected, but this is equivalent to an early beta/access game - which this is not identified as. Required tutorial story line missions are stuck in a broken state that can't progress. Saving the game sometimes crashes and destroys progress. Basic issues that should have been caught haven't been - walk in front of a scripted robot cleaning the wall? Get pushed through the wall. Stand in front of a vent and open it? The grate lifts you, sticks you to the wall above it, and disables you from closing it. Sometimes, while looking at the ship's in-cockpit UI, the UI becomes non-interactive and can't be left.

Awkward:
Even for a game in the X franchise, this has the poorest usability of the series. Somehow, the focus on immersion lost out to having a decent, playable game. Having to wait for length animations for basic functionality that a player would do often adds to the tedium for the sake of immersion. Despite being in-space, navigation involves entering an animation where the character pushes back, rotates his seat, and waits for a display to activate. During this, the game world is active, so don't count on quickly breaking from navigation to defend your self. Accept a mission to pick up and transport a passenger? Dock and hoof it through repetitive hallways to that duplicated, shoddy model of the passenger, talk to them (without skipping dialogue), wait through their boarding cutscene, then hoof it or teleport to your ship. Want to ask an NPC for directions to a drone trader? Talk to them, press a dozen keys to navigate through multi-level, multi-paged sets of dialogue options in a Mass Effect style dialogue wheel, 6 at a time (4 + More" + "Back")
recommended: so that NPCs can randomly decline to inform you *after* you've went through 20 - 30 seconds of this UI to hear a snide rejecting remark. The cut for entering the cockpit of your ship teleports from one side of the ship to the next with no fade - akward and unpolished. While entering the seat
hoursPlayed: the seat animation seems to be mirrored for your copilot so that she flails and rotates in an inhuman fashion. All of this you must bear each and every time you do so and there is no option to skip.\n\nReally wanted to love this - played previous entries in the franchise

reviewText:
After a really shaky start about a year ago, the game is not only playable but completely addictive. The release of v.3.0 added a host of features and new galaxies which have brought the game alive, bringing much of the enjoyment of X3 to this verions of the game with the added bonus of being extremely pretty.

The game is also enhanced by the multiple mods which can be accessed easily through the steam workshop, which, far from being cheats, add gameplay and interest without destroying the game balance.

Definitely recommended although you will no doubt be saying goodbye to friends, family and a healthy social life!

reviewText: I've been a big fan of the series, logging hundreds of hours between X3 Reunion, X3 Terran Conflict, and Albion Prelude and am sorry to say that Rebirth is my biggest disappointment in recent memory. Three weeks after release and Egosoft has yet to provide a game which is either functional or optimized. Numerous bugs and poor graphical performance (even on high-end rigs) still plague the game. This may have been forgivable, but in the few hours I've been able to play, due to game breaking glitches, there isn't much to miss. The menu system is counter-intuitive and show none, I repeat NONE of the information I look to see on ships, stats, et cetera. The map system is an oddly unintelligible, two-dimensional take that is unhelpful. Moreover, the new highway system and removal of the autopilot feature from X3 makes navigation a committed and tedious process. In all of my save games, the trading is irrepairabily broken because trade ships wil not dock with stations to buy/sell goods, but this isn't a huge problem as it prevents me from continuing in the trite campaign missions (sarcasm). I can reconcile that with the tedium and obtuse nature of trade in this game. Unlike X3 where you could issue buy/sell orders to ships remotely without being near the station(s) where the orders were placed, X: Rebirth requires you to fly to each and every station to place each an every order in a system that is simply ludicrous. Overall, a HUGE step back in what was a fantastic series. Not only am I out $50 on this game, but I've lost all faith in future releases from the X series and Egosoft.

reviewText:
On the one hand, as a veteran of the X3s (I came to the X-Universe with Reunion) I need to say this game is not X4, which I found disappointing even though Egosoft warned us all along it wouldn't be.

Whilst I am tempted to say the game isn't that great or engrossing, the truth is at the time of writing this Steam has me at 520 hours of playtime (vs the ~1800 I have between X3TC & X3AP since I got the Steam versions) meaning that my impression of how much I enjoy this game must be a little off (obviously I play it too much to enjoy it as little as I think I do).

I do recommend starting with the Campaign, as the tutorial is baked into it, & you get a unique asset.

All things considered I do think XR offers the Build, Fight, Think, & Trade that characterises the X-Universe, it just does so differently.

Most tellingly, is my belief that if Egosoft releases an XR2 or an X4 (or both), I will buy it(/them) on the strength of previous successes, including this one.

reviewText:
First things to know:
-I started playing at version 3.20
-I know it had a bad launch
-It is not X4

That being said, it is a great game!

Like I said, I have not experienced the game-breaking bugs that most player experienced at launch.
Egosoft really worked hard to make this game better, and are still releasing patches to fix/add/polish content.

I remember playing X3: Reunion years ago. It has tons of problems, but they fixed them in later patches. Then Terran Conflict came out: very similar to Reunion but way better. So I knew that a bad launch was not going to be a problem in the long run.

I understand the frustration of early buyers and fans, but now it is a great game.

You still see on forums the usual is the game still broken?" posts. To those people I say: it is perfectly playable.
I had one crash to desktop
date: but it was my fault (alt-tabing during screen-resolution changes on a dual-monitor setup
recommended: the game did not like it).\n\nI run the game at maxed out graphs
hoursPlayed:
on a 1920x1080 resolution: no slow-downs in fps.

So here are my pros and cons:
Pros:
+Beautiful game
+Nice micromanaging
+Lots of options to choose from
+Great gameplay (altho different from other games in the series
voteText:
again: not X4)
+Constant improvements from the dev team (thanks!)
+Good music & sound effects

Cons:
-Repetitive dialogs
-Some few-years-ago character models
-The interface needs a little getting used to

So for all space-sim fans out there: I recommend the game. If you read reviews of the game

reviewText:
An unfortunately incomplete game that doesn't live up to the expectations of the series.

The game has relatively good graphics for a space game, but is highly unoptimised with frame rates coming out quite low.

The gameplay has been somewhat limited compared to the previous games, with the player only able to pilot a single ship (though it is a flexible ship with plenty of capacity for modification). In an attempt to create more immersion within the game the player can now walk around inside the space stations, however this is very poorly done. The stations feel dead and empty. Their is very little personality, with the NPCs all being generic. There appears to still be the capacity to set up the same economic empires that were possible in the previous games.

I think this game is not what it could have been, though I hope this is remedied in the future. Currently I would give it a miss and check out the earlier games in the series. Or check out the upcoming 'Star Citizen' (which isn't on Steam and is still in development).

reviewText:
Bad news first;

This was more of a letdown than Duke Nukem Forever.  I love the X series.  I've bought the games more than once.  This does not belong in the series.  The only controller that works right is the Xbox 360 controller, and the entire interface is made around being a console game.  The game only uses DirectX 9 (like Xbox 360), and the story line missions are buggy and you can get stuck and have to manually edit your gamesave in order to continue the game to fix things yourself.  This really feels like a failed console game that was ported to PC that was never supposed to be in the X universe.

Industry standard controllers, like the Saitek X52, do not work.  The button mapping is buggy, as well.  It sees everything as an XBox 360 controller stick for some reason.  Also, it won't let you map more functions to a keyboard and mouse than you could to an XBox 360 controller.  This is a PC game that is constrained by a console controller's limitations.

I'm still in the tutorial and it bugged out on me and stopped giving me any story missions or objectives about 10 minutes in.  Now I'm abandoned.

The universe" is tiny.  There's only one camera view for your ship and only one small ship to fly.  You will not be commanding a large capitol ship yourself into epic battles.

There are maybe 10 different NPCs reused everywhere and only 3 different tiny interiors of space station ports.  Going inside of the space stations is obnoxiously painful
date: and the NPCs treat you rudely for no reason and repeat the same few phrases over and over.  It is also a pain to find the vendors you trade with and the interface to trade is awful.  It's just like a big F You when I am talking to every NPC to try to get the story to progress and trigger something
recommended: and they all end a conversation with something snarky like "Nice chat.  NOT!"\n\nThe economy is less advanced than current convenient stores.  It's seriously like each little port is a mostly empty farmer's market with a few NPCs that will trade with you
hoursPlayed: but you have to find them and sit through their insulting chat.\n\nThere is a trading system you can do from your ship
voteText: but I cannot figure out for the life of me if I am buying or selling items and where they are going or where the money is going.  I don't know if I'm buying missles or selling them.  What is the difference between To Sales and To Offers?  I have no idea.  I think I accidentally sold all of my missles

votesHelpful:
but maybe my large ship had them?  I couldn't figure it out at all.

There is no radar for space battles.   No radar.  NO RADAR.  How do you dogfight with no radar to track enemies?  All you have is pointers around your view screen for directions.

Oh yeah.  No targetting
votesTotal:
either.

The Good:

The art design for the ships and exteriors of the space stations are amazing.  The art direction really is inspiringly beautiful in how they designed things.  You can get a sense for the purpose of various parts of stations and ships just by looking at them.  It is a joy to first explore them.  Even with only DirectX 9

reviewText:
I came to this game after having put 60+ hours plus into the X3 games and expansions. Loving X3 i was really excited about this landing.

But i'm sorry to say this game is buggy and broken and not a patch on on the previous X games. Yeah its pretty to look at a glance but once you start spending time with it and looking in detail you see how broken it is.

Capital ships phase straight through stations and now seem to fly faster than the smallest ships.

After about 7 steps of the main storyline i came across a game breaking bug that means you can proceed any further.

While still hand holding you through the basics the game asks you to buy a certain type of drone, after spending about an hour looking for someone who sells the certain drone, the game hasn't left you with enough cash to buy it and gives you no signs at all to go and make cash. You have to go and explore...

Which wouldn't be too bad if the station explanations and exploration is impossible to get to grips with.

This wasn't a one off, this happened several times, in the end i gave up.

I tried this game on launch and 6 months after, after several patches... they haven't fixed it.

If you want a deep space game with decent mechanics, stick to X3 and the expansions

reviewText:
Short review: If you really want to try this game, either (A) wait for a great sale (at least 1/2 off) or (B) buy X3 Terran Conflict and Albion Prelude.

Long review:
Simulation games, especially space simulators run a very tight rope. They must be open enough to allow the player to experience the universe, but structured and formatted well enough to ensure the experience is a fun and pleasant one. Anyone who has seen 2001: a Space Odyssey knows that simulating space exactly would be maddening, boring, and above all, not really a game. In the past, Egosoft has managed (with a great deal of modder and community help) to make an enjoyable space sim. They managed to balance the openness of the universe with (albeit a bit buggy) mechanics. Although the learning curve was steep, the rewards were worth it when you found yourself the ruler of an interstellar empire.

For X rebirth, Egosoft decided to sprint full speed ahead, oblivious to that balancing act, and fell off that rope before it even managed a single step.

Pros: (1) Graphics update, (2) Capital ships have subsystems you can target strategically, (3) Boarding and training marines are more straightforward, no more chasing marines in space or waiting for them to train. (4) I managed to finish a full length novel and download another on my kindle while waiting for things to happen.

Cons:
(1) You have 1 ship. Which wouldn't be bad if (A) you could actually customize it beyond 1 upgrade for each option, (B) you could actually customize the ship itself, beyond changing the glass layout in the cockpit, (C) your AI ships weren't braindead or hell, even (D) if you had a copilot that did more than argue with the computer and
(2) almost half my total play time was spent wasting time doing NOTHING while I waited for (A) NPC trade runs to complete, (B) trading to complete, so that construction could continue to complete, (C) follow/escort missions to complete, (D) scripted events to start, (E) scripted events to complete, (F) NPCs talking to themselves, especially during D and E, (G) navigating menus while listening to NPCs flirt with me about their wares". (I even managed to finish an entire novel in the time I was waiting! I kept it close by for these times)
(3) The design

reviewText: Apparently this game was poorly recieved when it was first released, but I can't say anything about that as I picked it up when update 4.0 was released.\nAs of the current version, this game is fantastic. Some weird dialogue is about the only complaint I have; otherwise this game is a phenomenal space empire builder. Combat is solid and satisfying, graphics are lovely, the simulated economy models are astoundingly complex, and the variety of different play styles you can go forth with make the game a little bit different for everyone. The detailed encyclopedia is also very accessible and helpful for learning about the game world.\nI'd definitely recommend this to anyone looking for a space game with a lot of depth.

I bought into the hype pre-launch and thought the game would be fantastic. In the 7 hours I played the game hard crashed 6 times and I lost save data every time. To complete a tutorial mission I had to edit a game save file in notepad and put my mission state further ahead because of a bugged ship that got stuck. After I finally finished the tutorial I closed the game and never touched it again.

The entire thing is optimized terribly and even in my high-end machine I could barely break 20FPS at the lowest possible settings. And I mean lowest. Don't be fooled by the screenshots on this store page. They don't reflect anything I ever saw with 12gb RAM, GTX 760 and a Core i7. It seems like when you walk around on foot the game is not only simulating, but rendering all of the activity outside of the station which causes it to run like complete trash even when you're standing still, doing nothing.

Now they are rebranding as X Rebirth 2.0" but don't be fooled

reviewText:
You know when you create a new version of something it's usually to add to the good features of the previous ones and remove the bad bits?
Well it looks like someone at Egosoft got a bit confused with that! from what i can tell they have added one good feature (ability to disable individual systems on large ships by careful aiming), however they have removed everything else that was good about X3! They have implemented some completely idiotic game mechanics, like the need to walk around spacestations to complete certain tasks (all of which look the same) or the stupid highway system, which not only is an annoying mini-game, it's also based around something that only works within an atmosphere with air resistance!
you have no ability to look around in the cockpit (freelook) even though the cockpit seems to be fully 3d, you can only fly one ship, upgrading is ♥♥♥♥, i wanted to keep this short so i'm not gonna keep listing the dumbass decisions they made!

I've not even started on the bugs, yeah they have fixed a load of crashes, but what about the AI repeatedly flying straight into a satillite dish and bouncing around like fish in a tank.

I don't understand how a company with such good titles like X2 and X3 can go so very wrong! they have both failed to satisfy fans and failed to make the game accessable to new players, Well done Egosoft!

As a space sim fan, I am very dissapointed in this game. I paid full price when it was first released and regret it to this day. Bugs and glitches galor, and Im trying to give it another chance now that the 2.0 patch is out. The learning curve is very high, so the people sticking with it are a bit more hard core, or gluttons for punishment. The game is pretty, but if you have played any of the previous X games, you will be dissapointed to learn that you are limited to one ship, an annoying copilot, bad voice acting, and some ugly NPC's when you have to encounter them.

I dont know anybody who likes to pilot sim games with mouse and keyboard controls, but there is support for a 360 controller, which is ok at best. And if you have a decent flight stick, expect to spend a good amount of time remapping controls till you get it into a useful configuration.

Sadly, there are no other current gen space sims on the market, though last I checked, you can get the X bundle of the previous games in this series for under $20. If that isnt good enough for you, its still a long wait for Elite: Dangerous and Star Citizen.

reviewText: While Egosoft is truly devoted to the genre and their past games have been great niche games (go check them out, buy the X Superbox), this time they took more risk than they could handle. Not only the engine has undergone dramatic changes, if not even being rewritten from scratch, the whole gameplay was redesigned and changed. This results in huge performance problems even half a year after release - and yes, still in version 2.0" - as well as tons of bugs and lack of polish. The game still feels like a beta version at best. The graphics are shiny (except for the NPCs

reviewText:
When I first heard of this and saw gameplay trailers I was so excited about this game. It was what I wanted to see.. Or so I thought.

The game just is not as good as I had hoped, the missions (at the start anyways) do not explain what buttons to press for things such as docking and I needed to go into the controls config in the main menu to find them out.
It is also terrible for fighting, you cannot judge your aim correctly and even during travel it can be an annoying experience..

I wouldn't reccommend this game to anyone, it's just not good with the controls or dogfighting/ship battles. The idea, concept and potential of the game is great on paper, in practice it's highly underwelming.

reviewText:
Horrible game. I enjoyed the prior x games, but this is the 'special' cousin. If you enjoyed trading, forget it here. In an effort to 'streamline' trading, they basically made the whole thing shockingly frustrating. Most of your time is spent flying only a few meters away from each station searching for the hidden docking points. You will realistically spend 5-10 minutes just circling each station to find it has nothing of value to offer. I spent hours looking for a single profitable trade and couldn't find it. Epic fail on the trading side of the game.

All other aspects are just as broken. The system of highways makes you fly in predefined paths from one set of stations to another and forces you to play a really lame minigame that involves drafting other ships for added speed. If that even sounds interesting, think again. What it means is that travel generally consists of a low res view of the backside of some stupid civilian ship only meters off of yours.

Oh and the voice acting in this game made me want to hurt myself.

reviewText:
I was looking forward to this game for awhile.  Stayed up the night of release with my pre-purchase copy.  I saw beyond the worried complaints of fellow forum goers and knew, KNEW, the company would steer us right.  I.  Was.  Wrong.  So very wrong.  This game is a rebirth.  It is nothing like the previous X games.

The core fundamentals that make the X games are absent in Rebirth.  Trading doesn't work.  Using other ships for trading/fighting/whatever, doesn't work.  The only that barely works is combat, which is one dimentional.  Selection of weapons is very limited.

This game should have never been released when it was.  And that the companies behind it are calling a Huge success" is insulting beyond words."

reviewText:

In short, I deeply regret paying full price for this turd.

reviewText:
*Short Summary at the bottom*

X Rebirth... there is so much to say about this game, nearly nothing nice to say though ( the fact that this game single handedly killed off the entire X community, should make it clearer just how much not nice is to say about this game ), sure, the game kinda looks nice, but that is also the best you can say about the game.

the game is so full of bugs, that I had to use all 10 save files + quick saves to have any progress, because I kept breaking the game to the point where loading an earlier save was the only solution ( this happened extremely often ).

I admit having my game save modified to get the required amount of money for the 1 Billion achievement, but only because of a magical money drain in the game that caused me to lose money constantly, seriously, 1 billion, gone in 2 days of not spending money ( never found out what did that ( the log over everything, had no info about any money being spent either ) ).

The game is dumbed down and restricts you the entire way, even in the other game modes, you will never have anywhere near the freedom you had in the earlier games.

Without any spoilers, the Champaign mode is broken on several levels, it ends in a way that makes you go: and what next.... wait... was that it..... I beat the story mode....... IT CAN'T END LIKE THIS!, this dosn't explain anything, none of this made sence..... there have to be more... right..... maybe there are some DLC comming that will complete the story, give some answers, make some sense of this.... at least a complete" story... right?... NOPE!

reviewText: Not your Daddy's X! ...and that's not a good thing. reviewText: Egosoft, or rather the lead designer, apparently succumbed to their own arrogance and chose to ignore every bit of feedback from their loyal customers and chose instead to develop a mediocre arcade shooter.  I was alarmed when I read that there would be only one pilotable ship, but was assured that it would be wildly customizable.  They lied, there is virtually zero customization...  which primarily revolves around which of a half-dozen weapons to equip.\n\nThey touted on-foot exploration as a groundbreaking feature where we could explore space stations and factories that actually had working machines producing physical goods using physical resources.  They lied...  there are ~4 layouts of space stations with a minimal amount of space to adventure".  Hallways are blocked off via doors painted on walls and piles of janitorial refuse.  None of them appear to actually serve any real function
date: although one was obviously intended to be a jail.  I guess some genius figured that nobody would question why 1/4 of the space stations in the game used to be prisons.\n\nThey got rid of the time acceleration feature
recommended: claiming that their usage of space highways would make the game faster.  Unfortunately it just means that your cargo ships now take hours of real time to get anywhere since they don't use the highways.  And you end up staring at the ♥♥♥ end of the 34th century's equivalent of a Honda Civic while traversing the wonders of space.\n\nThis may be the most disappointed I have ever been by a game."

Cons

reviewText:
Newer: EDIT!:
I have since completed the campaign and it was a brutal grind at times (Most of the X games had that at some point). And I must say there are some systems in the game that once they have been fine tuned and you understand them completely its... pretty damned impressive compared to the earlier games. The automated trade system is absolutely lovely, manual trade was the one thing that always turned me into nothing but a hitman in the other X-Games as the combat was really the only rewarding thing. The boarding system is much more interactive and challenging however it can be very difficult to get going initially as marines are sold only as recruits and even with a decent commander they can still get wiped out in seconds of reaching the inside of a craft. Combat against larger targets is much more interesting as they have soft points that can get blown off individually (Turrets, Jump Drive, Engines). The new missle system is short but not very sweet, as they are very cookie cutter (3 different types for fighters, 3 different types for scouts/interceptors, 3 different types for capital ships and stations) also there is NO missle defense system, once the thing is launched there is no getting rid of it unless it hits you or self detonates due to range. Drones have had a huge overhaul, there are hacking drones, automated interceptor/defense drones, missle drones, and manual control combat drones.

Crew: Yeah these actually exist now, mechanics, marine captains, captains, defense officers, architechs, pilots and they can all be trained and have thier own skills.

The game its self is unique in its own way from its predecesors and it expands on its idea as its own and I dont think it should be compared to the other X-games because it is so different from them as there is no comparion really. However those crappy highways need to go away and they need to bring back the Singularity Engine Time Accelerator (SETA)

If Egosoft did the following:
Took Terran Conflict/Albion Prelude and put the many systems that X Rebirth had into games like that then they would indeed have a title well worth their time, X3TC/AP with automated trading, indepth combat/boarding, Crews, Automated Station Administration, Adaptive Drones and took the complexity and diversity of the Terran Conflict/Albion Prelude and that would be something I would gawk at.

However the game its self doesn't stand very well on its own and its so mediocre that I still would skip it.

Older :Do not buy this game for its current price it is NOT worth 50 Dollars. I have been a veteran of the X series since X2 The Threat and I have no idea what Egosoft was going for with this one =/

The game is mostly just flair and flash and the content is... repetetive, limiting, small and not to mention the menus are absoultely tedious to deal with and half the hud gets in the way of its self. There is only one ship that you yourself can operate which is just bonkers from the last installment of the X universe. There is a lot of new systems and scripts along with the game being mostly automated in comparison to the old system but getting the hang of these new systems was overwhelming and really not worth my time and I am familiar with these games, I couldnt imagine someone new to the realm of X starting up on this installment.

Normally I like to play a months worth or so of a game before I decide to review it but I just cannot play this game because I cant even get past the broken campaign. If they fix one storyline halting bug, there is another (I have run into two and after I finally got past one there was another I was stuck at and after the game crashed it corrupted my save and had to start all over and now cant get past the first bug). The game feels rushed and incomplete and I honestly think egosoft just flat out landed on their face on this one. I hope they completely scrap this, stop working on it and move onward because the storyline wasn't honestly interesting me at all and I LOVED all of the other stories up to this one.

Buy at your own risk is all I can say.

Don't give up on the series though, if you haven't already play the titles before this one and wait patiently for the next installment. Hopefully they listen to the community and get it together on the next one.

♥♥♥♥ Tyrone get it together!""

New review with 2.0...

I restarted the game, they (finally) removed the highway stuck on people mini-game.

Other than that, the game is the same, just a load less buggy. The icons of enemy ships and loot is still to small to see, there still is the boobs mini game... the stations still need to be identified (which takes hours), and the game is still 4 sectors big. Did not see new weapons.

There are a few new starts, the new cockpits don't block the view as much as the old ones.

Be back later if I find the courage to try the game more...

reviewText:
NOTE: I have NOT played any other X game. Also I have NOT played Elite: Dangerous either.

I have been looking for a great space/sci-fi game for awhile now. I've tried StarPoint Gemini 2, but that really didn't grab my attention at all. I was waiting for this to go on sale, and then I picked it up with the DLC.

So far I am having a blast!

Yes there are bugs yet, or you can get confused on a mission, but all in all, a quick Google search, and you can figure out what you are doing wrong. The controls run smooth, the gameplay is fun, and the graphics are pretty good!

The voice acting is terrible though. Terrible.

I will try mods later, but with the normal version of the game is a great way to learn! I can't wait to finish the campaign so I can actually start a normal game from scratch!

RATING: 3.5/5

reviewText:
Let me first say that I am an X series fan. I am not a veteran of the series, since I just started playing X3 Albion Prelude less than a year ago (it being my first X game). I absolutely love the lore of the series and the core gameplay mechanics. This would have been a perfect addition to the series if it had just did the following simple things:

1) Add a few more graphics effects to X3AP, like SSAO and the new anti-aliasing techniques such as FXAA and MLAA.

2) Add good tutorials for the X3AP UI. (Don't make a silly radial UI; it makes the same quantity of data harder to read, makes complex functions harder to access by requiring the player to dig through menus, etc.)

3) Improve AI decision-making

4) Add in-game access to an extremely detailed encyclopedia about everything, especially the history of the Albion System and information about weapon systems and ships. This exists in X Rebirth, but much of the potential combat depth of X3AP is missing in X Rebirth.

5) Build the rest of the game around it.

Admittedly, it would have run worse and not looked at good as X Rebirth does now, but at least the gameplay would have been better.

The biggest reason that this game is so buggy and broken is that Egosoft developed an entirely new game engine. That's right, this is NOT running on an older CryEngine. They spent a huge chunk of their development costs on creating an entirely new engine for the sake of graphics. This game will stand as a testament against the philosophy that graphics are the primary contributor to the quality of a game.


Final Notes: In X3AP, you could captain or pilot every ship in the game - including capital ships - yourself. You could create fleets of numerous types of ships all supporting each other in various ways, according to your specifications. For instance, you could purchase a carrier and dock dozens of fighters to it. If the fighters needed to rearm with missiles, you could stock the carrier with missiles. You could outfit one destroyer to support your fighter wing with anti-fighter and anti-frigate capabilities, or the destroyer might attack other destroyers while protecting a missile frigate (probably piloted by the player) that barrages fighters and frigates with swarm missiles and capital ships with torpedoes.

In X Rebirth, the tatical options have been limited for the sake of simplicity, rather than explained. Honestly, why couldn't they just make in-game tutorial videos for all the already-existing, complex functions? Change and improvement are often two different things.

Do not buy this game, even if it's on sale for five dollars, unless it's drastically patched.

reviewText:
Don't let the bad reviews dating from launch fool you, X Rebirth as it is now in 3.6 is a very very good game. You still need to mod it to get the best out of it but everything is readily available in the steam workshop. Great game if you are into empire building. That feeling of taking on a small mission, not being able to cut it and just calling in a full capital fleet to wipe the map with the baddies, all the while watching the action unfold from the bridge of your flagship (Youll need to DL the mod for this) is pretty damn good.

Complex economy is pretty fun too. Though I was clever and got one of my enemies to shoot at a neutral station. Well it worked and the station opened up on the capships following me, declaring war on my enemy by doing so, only this station was one of the few producing a very rare ware and with it's haulers now at war it could barely produce, spiking prices all over the galaxy -.-
That being said, want to make a load of money and have fun with corporate espionnage? Go sabotage stations competing with you, lower your costs and pick up all your competition's clients while you're at it. Game has lots of depth if you want to play around with it.

Severe shortage of guides and tutorials though, be patient and ask questions on steam discussions.
