reviewText: Ive been a long time fan of the X-series games, and have stuck with them through many years of bugs, fixes and patches. This game though, seems different. Its not an X game, its a console game. To clarify that, it feels like a failed console game, that was pushed over to PC because there was a market there. It is not of good quality, and certainly not Fit for use. Admitedly, it has got better over time, but not enough for me to justify the money I spent on it. I did learn a valuable lesson from it , which was never , ever again pre orer any game. The hype was amazing, and the spin that Egosoft put on it, made it look incredible. Well its not. Im sure it may be good in time, but its not something i could recommend to other gamers. Save your money and head over to Frontier Development, and check out Elite Dangerous. now THAT is Amazing and then some !!!

reviewText:
You can say what you like about any 'flat' parts of the game, but this is still the fairest space sim I've come across.
There can be an update every few days, and the devs listen to players more than literally any space sim I've seen.

Sure I don't play it much now as the flight seems weird compared to Elite, but Elite: Dangerous is charging £40 for some features it promised YEARS before release, and only one notably large update has come out in a year. Plus Elite doesn't have these gorgeous station interiors that boost immersion.

And sure, Star Citizen has better FPS, but this game doesn't come in $60 'modules' especially as a game that already took millions upon millions in Kickstarter.
Not to mention X Rebirth is officially moddable, both Workshop and Nexus compatable and stable with user tweaks!

The story has been insulted, but some of the competition doesn't even have a story.

Sure this game isn't perfect, and can feel a little indie, and even I might not play it very often any more, but the fact this game gets such a hard time is an offense to its immersion, beauty and comparitively generous devs.

reviewText:
I'm rewriting my review after a year of this game being out.  I'm also going to consider it from a stand alone point of view.  This is only an X game from a story line point of view, it does not hold anything else in common with the preceding X games.

As a whole, the game is free from major bugs, expecially the plot breaking ones.  The biggest problems I have with the game, is that for a game set in space, the areas are both cramped and to expansive at the same time.  The massive stations, while full of detail, can really become a hinderance while fighting near them as there is no reprecussions for the ai if they accidentally shoot them, but as the player, if you shoot the station or some of the civillians running around, you get reported to the police, have a standing drop, and if this isnt' your first time, get to have some of the police joining the fight against you.

These stations aren't so far apart that it takes long to get to them, but finding your way around them to a specific docking port can take a while if you don't have something to lead you to where it is.  This has been helped alot now though with the ability to gain access to all of the people on the station from near one of the dock ports.  You can also trade and recruit without landing on the station, with a slight delivery fee.

The stations themselves, while each type being very detailed and different, are rather limited in numbers.  Station interiors and NPCs also fall victim to this.  There are only about as many interiors as there are types of docks.  While each one is changed slightly, it's kinda like just rearranging a house without changing the base layout, there's only so much you can do.  The NPCs are all very generic, detailed, but ugly people generally.

This type of situation is the standard for the game.  Excellent detail on the individual parts, but so few parts, they repeated to many times.

Your ship, the Pride of Albion(aka Albion  Skunk as the designers decided to name your ship without giving you a chance to rename it to something worthy of a leader's ship)  Falls vicitim to this detailed mototony again.  Your primary weapons, a variety of lasers, are all able to be equipped to the ship simultiously, though you may only use one at a time.  As your experience, and cash, goes up, you are able to purchase upgraded versions of these, but they are nothing more than more powerful versions of the basics.  The missile selection is a little more diverse, mainly attributed to  the latest patches, with a good selection to suit most suations.  The engines and shields are also limited in selection with an average version, then one version at each extreme.  3 types" of engines/shields

reviewText:
Note: I'm not counting bugs as apart of this review.

Very upset to say, this game is not what I expected. Luckly I purchased this game at a much later date when it was being sold for 50% off. As much as I want to recommend a game that developers put a ton of time into, I just cannot do it with X rebirth.
Here are the reasons why:

1.) We'll start with the campaign; One thing I like about Syfi games is immersion. If you can make me feel like I'm in living breathing world with things to do at ever corner, you've done a good job. Now I must admit they almost had me but when I found out that NPC's in the game where not actually doing anything they're simply there for cosmetic purposes, that killed me.

2.) Voice acting, simply put, if I wanted to go see or hear talentless actors, I'd watch Twilight. The voice acting is absolutly, (ABSOLUTLY) atrocious. Coupled with bad resolution NPC models which a player would easily see that they all look simlar to one another, like a universe with a obvious incest problem.

What I don't understand if you would go to the lengths to make the outer world beautiful, and unique. Why not apply that same work when you're inside the station walking around? Keep in mind AAA graphics is not the bread-and-butter of a game, but keeping graphics the consistant through out definitely helps.

3.)  I've played the earlier installments of the 'X series' and enjoyed them very much, personally one of the things I enjoyed the most was being able to switch ships around for bigger and badder ones. Although piloting a ship is one-hundered times better in X Rebirth, you are limited to one ship. Many people will aurgue this, but point blank if you're going to compete with today's space sims this is a feature your game is going to need.

The good:

1.) With all that said, the game does have it's good side. One, being piloting the ship and navagating through menus is awesome, takes some time to learn.

2.) The outer world" (when you're flying in space

reviewText:
I have been playing the X series since X2:The Threat

This game is best enjoyed without taking into account the previous X titles, as a standalone game, it provides a fantastic and fun space-shooter/empire-building simulator.

As an X game it does fall flat as you are only able to pilot one (althought upgradable) ship, rather than dozens of options that were availle in the earlier series.

With the recent 4.0 update it allows for a quicker method of casual play, giveing you the opportunity for a 30 minute mission run, rather than spending a good hour or so simply hunting for an acceptable mission you can open up the BBS system and choose within minutes.

If you like space games, give it a whirl, play campaign first as it is just a glorified tutorial and then dive into an alternate start.

reviewText:
This game solidified my decision to never pre-order a game again, no matter how enticing the promotional material is. It took me seven months to come back and review it, the distaste was so strong in my mouth.

I could go into the numerous, shockingly horrific decisions made during X:Rebirths 7 year dev cycle, but that would frankly be a waste of my time. This is a failed clone of Mass Effect that was hastily ported to PC after the console release was cancelled, and it shows through.

Egosoft straight up lied about features being included, right up to the release of the game. For shame.
voteText: 20 of 33 people (61%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Remember all the amazingly cool features in the previous X games that made them unique, and well worth the long startup time and learning curve?

If you don't, you should probably go play those.  They're still pretty great, especially with mods.

Well, Rebirth basically took all of good parts of the previous games and threw them out.  It's trash.  Combat is completely generic.  The trading system has been completely gutted.  The menus barely even work, and are bogged down with annoying animation to transition between the pages (and there are SO many pages).  The follower ships that you're supposed to hire and order around?  Wothless interface for orders, and they mostly just bug out and sit there.  The first person portions of the game, walking around on your ship and on stations are not even remotely interesting and only serve to distract and annoy from the already terrible gameplay.

Remember how previous titles focused on setting up automated production/trade routes for profit?  Nope gone.
Also, you only get one ship.  Because someone at the developer thought that could possibly be a good idea...I don't know how.

I really enjoy the previous titles in this franchise.  They were challenging and unique games that occupied a special niche in gaming for me, and nothing else has offered a economic space sim that was even close to as interesting.  I cannot express how disappointed I am in this waste of a game.  I'm not sure that I'd be willing to risk my money on future titles from this developers.  Previous games make it clear that they have some talent.  This game makes it clear that they don't really give a crap.

This game is complete and utter garbage, there are better flash games out there.  I wouldn't pay $10 for it, much less the (completely insulting) $50 that they seem to think they can ask.

reviewText:
Despite fixing a number of things with the 2.0 patch, there are still too many things that require fixing to go as yet. Ships frequently smash into things that they shouldn't and trading can be a bit hit or miss occasionally due to this issue.

The biggest problems lies within the story however, which is supposed to act as a tutorial. However it's fairly evident that little more than a quarter of the way through, the devs got pretty fed up with trying to make the story function as a tutorial and stop giving any advice whatsoever about how to acheive the required actions to continue the story. Unles you're already familiar with X you will not beat the story without a guide, and even with one there will be many hours of head scratching. There is no warning upon entering a mission that you will need a lot more finance.

To give a short example, I was asked to do a food supply run, with little instruction as to how. After 4 hours of reading forums and experimenting I finally figured it out and was ready to progress with the story. Unfortunately the game neglected to mention that I would also be expected to build a space station that would cost me well over 2 million. Considering the amount of weeks it would take to build up such money, I say dodge the story and try and enjoy free play for what it is if you really must buy it. A buggy, broken and questionable mess that at least looks pretty.

Star Citizen and Elite: Dangerous leave this game in an awkward position, making it the lesser of the three despite being the only finished game, and your money would be much better spent on the superior competitors, one of which should release by the end of this year.

reviewText: As a huge fan of the X series, I hate giving this game a thumbs down. I really do. But it just doesn't feel like an X game. Gone is the series' trademark ability to pilot any ship you see. Sure, you can capture and give them orders, but it's not the same. Instead, you get the exciting ability to slowly explore stations that all look the same and collect worthless loot from unlocked containers that are apparently just lying around.\n\nI admire Egosoft's loyalty to the game and I respect that they didn't just leave it to die, but they are just kicking a dead horse at this point. The game can be fun at times and it looks graphically amazing, but it just isn't an X game, and that's all that really matters in the end,

reviewText:
Big waste of money.

Bought it thinking I would be once again presented with a masterpiece, coming from the humble beginnings of XBTF, and then through to the likes of the brilliance of X3TC and X3AP, immersed in the vast selection of pilot-able ships, vast galaxy, pirates etc etc etc.... All briliant in their own unique ways, so many features to list.

But it soon dawned on me I had no SETA, no external view, ONLY ONE LAME SHIP TO FLY, and there was no huge galaxy to explore, also the Paranid, Boron, Yaki, were gone! WHAT!!! In their place you have what seem like very rushed and poor models of the races you could interact with, the space stations were the same, just the textures changed depending on where you fly, and everything seemed nausiaingly boring. if more effort was put it it would have worked, sadly not.

What I actually received was a haplessly thrown together piece of gristle I wouldn't even let my dog chew on. This game is simply the true embodiment of old mother Hubbard's cupboard, it is totally bare, all the features you expect from the old games are gone. Prepare to be blinded by posh graphics over gameplay, not both as promiced... I will say that I wont be buying anything from Egosoft as fast as I did with this game.

reviewText:
I have played 148 hours of this game since its release. I seriously gave it every effort that could be expected. I have tried various mods to fix the otherwise terrible game design. I have edited save file after save file. The unfortunate result is that I am burned out by the constant restarting and the lost challenge inherent in editing save files.

I feel ripped off by EgoSoft. They fell prey to the same business/design choices that so many other games have, like SWG and SWTOR for instance.... dumb down the game to appeal to the greatest number of people, and so designed the game for xbox 360, then at some point decided to port it to PC instead. The X series has always been a unique game with a loyal, if small, following. They betrayed us.

Its 2013, why would you release a DX9 game in 2013... oh yeah, xbox.

Dont buy this game for several months. Wait until the modding community, the real developers of the post-release game, to make it what it should have been.

reviewText:
TL:DR - Some game called X-Rebith sucked in 2013 and ruined my birthday. Suddenly, there's a different game in my list claiming to be X-Rebirth and it is really good.

I knew my birthday in 2013 was going to be amazing. I knew this because X-Rebirth was going to come out the day after. I gingerly thanked everyone that wished me a Happy Birthday and kinda more or less glanced over any of the gifts, because the next day none of them would matter. I was going to be fully engulfed in X-Rebirth. 2013 was going to be the best birthday ever.

Then it came out. I might have played with it for 12-20 hours. Trying to get past the bugs, the glitches, the missions that won't work and force a restart, the loss of SETA, and everything else that I felt as though I had lost from the previous versions of the game. My birthday... was destoryed.

A year later I noticed that I had been given the first DLC since I was one of the inital purchases of this awful game, so I thought I'd give it another shot. Add in a few mods and I suddenly had a tolerable game. I didn't hate it, but I certainly didn't really like either. Things where progressing and I decided that I would continue to keep an eye on it.

Then 4.0 Beta. A totally new game that keeps telling me that it is X-Rebirth, but this game is really really good. I've got quite a few hours in it now as you can see and this is only because of what they have done since the newest patches.

Ignore the old reviews and read the ones for the DLC. This game is easily worth every single penny these days.

reviewText:
I've been reading and watching how bad reviews Rebirth has been given...
However I had made a decission to buy it when it would be cheap enough, and the weekend deals -66% was enough.
I loved the previous titles, to the extent of X taking over my life pretty much.

In anycase, the expectations were low thanks to the reception Rebirth has earned and I do really understand the reasons for it.
The control scheme is pretty much ruined; when things were fast and simple (map, property menu etc) in earlier titles, in Rebirth it's done slow and cumbersome. Everything looks like it were aimed at consoles, but on the other end... not.

UI is not only complex, but it lacks any sense of purpose. Earlier it was just complex but almost everything was where it was for a reason; and it worked after getting used to it. 7 hours into the game and I still have constant issues with the UI, never finding anything and things have been done VERY complex compared to what it used to be.

Story feels nice and for that alone I will keep on playing, hoping that one day I get over the hugely confusing stupid UI Egosoft has created for Rebirth. I heard that a year ago the game was utterly unplayable and that doesn't surprise me at the least; it has been like this for a long time for X-series... Game is more or less unplayable for the first year and then it starts to get where it should be.
I only hope X:Rebirth isn't where it should be, since there is so many issues still (at least for someone like me, who has spent literally thousands of hours in the earlier titles) especially with the UI and the way everything works.

Fighting is very difficult with autoaim set to off, using Saitek X52 Pro makes life hell - easier to play with a gamepad and everything works way more logically with that.

All in all, not a TOTAL failure. Not worth the full money even after a year of developement and bug fixing or the DLC. Still I get a nice feeling flying around trying to go on with the plot and the game draws me back in, calling me to play more.
A lot of work is still needed, but if anyone can do it - Egosoft can.

Against my better judgement I *will* recommend this game for everyone who are enthusiaistic about X series or hardcore space sim's"
date: but those who are not one of the two groups mentioned should really try it out first to see if they like it."

reviewText:
It seems like this game had a very rough launch and I'm happy to say that it does not deserve its reputation as a bad game.

Having picked up X Rebirth during patch 3.5 it seems that many of the huge problems have been fixed; there are also some very good mods available, just search by highest rated.

One large issue that I have with X Rebirth is the inability to pilot different ships. However after playing X Rebirth for a decent amount of time the ship that you fly (The Albion Skunk) has really grown on me. Piloting the skunk around the universe as you build up your forces has a Han Solo feel to it.

Overall the I recommend the game to anybody looking for a great sandbox space sim that features tons of emerging mechanics that makes each players experience vastly different. If you are on fence the about buying X Rebirth, wait until it goes on sale and pick it up for cheap.

Pros:
+ Sound track - top quality stuff, definitely worth the money for the sound track
+ Graphics - the older X games really felt lacking in this department and X Rebirth delivers
+ Gameplay - piloting feels fun, and large scale fleet actions with capital ships feels omg epic
+ Crew - you need to hire staff to run your empire, capital ships need engineers and captains. it adds a bit to the immersion
+ Easy to learn - compared to the other X games the learning curve is less steep
+ Replayability - with different start options and so much to do (start as a trader, combat pilot, or pursue the main story), the game evolves in so many different ways

Cons:
- Weapons - choice feels very limited, and no real customization in this department
- Pace - as with all X games, the game may be too slow for many people. it takes serious time to enjoy the game, especially if you are new to the series
- Bugs - there are very annoying bugs, however none that I have encountered have been game breaking
- Cannot fly multiple ships - this makes many people sad

The only space combat sim that imo got the balance right was Freelancer which ofc is now barely limping along due to lack of support.

Go for Elite Dangerous if you want a pure sapce flight sim (but thats all you'll get).

This is the goto game if you want something with loads of depth and life.  The game draws you in and makes you feel like your part of it.  The art of a good game is to make you feel there.  This game finally does.  While your waiting for Star Citizen give this a go

reviewText:
I am so sad that I can't get a refund for this. The game was officially released but it wasn't even in Alpha condition. In addition to all the updates that have happened since release, it's still a load of garbage for the following reasons:

- There is truly nothing to do but walk around cramped stations
- Attempting to trade with stations is one of the most ridiculous things I've ever seen in my gaming career (you can't even tell if you're buying or selling)
- Combat has no User Interface. You get a targetting reticle that stays on your screen and has no ability to lock on targets (and when you lead your shots, you still can't hit anything)
- Trying to take over a capital ship? Forget it. Attempted that, couldn't even disable the ship's engines let alone comandeer it. It's bugged because all the ship's systems come right back to full and you never find out what happens to your marines.
- Dialogue is garbage
- Interface overall is cumbersome, you ACTUALLY TURN in your chair when you open a window by accident, completely blinding you even while in a fight.

And the kicker:
YOURE STUCK IN ONE SHIP FOREVER! That's right

reviewText:
I really gave this game a lot of leeway.  I'm a software engineer myself; I know how much it takes to make good software.  I loved X3: Terran Conflict.  There might not be a single game I've played for more hours, and I'll have to admit that even that was severely flawed.

The UI in this game is horrendous.  The AI is missing.  It's terribly unbalanced.  There is very little actual content.  The performance is terrible (even on the lowest graphic settings).  And the bugs ... call Orkin.

All they had to do was make X3 with a better UI, fleet management, and (if they really insisted) the ability to walk around inside of stations.  Instead, they made this mess.

I wanted to like it.  I gave it a good try (and $50), and I just can't take it.  I've been scouring the internet trying to find ways to make the game fun, playable.  There's just no hope.

Maybe by next year they'll have something good.  I'll check back then.

reviewText:
This is the crappiest game I've have ever played!  Why?  Of the 7.1 hours I played, 6.5 of that was just figuring out keyboard commands with the lack of documentation provided by the game.  I finally gave up.  I’ve figured out command lines for Cisco network switchs' advanced configurations faster than I have learned how to engage basic functions in this poor excuse for a video game.

Oh, I don't mind a complex command layout—Freespace 1-2 had some of the most complex commands in a video game and they were epic games—but these developers failed to document the commands.  That is a serious problem: complex command structures combined with little to no documentation or tutorial.  Definitely an Underpants Gnome’s recipe for profit.

For example: early mission – acquire captain for your freighter.  Ok, no prob.  Get to said station, something Labs something.  It’s big.  Looking for a docking port.  Not showing one.  Looking at map, not showing a docking port.  Followed the beacon, takes you to a generic point on station.  Knock on the station “door” with the front of my ship – no answer.  Guess nobody’s home.  OK, consult in game control settings at this point (Esc > settings > control).  In the last X games, it’s comms, request permission for docking.  Tried that first, mind you, yet there is no comms with the station at all (a space station that does not talk to anybody, intereseting).  Going through settings > controls, nothing about acquiring/hiring personnel from a station that will not answer comms.  Out of desperation, just start hitting all other buttons to see if something works.  ‘I’ was the one—because, you know, the info menu is the logical place to put hire commands—and I was able to hire a caption after further difficulties with the info menu.  At no point in this little adventure did the game give you instructions.  All this took only 2 hours.

Moving on.  Next objective: deliver said captain to freighter.  Get to freighter.  Again, no comms.  Ah, but I learned the magic ‘I’ command now.  Nope, nothing.  Ok, tried generic ‘F’.  Again, nothing.  It did let me ‘Auto-follow’ the freighter though, so decided to see how that worked for later because following ships is important in most escort missions.  Oh, bad bad mistake.  When you auto-follow, it takes away all your steering functions and speed controls.  And you know what happens when you follow a ship that is not going anywhere?  You sit there with no controls, no ability to accelerate, no comms, no ‘I’ of ‘F’ menus.  Nothing.  You sit there.  And you stare.  And you contemplate your meaningless existence playing this meaningless game.  And because you are in space, no one will ever hear you scream.  At this point, I’m struggling to keep calm.  Again, checked the setting > controls for help.  Surely they list the key command to disengage the auto-follow.  Surely.  Nope, FU player!  There is only two times in my life that I ever got so mad at a game that I literally snapped a keybroad in half and threw its parts across the room.  One, when my Lustitanni infantry wouldn’t take orders to adjust its position for a Roman flank attack in an epic 3-hour long battle I had in Rome: Europa Barbarorum (there is no saving in a battle sequence), and here when there was literally no way to disengage an auto-follow on a ship that was not going anywhere.  The first was a delight born out of a wonderful challenge in a great game, but this time was out of a sincere desire to hunt down developers to exterminate with extreme prejudice.

After finding another keyboard and pulling the embedded half of the old one out of the sheet rock of my wall, I decided to reassess and continue.  Surely, I missed something.  Surely, no one would design a game so crappy that they would not document their user commands.  Loaded from another point and tried again.  Get to freighter, copilot says something about docking—well, no ♥♥♥♥ Sherlock.  Finally see the docking section of the freighter were ‘F’ works (not comms mind you, because that would make too much sense—see, I’m getting the hang of how these jerks think}.  Select dock, docking cut scene, now standing in my cargo hold.  The screen flashes a brief hint to tell your new captain to take command of the freighter by “[MAINMENU] 7-1”…  WTF does that mean?  I hit the ‘7’ key.  Nothing.  I try all commands I learned up til this point.  Nothing.  OK, I logically conclude that I have to find this magical [MAINMENU] that the hint speaks of.  Go to settings > controls.  Nowhere does it reference a main menu.  Oh, I have info on dialogue menus, I have flight and platform menus.  It will tell me how to walk and talk, how to take a ♥♥♥♥ in the station corner, but nothing about a [MAINMENU] or any other main menu at all.  Not a single reference.  By this time, I had wasted 7.1 hours of my life on this trash.  The game is just poorly designed.  I sincerely believe I spent more time writing this review of my experience than these crackhead excuses for developers spent in writing a reference guide for their ♥♥♥♥♥♥ game.  So much potential, such waste.  And I do have the TO bundle with all current content until this point (Jan, 2016), because I know some people were like “it got better after TO DLC released.”  Well, if it was crappier than it is now, then may the video game gods have no mercy on the souls of Egosoft developers.  If I ran a software development company, I would thoroughly watch the credits to write down all the names of every professional who worked on this game and blacklist them from ever being hired in my company.  Yes, this game is seriously that bad.

reviewText:
Having played one of the free weekends. I'm surprised that this game is voted at Mostly Negative. While I wasn't there to see the initial horribly broken release. Whatever post-launch version I was playing was enjoyable, immersive, and in a way outright addicting.

Though, if you're expecting some Epic Story-Driven Saga like Mass Effect or something more combat-focused like Star Citizen, then this is not your cup of tea. This game is more akin to older space sim types that your basically a simple cog in the larger galactic economy machine, which makes it partially similar to Eve. So in essence it's more of you being a random person earning a living in space while slowly building your reputation like the other X games.

The game does take some learning (took me like 3+ hours to finally figure out what's what), but after that it was pretty much sooth sailing

reviewText:
The 4+ hours I spent on this are maybe the most wasted hours I ever has spent in any game I have played the last 30 years. It is actually very sad that this promissing title crashes as it does all over the review board. It became apparent early on that this game did not resemble previous X-games in any way other that it was space based. To top it off the game is full of strange design decisions like looting boxes and air vents for useless trinkets. No auto pilot, radar or an understandable map.
I did not encounter any bugs, but then again I hardly got as far as just starting the first trade.

The game is riddled with bugs, even now after several patches if you are to believe the postings on the forum.

Egosoft aimed for simple, but hit dumbed down. You have to tell your Captain on your tradeship where to trade. Odd, didn't I hire the capatain to run the ship for me? Why should I then have to baby sit him and do the actual job for him?

To be honest, as it appears, this game is hardly the shadow of its predecessors. Stay away.

reviewText:
I was hesitant to post a review of this game, and it took me awhile to think of the words I could use to express my distaste of this binary vomit of a game. I have played many games in my life, and I would compare the enjoyability factor of this game to running through a federal prison naked while slathered in baby oil. In fact, I would take federal prison over playing this game because even though you know you are going to get ♥♥♥♥ed, at least it will be over in 10 to 20 years.

I have played through games called Temple of Elemental Evil, Pools of Radiance, and Battle Toads, and I can safely say that those three games brought more joy and memories to my life than X-rebirth. I have seen movies called Xanadu, Glitter, and The Human Centipede, and I feel that those movies held more art form and character than all of X-Rebirth. The images of ♥♥♥♥♥♥, tubgirl, and 2 girls 1 cup still haunt my dreams, and yet I would rather look at those than the character models of X-Rebirth.

Egosoft should stop trying to fix this game... stop it... stop it right now. Their best option is to apologize and pretend that this game never came out. If I could time travel I would go back to my past self and punch me in the balls. I would also bring with me all of the reviews of this game to warn the others of their future poor decisions. What I am saying is that this game is garbage. ♥♥♥♥ you Egosoft.

reviewText:
The game is in a pretty bad state right now, but Egosoft has a decent track record for massively improving their games after release. Don't get it now and check back in a couple of months.

EDIT 11/4/2014:
5 Months after release and the game is still a bug-ridden mess, just avoid this and get X3:AP instead.

Edit 23/4/2014:
Patch 1.30 hit and its improved joystick controls just barely make the game enjoyable but I did end up spending some time with it, so after ~20 hours of actually being able to somewhat experience the game I can finally write out some proper thoughts on the game.

Clunky, very clunky. There's no easy way to go about anything.
Want to setup a trade information network? While in X3 you'd send a ship to automatically deploy satellites in every sector, in Rebirth you have to dock with every single station, walk around until you stumble into a NPC that you can small talk" with
date: play a silly minigame and sit trough cringe worthy dialog and then hope that NPC can actually update trade offers.\n\nTrading itself is also an issue. Unlike X3 you can only order trade ships around via a special trading interface that lists all trade offers and allows you to queue up trades. The idea is nice but the execution is very lacking

reviewText:
Terrible game. I'm a huge fan of the X3 series but this game is nothing like them.

The map system is restrictive and confusing. The idea that you have to fly around little icons all over a station before getting the best opportunities gets pretty irritating. I spend 3 hours trying to make one cargo ship comple a trade in a tutorial mission and it just wouldn't do it.

The in-station sections look like they were designed for the nintendo 64. Poor character animations, and you are encouraged to steal anything that isn't nailed down right in front of people that don't even care.

I wasted 5 hours and too much money on this piece of garbage.

reviewText: I would not buy this at the moment. It is broken. I have and FX 8350, 8 gigs ram and a gtx 780 ichill which is faster than a TITAN, and I get 25FPS from the start. It should never have been released, and I'm truly kicking myself for paying £40 for a broken game.\n\nWe need a law to prevent this kind of thing from happening. reviewText:
Nice try egosoft, the only thing you forgot to do before releasing the game is to fix the hundreds of bugs there are in the game. its been a while since the game was released and it is still full of bugs. During 4 hours of actual gameplay, you have to think that you have to add 2 hours of waiting because of the multiple bugs there are in the game!! You target spawn inside a station so you cant kill it, your capital ships wont go to a refueling station, you cant cancel trades and all the things that will make you enjoy waiting for hours. But when you think you finished waiting, another bug appears and you have to wait another hour!!!

Also, some feature of the game are hidden! And by hidden I mean core features that you dont know how to access! Even some of them are missing, for example, you cant cancel a trade! But why would you cancel a trade? Because of a bug that make your capital ship stand there, watch cartoons during 9000 years and when you ask him again, he look at you, and go back to his cartoons.

So if you want to buy this game, wait a year, that way youll be sure (or not!) there are no more bugs! (Seriously, its a nice game, but its impossible to play it)

AVOID THIS GAME."

reviewText:
Ok so 2.0 is out and there are have been a few improvements made to gamepley, controls and graphics stability since the last review. The game no longer crashes every 5 minutes and the graphics seem much smoother noteably when moving through densly populated areas, the controls are much the same but don't seem as jerky as before. I would still wait for Star Citizen of you're looking for a really involved space sim experience buecause this isn't it, it may do to fill in time if the price drops below £10. I worked hard to love this game but came up short and then just gave up. It still isn't the high quality involving game that it was supposed to be and I fall just short of demanding a refund. The stations throughout the game are based each on once of 3 layouts! That's it once you've seen all three you've seen all of them and you may as well get the mod that allows you to avoid going into the stations like X3 series stations.
The voice acting is naff, the storyline is rubbish and the dog fights if approached correctly are a doddle so where's the challange? Where's the fun? Dissapointing to say the least.

4.5/10

Update:

The new update 2.5 is a greay improvement and really shows what a comapany can do when they realise that they have released a sub par product to win customers back, the game is much smoother and edits to the travel system have made this game a little less boring. It's a step in the right direction and with the release of 3.0 due in dec/jan this game shows a real promise of being well worth a sale purchase to waste a few hours on.

reviewText: I have been the advocate for this game. I have defended it to friends, family telling them this series is worth hanging on to. Sure the game was dodgy at release, but hold on for the patches. However, it's months since the release of this game and it is... poor. Very poor. In fact, I cannot believe that this was even released - poor. This game is still in development. I've played Betas that are more playable. The X series has always been at the pinnacle of space simulation games. This is a pile of dog excrement. It should never have been released in this state and charging the full pricetag for the hopes that the game will get better in a few months is appalling.\n\nYou don't sell a shirt with buttons missing for full price and say - STOP MOANING
date: THEY'LL MAIL YOU YOUR BUTTONS IN 6 MONTHS"\n\nDon't buy this game. Wait until its a rotting pile of garbage on the 90 percent off Steam Sales."

reviewText: Xrebirth is a good game it has alot of potential for advancement into something far greater than it currently is at this stage. For example a storyline with a mass effect 3 or better instead of just a space game add a people individual action to it. Also I have played this awhile. I have sort of grown to it. IF the bugs of station ships not working , traders not trading , It sure would be nice if there was a total overide command to wake the game or diagnose the conflict of what is wrong with the players game which said fix this or delete that or whatever without getting the error messages on startup saying cannot load game account stuff like galaxy communication not on because it was part of the problem and have to start all over in the game, or any other error message as a matter of fact on the menu selection.\nships not transferring wares between them and station bto builders not building got fixed along with the other bugs in the game got fixed when steam updates or modders update or egosoft updates . If everyone had some common ground to play the game the way they want to play it , that would be one heck of a game This game could really evolve into something far more that what it is. But everyone needs to work together with the creators of the game and steam and the modders. When a modder updates their mod and/or adds a newer version of the mod it kills the game for other players or at least the ones who do not know how to fix whats wrong, like me. I have come to the point of creating a decent empire only to have some bug mess up the whole game. But like I said it is a great game or it can evolve to a greater game it all depends on you guys and what you want. Please just fix all the bugs and compadability.

reviewText:
Version 3.53 :
Egosoft has finally made X Rebirth a proper X3 sequel!  Although X3 Terran Conflict (TC) and Albion Prelude (AP) are arguably better games for many reasons, X Rebirth is finally in a state that is worth playing.  It's not perfect – there are still many graphical issues, performance bottlenecks, and annoying restrictions that keep the game from being great, but it is worth 15 or 20 dollars if you find it on sale for that price.

For fans of X3 and the series, it is worth coming back to and trying again.  I waited until 3.0 to get back into the game since its disappointing release.  It wasn't unexpected that release day would be problematic: There was plenty of evidence that this happened to prior games in the series and that Egosoft added many features post-release that should have been available on release day.  Still, despite how bad the game was when it came out, Egosoft has written the wrongs right.  I never had any doubt that they would get to 3.0.  But for those who are still bitter about the release: Their anger is justified, however, outdated.  X Rebirth has had a second rebirth.

Why does this game now deserve your time?  It is probably the easiest X game in the series to get started with.  Unlike the other X games, the story/tutorial does explain most of what you need to know in the game(although the campaign gets frustrating at times).  Egosoft recently posted videos explaining advanced features that I would have never been able to figure out on my own.  The missions are also more friendly, giving you the ability to make money early without drudging through 50 hours of poverty trading energy cells.  The combat isn't the best part; and I find that exploration is lacking a bit as well.  So if those two features drew you to this game, get X3TC or AP instead.  This game highlights station building with an emphasis on building an empire as well as trading and building a fleet.  Station building is the only feature I can definitively say I like more than X3.  It is my personal favorite part of the X series, and it may be the reason I end up playing X Rebirth more than the 1000 hours I put into X3.

If you are new to the X series, you may want to move on to X3 TC and AP if you're looking for more fun and more challenge after X Rebirth.  AP is also easier than TC, so that game may be a preferable next step.  I would recommend playing all these games with a joystick though.  I use a yoke myself, and I find that much more immersive.  You may also want to run the soundtrack for X Rebirth in the background -- it is absolutely awesome but half of the music doesn't seem to appear anywhere in the whole game.

In the end, this game isn't worth 40 dollars.  It probably isn't even worth 30 unless you've already paid 300 bucks for a ship in Star Citizen.  I'd say buy it if it's under 25 if you're a space genre fan or empire builder.  This is just my opinion of course; I preordered the collector's edition.  I have no regrets though.  It was worth it for me.

Note: The Teladi Outpost DLC is a small addition of content, probably worth 3 to 5 dollars.  It's nice to explore and build in a new region of space.

My opinion and final thoughts: This huge game was made by a small developer, which inevitably means it's very rough around the edges. It's my opinion that most people who gave this game negative reviews think that it had a development team as large as Skyrim with a massive budget. I read many times about how X Rebirth (the game) was compared against Star Citizen (the idea), and somehow Star Citizen won almost every time. I find that line of thinking to be completely irrational. And I'm hard-pressed to find a game on steam that received lower ratings than X Rebirth (27% in 2014), even amongst games that were abandoned by their developers. X Rebirth seems to be the game that appeared at the wrong place and the wrong time.

reviewText:
One of the worst games I have ever played. This is not a simulator, nor is it an action game. The voice acting is horrendous. I could have easily done the voice acting better myself. The way you go about looking around stations to find missions is just terrible and tedious. It's so much hassle just trying to find a mission that it becomes a mission itself trying to find a mission.

That stupid co-pilot can f-off and so can the absolutely absurd camera view. Forced first person/cockpit seriously doesn't work.

Space looks lovely, but good luck trying to enjoy it with the worst fixed cockpit camera in the world.

Complete and utter waste of £40.00, I'd like a refund back from this terrible excuse for a game. This should be pre-alpha and it's far too overpriced. 7 years of wasted time. Should have done X4! And for all of the crap this game entails, I give it the almighty score of: MINUS-100 out of 10. P.S. Buy at your own risk.

Complete and utter waste of £40.00, I'd like a refund back from this terrible excuse for a game. This should be pre-alpha and it's far too overpriced. 7 years of wasted time. Should have done X4! And for all of the crap this game entails, I give it the almighty score of: MINUS-100 out of 10. P.S. Buy at your own risk.

reviewText:
I am LOVING this game.  Looks like I've about a hundred hours in, and I've barely begin to scratch the surface - but I've been having a heckuva lot of fun playing.  This is a deep, rich, immersive game.  I start it up and the hours happily fly by.

I'm gonna keep this short because given the choice I'd prefer to be actually playing the game.  I've only ever bothered to write one Steam review before, but I wanted to toss in my two cents on this game.  I don't know if you'll like it (evidently a good proportion of folks are still determined not to like it) - but I do know this game has given me what I've been searching for a long time.

I've been trying a bunch of space / sci-fi games - many of them great games - but to greater or lesser degrees I always felt something missing.  I finally figured out what it was.  It was what I loved most about good sci-fi: the sense of Wonder.  Well I've found it here in this game.

This is a richly imagined space game, with a bit of a high fantasy edge - places feel different and alive and beautiful.  I've apparently spent a hundred hours just flying around, exploring, admiring.  I've done some missions, I've done some fighting, I've made some credits, I've made some friends and some enemies - but mostly I've just been smiling a whole lot.

I've only seen the tip of the iceberg.  I haven't yet assembled a fleet, or even bought my first Capital ship; I haven't yet built an empire, any stations, or even my first trader; I haven't yet captured my first ship, or even fully pimped out my own.  I have yet to dip into the Teladi DLC, and have already pre-purchased the upcoming HoL DLC.  I see many many many more happy hours ahead.  I think I've finally found my Space Skyrim.

It must be disheartening for the Devs to see so much obstinate negativity; they had a vision and they've been working hard to keep polishing it (I'm on the 4.0 beta).  For my own part a big thank you to them, and their next X game will be an instant buy for me.

Anyhoo.  If the first hundred or so hours are anything to go by, this game is right among my few all time faves - don't know if you'd like it, but then I don't know if you like ice cream either.  Back to SPAAACE!

reviewText: I waited to purchase this game until 2016 as it had terrible reviews and I wasn't happy with the level of polish that I had seen.  I'm glad that I did. reviewText:
Finally X-Rebirth got me hooked with 4.0 Beta.

In previous versions I quit the game mostly after 30 minutes, because I couldn't get into it at all. Yesterday I spent hours on missions, getting loot for Sinza, Jumpdrive, trying out weapon mods, exploring the universe - it was dang fun. It was almost like in good old TC times, when I played 6 - 10 hours straight on weekends ... just one more sector, just one more mission, just one more Paranid scum that has to die.

After this 4.0 gaming session I instantly bought the DLC. However, still missing the ultimate micro-management space empire, fleet management feeling of TC and the possibility to fly other ships.

Good Job, Egosoft!

4.0 Beta 6 (have not played since 2.0)
Pros Visuals & Effects
Music & Sound Effects
Mission System
Great Community Mods
Challenging Boarding/Piracy System
Better User Interface
Discovered no game breaking bugs so far
SETA/Jumpdrive/Crafting
Increased Performance
Cons Only one ship to fly
Highways
Minigames
Yisha/Audio Comments

Pros
Visuals & Effects
Fly into an ice asteroid field, peacefully scan for loot and suddenly a huge asteroid blows up in an cinematic like explosion close to your ship - jeez. Jump into a sector, get a coffee, get back and watch Xenon destroyers jump in and starting a bombastic fight with battleships of local authorities - boom baby. New Shaders, SSAO and the usage of Reshade Framwork makes X-Rebirth to one of the best looking space games available.

Music & Sound Effects
Alexei Zakharov ... all I have to say about the music. Sound effects: immersive and great

Mission System
Lots of missions to go for, accessible via bulletin board system.

Great Community Mods
Lots of mods that make life easier in X-Rebirth universe. Capital Brigde Mod by Litauen ... just to mention one of the great mods available.

Challenging Boarding/Piracy System
Send your marines and the ship is yours - forget about it. You have to think twice before you start a capital ship boarding operation. Bring the best marines - which you trained by capturing ships with less resistance -, take out or hack subsystems to lower the targets boarding resistance, have a great feeling when the challenging job is done.

Better User Interface
The sidebar was huge step forward, also it's a lot easier to get into the UI, command your ships or employees.

Game breaking bugs
Well, I only have around 18 hours in 4.0 Beta 6: discovered no game breaking bugs so far.

SETA/Jumpdrive/Crafting
The Jumpdrive Quest was sort of responsible that I got hooked in the first place. I played kill mission after kill mission to get the components, kicked Xenon butts in Maelstrom - still missing one of them. Then I discovered the crafting/weapon mod system that just led to more kill missions. My skunk got well armed with modded weapons after a while, also it's supported by a fighter wing - this is where the real fun kicks in.

Increased Performance
Overall the game runs much smoother on my mid-range system (i5-2500K, AMD R9-270). I found out that some things (like the fish tanks in stations) drastically drop the framerate in full window mode. With borderless window the framerate drops do not happen. I can now tweak X-Rebirth with Reshade options that led to a slideshow in previous versions, so I can tell for sure that the performance increased drastically.


Cons
Only one ship to fly
One thing I really dislike. I do not want to fully control the huge ships, but more Skunk class ships with different attributes and weapons would definitely be good. Also a gamestart as poor fighter pilot, small vessel trader who is working it's way up to the bigger ships would be kind of motivating.

Highways
The sector highways are annoying and should be replaced by a different system. Coordinates to sector locations should be found out by either exploring, doing quests or asking other ships for coordinates.

Minigames
No minigames, no talk about AI fuss please. Add quests to convince the NPC instead or let us dance naked if the NPC wants us to. Minigames suck, should be banned in the X-Universe.

Yisha/Weird Audio Comments
Can be turned off thanks to mods!

reviewText:
i think its a good game, ignoring the review rating as most of those reviews are before egosoft patched the hell out of that game. i played the game after they fixed the majority of the bugs and glitches and it is a good game for those who are interested in space sims and/or econemy simulators. i think in some ways it improved from the previous games namely
1) ships arent restricted to six turret groups + one front battery anymore
2) lesser loadingscreens (going from one part of the universe isnt as painfull as in the previous games which was loading screen - fly to next gate - loadingscreen and you couldnt do anything in the loading screens)
3)the universe feels bigger(in the previous games the station were very close due to gameplay reasons, now we have highways, which connect the stations
4)capital ships are integrated better into trading
5)buiding ships and station takes time now, you cant just order ten battleships in a few minutes
6)equiping capital ships with weapons is a bit less of a pain in the backside
although it has some disadvantages when compared to the previus games
1) you are bound to a single, although upgradable, fighter/bomber class ship (might be because you dont have turret groups anymore so it isnt as easy to tell turrets what to shoot for a player so ego put you into fighter you are bound to, but thats just my theory)
2)every weapon type only has one bay". for example you have laser A which only fires one laser at a time and Type B which also fires only one laser at a time."

reviewText:
My intial play through of the game started with Campaign, I locked into the immersion of the Universe as soon as the game loaded but for me that is all the immersion I was going to get. Though my PC outranks the Recommended Specs I have been forced to play on super low graphics settings and stil lget around 8 - 12 fps and I thought that it could not get any worse than that!

I felt that the ability to play from within my ships cockpit was great though I was upset with only the 1 ship option and the very hard interface almost like it was developed for me to be using an Xbox game pad hooked up to it. I saw an icon for a Nightclub so I decided to to take a break and check out the ability to leave my ship... I wished I had not, upon leaving the ship I was met by a man with boobs... actually it turned out this was a woman when I showed the screeny to all my friends but none the less it amused me so... I carried on walking and found a Robot that sort of looked like a cross between a Dyson Vacuum Cleaner and WALLE but my eye was caught on something better, Advertisments for the strippers... a lot of raw skin so I hurried my way to the main bar where I was met by not NPC's not even CCC's just badly modelled mannequins with nothing more thna insults to throw at me when spoken to.

I met a man on the station selling illegal high grade missiles so I spent all my starting cash on them and returned to my ship where I saved my game... now I only play this when I want to mess about shooting at random objects. (Actually I learnt if I get the cops after me then go into the docking bay of the big capital ships then the police shoot at the capital ship hoping to hit me lol)

Overal I'm going to give this game a 3/10, It's not all bad but I can deff recommend you stay well clear of this title until either the sales or they patch it(in fact needs a whole new release let alone a patch) if your looking for something like this then checkout Star Citizen or head back in the series and check out X: Albion Prelude(the introductory game to Rebirth and the end of Terran Conflict)

reviewText:
This game is a terrible addition to the series.  It has taken the exploratory element as well as the advancement element of the X-Series and mutilated it horrifficly.  Also a terribly buggy release.

Came back to check if it got any better.
Technically it did.
There was no crashing, I could trade, and I only had one bug on the main quest line....

That said the core gameplay was lacking in comparison of the old game.
Still staring blankly at highways instead of a load screen when transitioning.
No fast SETA acceleration (fast forwards) so when waiting for something to happen it takes FOREVER.
You still have to fly circles around a station to figure out what prices are until you buy a module to not have to play a sucky mode.
Even once you get the module the prices are still ridiculously terrible until you talk to people, fly around the station some more and hack the station.
Don't get attached to your stuff you get early on if you're playing campaign mode.
Still stuck in one ship, and upgrades are fairly linear and bland.
They make you buy cockpits that arent obtrusive.
Couldnt figure out how to tell my ships to just dock at a station to protect them.
You NEED an afterburner to get anywhere without dying of old age first, but when you use it you're sacrificing your shields so getting to a distant fight is either brain melting or you arrive at half shields...

Nope, still cant reccomend it, if it were a star system I would probably score it in the 1-2 range.

reviewText:
Biggest disappointment of my gaming life!

I have been playing since the days of Apogee ( Commander Keen, Duke Nukem ) but this is the game that disappointed me the most.

I love the games of the X series before. While they were buggy sometimes the whole size and possibilities of the universe kept me playing for hours. Then came the Linux port and I was really happy playing again while waiting for Rebirth.

The trailers looked nice and while I didn't think Egosoft was developing it in the right direction I had faith.

I bought the game on launch and was massively disappointed.
The engine is *slow*, framerates are really low. But the worst is that it's not fun at all and I did try it!
The game mechanic is so simplified that there is not much to do. The freighters have little command options and the ones they have only work half of the time.

As much as it pains me to say but stay away from this game, it's not worth it, not even for 5€ on sale.

Too bad, I was hoping for another game in the rich X Universe. I guess now it's time to wait for Elite or Star Citizen.

reviewText: I loved X3, TC and AP and yes they were flawed and infuriating at times, but they were at least decent and unique games that were just a little rough around the edges. I gave egosoft too much credit with this game, I assumed they would take this opportunity to learn from their mistakes and do it right this time. They took seven years to do it for crying out loud. But no. This is a terrible game, filled with terrible WTF design decisions. I have no faith this will ever be a worthwile game. Everything good about the previous games isn't here at all, and the so called 'improvements' they've made just leave me scratching my head. I mean, at some point surely one of the developers looked up and said, 'actually this is pretty s**T, I think we need to rethink what we've done'. But they didn't. Sorry EGOSoft, but I don't have any faith in you anymore as a developer. You clearly don't have the self awareness to know when you're on a winner and when you're building a steaming pile. Maybe if you somehow survive as a company and decide to make X4 I might give you another chance. But I will be very hesitant to give you my money again. You did not deserve it this time.

reviewText:
Ambitious game, great concept. X games are usually awesome. But stay AWAY from this one. Riddled with gamebreaking bugs, horrible optimization (low fps on high end pcs), incredibly bad animations and character models, WORSE voice acting. Ambience is awesome, combat is okay (exeption is the fps drops), but gets boring fast. The concept of boarding cruisers is great, but there is no way to gague the progression system of marines, and you end up wasting ur time, and your boardingparty just dies either way.

Feels like this game was supposed to be developed for xbox 360, but didnt cut it. So instead of having a useless unfinished product, they made a horrible port to the PC, and just slapped full price on it, ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ on their customers.

I can safely say, that this game is the worst game ive played in a long time. NOT as advertised. STAY AWAY

reviewText:
Biggest disappointment of my gaming life!

I have been playing since the days of Apogee ( Commander Keen, Duke Nukem ) but this is the game that disappointed me the most.

I love the games of the X series before. While they were buggy sometimes the whole size and possibilities of the universe kept me playing for hours. Then came the Linux port and I was really happy playing again while waiting for Rebirth.

The trailers looked nice and while I didn't think Egosoft was developing it in the right direction I had faith.

I bought the game on launch and was massively disappointed.
The engine is *slow*, framerates are really low. But the worst is that it's not fun at all and I did try it!
The game mechanic is so simplified that there is not much to do. The freighters have little command options and the ones they have only work half of the time.

As much as it pains me to say but stay away from this game, it's not worth it, not even for 5€ on sale.

Too bad, I was hoping for another game in the rich X Universe. I guess now it's time to wait for Elite or Star Citizen.

reviewText: First of all: I really wanted to love this game.  I waited several weeks after day one, to have the significant performance problems and the huge range of different problems patched. And credits to Egosoft for actually making a big amount of problems vanish. The problem remains though: 1 1/2 months after release I still have a completely unplayable game (performancewise 1-4 FPS/s on lowest settings) in my Steam Library even though my rig meets the recommended specs and even improves slightly upon them. So no, i can not recommend an unfinished game( no matter how good it might be, if it was actually working). Pls wait at least several months with your purchase until all the problems are patched or at least make absolutely sure that someone with your exact same hardware and drivers has good performance.
voteText: 6 of 8 people (75%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I gave up playing the campaign because of the many bugs that made it impossible to complete, like a food supply capital ship simply disappearing from your squad to name one of many  such problems.

Whilst waiting for patches to hopefully fix the campaign I went on to play the free roam version the graphics are very pretty in space but the frame rate is terrible even on a high end PC.
In the stations you are taken back to graphics of say around the 2006 era, and without some mods you will meet some of the ugliest characters I think I've ever seen who all say the same thing over and over no matter what part of the galaxy you're in again the lag here can be a real pain.

The map system is terrible and I found it very difficult to actually use it to get anywhere with especially since the X3 maps were good.

My other disappointment is the lack of an external camera and no way to look from side to side, had I known this up front I most likely would not have bought this game at all.

On the up side there have been quite a few patches that have solved some of the many issues with promise of more to come.

As Steam seem to be quite stubborn on granting refunds my advice would be to look else ware for a space sim at least until this game gets a lot more patches.
voteText: 6 of 8 people (75%) found this review helpful

reviewText: I never played an X" game before
date: which will make this review of more use to those of you who also haven't and just want to know if this is a good game
recommended: and less use to those of you who have
hoursPlayed: and want to know how it stacks up to its predecessors. I thought I might start with an anecdote.\n\nTasked with building a space station in an ally's territory
voteText: I only needed about 60 fusion reactors to complete it. I searched every sector for it
helpfulPercent: but nobody was selling. I soon found out why: these were only being produced at 3 stations and my enemy
votesHelpful: the Plutarch Corporation
votesTotal: owned one of those and was buying every reactor that came off the production lines at the others. So what's a poor rebel to do?\n\nRaid their shipments
votesFunny: obviously.\n\nI waited several kilometers away from one of the factories with my cargo freighter standing by. After seeing a Plutarch ship dock and then pull away
commentsCount: I scanned its cargo
column16: revealing that it was carrying my coveted fusion reactors
column17: I made my move.\n\nI used my dumbfire rockets to quickly disable its engines and warp drive
column18: then went to work on the main hull. This was a long process but I found a safe spot just behind the engines where I could go to recharge my shields. Woe to the unwary freighter that travels without fighter escort.\n\nThe freighter destroyed
column19: I tagged the cargo for my own cargo ship to pick up. As a swarm of drones buzzed toward the remains
column20: I spotted a Plutarch destroyer in the distance. Several seconds later it was apparent that it was headed straight for me
column21: most likely in response to my little Space Pirate schtick. I had no means to fight a destroyer
column22: but I did tangle with the wing of fighters it sent ahead of itself in order to protect my cargo drones. As the last drone made it safely into the cargo bay
column23: the destroyer began to open up on my freighter. It's a hardy vessel but it wouldn't last long under that hailstorm of fire. I ordered the captain of the freighter to get us out of there
column24: then swung my craft around to the front
column25: briefly exposing myself to the destroyer's fire to dock. I watched from the deck as lasers streaked across the sky and missiles exploded against the hull
column26: hearing the faint sound of the frieghter's jump drive charging up. Moments later
column27: explosions were replaced by silence. The jump had taken me and my freighter hundreds of thousands of kilometers away
column28: with our precious reactors safely aboard (and with no load screen in between).\n\nI chose this little anecdote because it perfectly encapsulates X: Rebirth's interacting systems of trade
column29: construction
column30: and combat. But I neglected to mention a few details.\n\nDuring this whole scenario
column31: I encountered a massive drop in framerate that persisted until I left the zone and returned. The game crashed inexplicably some time after I transferred my wares. I originally tried boarding the freighter
column32: but found that while 8 marines was plenty to take a destroyer in an earlier story mission
column33: a full complement of 50 marines was totally incapable later on of capturing even a much smaller freighter than my target. The station repeatedly reminded me that my rash behavior "isn't tolerated in these parts
column34:
but apparently forgot to attach a consequence to their threats. Even now I can trade with that station as with any other. And the whole excursion was made necessary because my previous shipment of some 114 fusion reactors inexplicably disappeared from the freighter's cargo holds--the freighter made it, the goods didn't. It still had the order to transfer the wares to my construction ship in its queue. Upon deleting and reissuing the order, a message told me that it had no fusion reactors in its holds. Gone into thin air.

My point is this: At its best, X: Rebirth is the most full-featured, exciting, strategic space sim available that I know of. Though dogfights are a little awkward because the smaller spacecraft are so maneuverable, combat overall is exceptionally exciting. The game has made me think in terms of real logic (how can I acquire this good by any means available) as opposed to game logic (how can I exploit this system to get 1000x as much as I'll ever need). It appears, so far as I can tell, that the entire game is driven by a real economy: goods cannot be used until they're produced, and producing these goods means someone has to mine them, extract them, refine them, and manufacture them. This creates a living world unlike any I've ever seen before, and when I close my trade console and nudge my throttle forward (I use a Saitek X52 joystick) towards the next station, or merge into a highway and switch on the auto-pilot while I give orders to my fleet, I really feel like I am there, interacting with a real world in space. Seeing a station suddenly pop into view as I exit the space highway, or docking on one of my larger vessels while it jumps me across space (with no loading screens!) are experiences that just never get old.

At its worst, X: Rebirth continues to sport more bugs and headaches than are really excusable, especially with it being the fourth iteration in the series. You will encounter glitches. Your framerate will inexplicably drop to a crawl (only happened to me twice in 24 hours play though). You will experience crashes (save often). The story dialogue is fair, but most of the other conversations and text might have actually been written by a third grader (hearing a Marine Officer randomly chirp, valley-girl style, Eww
column35: slimy green lizardy things are everywhere!" is just bizarre
column36: and some of the logbook entries are so poorly written as to be indecipherable). The game does not explain itself very thoroughly
column37: and you will spend much time trying to figure out how many of its systems work (or don't work
column38: as is occasionally the case).\n\nI had great anticipation for this game's release
column39: so I was very disappointed when I read that it was basically an unfinished product. The free weekend just recently spoke a great deal about the developer's confidence in the current state of their product
column40: and I believe that confidence is justified. This is now a very playable
column42: and if you are patient and have a good tolerance for the occasional bug
column43: it can give you some of the most fantastic gaming experiences you've had in years."

reviewText:
Game is extremly buggy and with every new patch it breaks the old save game which makes the game unplayable. I dont even know if it will be worth a revist when they fix/finnish the game, by then elite dangerous will probally be out.  I have not tried the latest patch but i really dont have the patience to restart the game everytime theres a patch. Avoid this one, theres far better games out there.

Edit : retried the game 2 years later....

I have an i5 4670k and a 780 gtx, which is far better than the recomened specs. Frame rates vary but i seen the odd drop down to 20 fps. In busy places i get 40-45 fps on low settings, higher settings am averaging just over 30. Walking about in stations is bad, i often get 25 - 20 fps depending where i am. . It is better than when it first launched but fps is still bad and after two years of development they still havnt completly fixed the fps problem. I dont know what the fps will be using the minimum or recommened specs. Textures are still bad, audio is out of sync in places, no effort to add hair to characters. The game its self is ok, there is alot to like about it, if you can look past the issues it has but personally i find it hard to.

reviewText: Simply put, this game is terrible. I loved the previous X games, but actually found them a little bit too involving so I couldn't just jump in and out of them after weeks/months had passed so this game should have suited me down to the ground. However it is just an incredibly poor attempt from Egosoft, it was released in an unplayable state and I was amazed at just how much they got wrong, given the complete lack of content compared to previous games!\n\nMany people are irked by the console like controls and what looks to have been an intended console release at some point, however I could have quite happily lived with that if there was a game underneath that could be enjoyed without random crashes, a broken storyline, terrible lack of information on basic controls & mission aspects as well as the questionable performance.

reviewText:
It is with much reluctance I have to say No. I so wanted to like this game and mine and the community expectations pre-release were so high. Bugs will be (and are) being fixxed, but the basic design and loss of so many key gameplay and control features from previous incarnations has left this a generally empty and unfulfilling experience.

For those of you wanting a definitive space bulding and exploration experience, roll back and look at Egosofts earlier relase X3 Terran Conflict. (NOT Albion Prelude, this DLC adds game events that will  furstrate the overall game if you don't have a good grounding in the basic gameplay.)

For those of you who are familiar with X, then if you really want to roll back to an experiece equivalent to X-BTF designed for the forthcomming Steam Console, well, you probably got stung by the pre-order already.

reviewText:
I stopped playing this game due to excessive bugs when it was first released.
Now update 2.00 has cleaned up many of the bugs and the game is actually playable now. The hauler you control can actually move now to complete the trade mission. The framerate is a solid 50fps except for brief moments when combat begins. I am loving the ability to purchase different cockpits. I am using combat mk3 and since it is transparent i get the full screen to play with.
This game is getting better but I feel the trading to be uncompelling and going full combat is the easier way with just looting missles for cash. Capital ships actually shoot now so it is harder.
I do not reccomend this game, even if it is on sale since it's predeccesor x3:tc / x3 ap are both cheaper and WAY better games. If you are looking for an alternative game just look for star citizen or the new elite.

reviewText:
This game looks great when in space, and that's about it.

Currently, this game is nearly unplayable.
This is due to its many game-breaking glitches.
(One cannot even progress - early - in the story mode!)

For $49.99, one would expect the game to be - to say the least - completed.
But, it certainly feels like it's still pre-alpha.

The X series had been fantastic, but DO NOT let its past glory trick you into purchasing this game.

As a fan, I regretably feel lied to.
I really want my money back, and if I had a choice, I would redirect my money to another crowd-funded space sim.

reviewText:
From the initial terrible release of X-Rebirth with lots of really nasty bugs, after a lots of patching by Egosoft  today I would highly recommend this game to all space sim / trade empire players. X-Rebirth provides a unique approach to building trade empire, different than previous X3 games TC & AP, allowing building predefined industrial complexes in a step by step approach, station exploration and many other new features.
In-space graphics is  stunning, sound & music are great quality. The graphics inside stations and especially NPC graphics is still poor and needs improvement.
Afte exciting news that 4.0 patch with lots of necessary improvements and new DLC Home of Light with expansion of existing galaxies will be released in February 2016, well  simply I cant wait for it..

reviewText:
I picked up the collectors addition recently and have been giving it a go.

It is very different for x3 which I've spent a large number of hours playing. Playing on ubuntu on an under spec machine but it still plays decent with not one crash in 10 hours or so. So far I'd give it a 6/10 for gameplay. Very steep learning curve but that's one of the things I'm enjoying is learning how to get things done. Universe feels generic, ie finding a lost colony that's been isolated for hundreds of years, but they have the same clothes, same dang space station interior and space highways. The space station premise is poorly executed and feels like a waste of time but it looks like some functions can be managed over radio at least. I don't like the limitation of one ship, that was part of the cool factor of x3, but it's not a deal breaker.

I am going to keep playing, partially out of stubbornness to look past the faults and partially out of enjoying what does play well.

reviewText:
I really wanted to like it, I really enjoyed previous entries in the series but this one just falls so short in so many ways.

One example of why I can't stand X:R would be fast travelling, instead of having simply zoning or jump gates there's this highway system that's a bit like a drain pipe you have to fly around in.  It's effectively its own minigame and it sucks.  When I'm in it, I can't clearly see the boundaries, when I don't want to fall out of it I inevitably do, when I do want to fall out of it I struggle too do so.  I don't need simple fast travel navigation around the world to be it's own minigame.  I'm here to fly around in space and shoot and loot stuff.  Not to struggle and get frustrated just trying to get from point A to point B so I can participate in story line content.

I feel pretty much the same way about walking around stations as well.  I'm not here to play 'wander the station looking for relevant NPCs and random piles of cash hidden about a station.  I'm here for the sci-fi space ship sim.  Quit trying to take me away from it
date: or if you're going to do so make sure it's in exchange for truly fun and interesting content and not just a thiny vieled time sync."

reviewText:
Huge disappointment, thats to put it very simply.
Do not waste cash on this! rather wait for -Star Citizen- or get any previous X series game.

I was really enjoying the previous X series and had hoped that they would continue the series with X rebirth, instead they chose to make something that feels like a concole port, herea are some of the game breakers ive found so far:
- The movement of the ship is weird.
- The mechanics of the game are weird.
- You cant look around in the ship anymore. (no key bindings or track ir)
- The hud is boring and uninformative.
- No tutorial although the game is completely different to the other X games.
- The controls in general, including ship and crew controls are unintuitive to say the least.
- The graphics while pretty lack any kind of effort in the modeling of characters.
- The story is uncompelling and boring.
- Highway system while good idea is boring and sometimes confusing and is poorely designed.
- Support for HOTAS is very limited.
- Walking in stations is a feature that is completely unnecessary and is poorely designed.
- Interacting with objects is poorely designed and implemented.
- Walking in your own ship is limited to one room, you cant even walk around in the cockpit as entering it is scripted.

Learning this game is suprisingly even harder than in the previous X series games, at least back in them, most things were quite intuitive.

All in all, a big disappointment, a well marketed one but disappointment nevertheless.
