reviewText:
What can I say, this is literally a game that was designed to be released on the XBox, but released on the PC. It has many features missing, many game breaking bugs, and many systems in place that do nothing but try and ruin the game for you.

They force you to go through stations in order to get crew for your ship, and upgrade. The stations are mostly cut and paste between less than 5 models, and are meant for you to go blindly through and rob it blind. Character models look like something from the 90's, and there is no variation in communication.

In space, nobody can hear you scream as your trade ships lock up. Your combat ships might as well be ornaments since you can't tell them to attack, and unless it's a capital ship, it's dead before it can attack back. As of writing this, you can't buy small ships to outfit your fleet or small trade ships to embark on cheap trading.

If you get far enough from station, you can no longer access trades that were previously there. Stations are not able to be freely placed, and if you don't pay careful attention, they don't function.

The save files are uncompressed XML files, meaning if you have access to notepad, you can cheat your way to achievments by editing them to your hearts content. The install is laden with files that are meant to be used on XBox. Regular controls for computer such as the keyboard/mouse/joystick don't function as well as a computer game should run. XBox controller has full support though.

This is an alpha port, the developers are patching every day or two to fix issues. When it finally fixes enough issues to be a full release, I'll ammend this.

reviewText:
Egosoft. Whether or not it was intentional, I think you know that what you have released was not as advertised.

I am an avid PC gamer, and have been playing PC games since they began. I'm also an avid space sim gamer, and have enjoyed all manner of space games from back in the first Elite days. I enjoyed your previous games. But my disappointment in Rebirth is, well, palpable. Based on many posts in many forums, while my exact feelings may not be shared by all who have purchased X Rebirth, you know I am not alone in my dissatisfaction.

I know you are a very small company, and given the posts I've seen, you seem to be working hard to scramble together fixes for game crashing bugs, mission breaking glitches, and issues that leave the player immoble. My immediate reaction is - any amount of playtesting would surely have shown some of these very basic game breaking issues - why didn't you take care of these gigantic issues *before release*? I understand that no software is released without bugs, but come now - surely you see this as excessive (perhaps even for a beta, much less a release)?

Beyond the game breaking issues, there are so many changes that would be necessary to make this a game that doesn't seem to be some sort of weird retro alpha project stuck in the mid-90s, that I don't feel right about paying you with my hard earned money to attempt a belated fix for something that, frankly, may simply need to be scrapped and redone to even approach a mediocre product.  And the way this game was advertised vs the actual in-game exprience is approaching fraudulent. It seems like a joke.  Just not a funny one.

7 years? You worked on this for 7 years? I honestly don't buy that. Even a single developer working on a project for *7 years* could produce a much better designed product with much fewer crashes than this. You had a good base from which to start. What did you do for 7 years that this was the end result? I'm sorry Egosoft, but I want my money back. And I likely won't get a refund. Congrats for taking one more sucker for his $50, but fool me once..." It will never happen again."

reviewText:
X: Rebirth looks to be an immersive game, but ultimately the gameplay is neither fun nor even engrossing.
As a massive fan of space games and someone who loved X3:TC and X3:AP (51 hrs and 59 hrs), I was eagerly anticipating the X: Rebirth launch as a chance to reengage in the space genre, but this time as a freelancer pilot in an exciting universe.  Unfortunately, X: Rebirth is not that game.

Ultimately, the game may be fun at some point, but there are far too many constant gameplay aspects that try to be immersive and accessible at the expense of true immersion and fun.  It feels as though the game was not properly play-tested by players, and the experience suffers.  That being said, I’m sure examples would help.  This is not an exhaustive list, but here are some highlights.

1.	In order to trade larger trade goods, you must fly and find trading points to setup the order.  While that means you need to travel, this doesn’t make sense in context of being “in the future.”  How is there not a global listing for known trade hubs/markets/etc?  I understand wanting people to fly to these locations to make them more real, but ultimately this feels forced and unrealistic.

2.	In order to trade smaller goods, you must dock at a station point and then run inside the station to get to individual traders.  This is not realistic nor immersive. I have drones, warp-speed and ‘advanced’ computer systems, but I can’t make transactions via my ship?  It’s like the trade system was designed for a medieval RPG.

3.	Exploration consists of sending out a radar-like beacon and flying to hits.  I really liked this initially, but unfortunately it’s mostly just random items in cans and I have no way to distinguish junk from large ships or hidden nuggets (if they exist).  Once I retrieve these goods, I have to walk in a station to trade said good.  This doesn’t make me feel immersed, this makes me feel like I’m playing a poorly designed game.

4.	I’m only able to fly in my one cockpit view.  It’s neat how I move to my seat and can move around the ship, but the display is far too obstructive.  ~30% of the viewing space is taken up by cockpit walls/dashboard.  It is incredibly restrictive, and ultimately doesn’t make sense.  When I’m in a car, the top of the windshield isn’t 15% of my field of view so why would a spacecraft be the same way.

5.	GUI and map interface are atrocious.  Yes, the game was designed for console players, but unfortunately things are just archaic feeling.  Why can’t I zoom in/out of the map?  If I can, why isn’t there a button on the map to press?  Why do I need to use a Mass Effect style convo bar to access menu items that could easily be accessed by a sidebar or escape menu?

I really wanted to enjoy this game, but it’s not really a game and more of a chore.  If you enjoyed the world immersion of X3:TC or X3:AP, look somewhere else.  Maybe EVE Online for the truly immersive world.  Forcing someone to walk around like a character in a medieval RPG is not actual immersion, it’s only a narrow-minded developer opinion of true immersion.

reviewText:
Being a huge fan of the X series I was shocked by the state X:Rebirth was released in:
The performance was terrible, the game crashed constantly, you couldn't even play through the main story because one of the first quests just bugged out and kept you stuck. The game was a frustrating mess.
My experience with Egosoft however was, that they usually continue maintaining their games over a long period of time and so I kept following the development of things as they rolled out one patch after the other.

Now, with version 3.20 I can finally say, that the game is now in a proper playable state.
They fixed most of the performance issues, the story quests work as intended, station building and fleet management works fine and the AI is starting to improve as well.
Finally they added more ship models, don't force you to walk around stations anymore to trade your inventory and upped the threat that pirates pose.

So, if you were thinking about getting this game but weren't sure if you really should because of the bad stuff you heard from frustrated early buyers, I think now is the time to pick it up without having any regrets.

I expect Egosoft to improve the game for a long time now, so there should be something new going on every once in a while that will keep me coming back to it and thus never removing it from my hard drive for ages.

reviewText:
Final Verdict: 4.12 / 10



1 - Stability / Engine

6/10

There have been a couple complaints about FPS drops and crashes.

That makes me come to the conclusion, that there are some compatiblity issues, but the majority of players seems to be able to play the game at normal framerates and crashfree.

I myself am using a Radeon HD 7970 and experienced a couple frame rate drops here and there, but until now I didn't have anything dramatic happening to me and I'm playing at pretty high settings.

There are no hardware caused bugs like graphic bugs, in this perspective it runs without any problems.

Things that do stop my gameplay and have me lose the progress since my last manual save are UI-Bugs.

I got stuck in the trading menu with the save" option turned off. The game kept running
date:
but I couldn't close the menu so I had to quit and start over with an old savegame.

Another bug is that if you dock on a big carrier with having it's docking platform outside you might experience the carrier flying through everything. It just glitches through the giant space stations as if they aren't there. You better watch your step when going back to your ship.

I do not wish to have these bugs influence the score too much because Egosoft used to fix such bugs in previous titles.



2 - Gameplay

2.1 Learning Curve:

3/10

The game is once again extremely hard to learn how to play.

I take the risk and dare to say it is far harder to understand the game than in previous titles.

While previous titles like "X3 Albion Prelude" had icons and colourful effects at every space station and ship telling you "Hey here's a quest!" or "I'm taking damage!" X Rebirth doesn't have that.

They wanted to make the gaming experience more intuitive but they did that on the cost of obviousness.

As a new player and even as an experienced player of every single previous title you have absolutely no idea what to do or how to actually do it.

This comes along with a problem with the UI: it doesn't scale with the resolution!
At a for today very normal resolution of 1920:1080 your UI becomes so tiny that it's absolutely not the player's fault if they miss something.

The tutorial uses the same lines as the subtitles.

Eventhough there is no text overlapping it is still a very bad idea
recommended:
especially because you constantly get tutorial messages for just piloting the ship during the normal gameplay.



2.2 - Human Gameplay

1/10

During the gameplay it is necessary to stand up from your seat and walk through your tiny ship or some tiny levels that resemble the interriors of a space station.

I don't even want to pick on the fact that you don't seem to have a body yourself
hoursPlayed:
what's far worse is that you run through the stations with far too high speed.

You can barely interact with your environment and the interactions that are actually there feel very clumsy and poorly designed.

It is clear that the development team or the game engine itself is not capable of implementing an organic gameplay within a space game.

Together with 3.1
voteText: 4.1 and 4.2 the human gameplay is rather a huge bother than an enjoyable side experience.\n\nThe human gameplay is a requirement to play the game properly and overall I'd say it has the level of the worst games that infect the market with their low-quality rip-off poison
helpfulPercent: I've seen super-low budget games that did a better job
votesHelpful:
I'm sorry to say.



2.3 - Ship Gameplay

5/10

I'm pretty nice here because I see the little details they added to the franchise over time.

Your ship doesn't just "turn" if you move your mouse
votesTotal: it drifts into the previous direction
votesFunny: till your accelleration overcomes the former vector.\n\nYou can see your actual speed in real time
commentsCount: there is no restriction when it comes to flying around.\n\nI do see the relative speed they added to the game
column16: so you don't get crushed by a carrier
column17:
while you're flying inside its docking area or anything.

I do see that they really did put some effort into it.

But the ship gameplay is not just the 360° controls
column18:
it's also the interaction with your environment and that's where the score dies.

To interact with a station you have to fly really close to its hovering icon.

Often you find yourself clicking and clicking and just not getting that stupid icon to highlight.

If you concentrate too much on keeping the icon in the center of your crosshair you will find yourself crashing into the station with mach1 or faster (that doesn't sound healthy).

Since they removed the targeting system you're usually left having absolutely no idea where your ships are.

At the beginning of the story mode you get a large trading ship
column19:
but I couldn't find it!

I had no idea how to get to it.

It was on my sector map
column20: but I could only get a rough idea of where it must be
column21:
I couldn't highlight it.

When I finally found it I had to go to the front of the ship to be able to access the docking menu.

Being 10m away from a big moving obstacle and moving to it with the speed of sound is a BAD COMBINATION.

Aside from that I did notice that the ships you meet in the highway are just there for the minigame.

If you leave the highway through its gate none of those ships come out
column22: and there are a lot of ships in there.\n\nPrevious titles told you when an enemy gets into or out of your weapon's reach
column23: now you have no idea when to shoot.\n\nThe distances are less detailed now
column24:
you only get kilometer displays.



2.4 - Menus and Control Panels

2/10

I wished there was anything enjoyable but not even the main menu feels good.

You have to switch to arrow keys + enter/esc to use the menu properly.

Mouse input doesn't work very well since you often don't know if the game actually took the double click or not.

There are a lot of issues with things like the trading menu.

While I already transferred the bugs to the stability rating
column25:
the menu also feels unintuitive.

I had no idea who trades with whom and in which direction the wares are going.

The few menus and control panels that are present are a bother to use!

And it's not just what's there: It's also what's not there.

I have the strong feeling that the game would have been better off with far more control panels than that.

The "intuitive gameplay" is a huge failure and without a proper control interface with a high grade of obviousity you cannot play the game properly.



3 - Graphics

3.1 - Human Character Models

1/10

During the gameplay you will soon notice the incredibly ugly character models.

Most humans you meet look so old
column26:
you'll be afraid they drop dead any second.

Aside from the age they look like their parents were very sad fishes.

http://cloud-2.steampowered.com/ugc/469793673227446070/40D404604FC504953A6296C198E7CC544F400BA5/



3.2 - Human Animations

1/10

The models are also barely animated.

No mocap studio was used for those animations
column27:
and you will definately see that.

The animations are extremely rudimentary.

It is very obvious that someone doesn't know how to rig clothing to a mesh
column28:
so you'll often see hats and glasses move differently than the bodypart they are attached to.

Also often animations don't fit together and lead to weird dislocations.



3.3 - Ship and Station Models

6/10

I'm sorry to give this such a low rating
column29: because most ships look very beautiful
column30:
especially the larger ones.

Same goes to the majority of the station models.

What's a bother though is that not all of the models look good.

Actually some of the models have an incredibly low polygon count for the fact that during the normal gameplay you have to stare at them closeup.

Aside from that many parts of the space stations are made of alpha-textures instead of 3D models.

You often get to see really ugly flat pictures instead of beautiful 3D models
column31:
and they will ♥♥♥♥ your eyes until you hate the game.



3.4 - Textures and Effects

4/10

You're often stunned by the beauty of the environment ...

But the rest of the textures real"

column35: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Ok, I was really, really mad when this game came out because I was so damn excited about it. I had high expectations, because I LOVE the X series. I own every X game that exists (and about 5 or so other space sim games).

Let me just say WOW, now that the game is working and running amazingly smoothly, 1 crash in over 20+ hours of gameplay, that may not even have been atrributed to thier game engine. The frame rate is awsome on my GTX 770 maxed everything.

THE GOOD
--------------------
GRAPHICS:
The grahics are next-gen for a space combat game, they are amazing and fun to watch every, single time.

SPACE COMBAT:space combat is fun and the AI is better than most space sim games out there. It can get repetitive after a while doing nothing
but combat for hours on end but you can just go do something else, build some stations, conquer sectors commanding your capital ships and just watching the battle
from a commanders perspective. You can start a trading empire, or become a pirate and depoy remote detonation bombs on ships... it goes on and on.

ENVIRONMENT:
As a Uninty game engine developer, I'm pretty amazing at what you have achieved with scale in this game. At first I couldnt tell if some of those large scale objects (Planets,Shatterd Moons) in the background were part of the skybox. I am very impressed with how you scaled the game and made it look so good. Though I suspect some kind of trickery at work with your Shaders! You should let me borrow some ;)

GAME PLAY:
You can board ships and take them over. nothing new here BUT, the pods come out of your ship and attract to the target like an action scene in a sci space film. So far it has been fun to watch every single time. Im addicted to capturing enemy space ships at this point just to watch the pods fly out. (they could add some drilling and molten metal types of animations and particle effects to make them appear to drill into the surface).


THE BAD:
-The sound effects can get a little old, if we can add more varition of sound effects and voice overs for the expansion, that would make this game more imersive and truly make it the greatest space sim ever made. Also, they need to write a script to limit how often a voice over is played from a single character controller, since you tend to click on them repeadedly when shopping for better crew members or ammo for your ship. You hear the same person repeating themselves 2-3-4 times... its annoying!
-`They should add the voice over limitor function to the ship as well to keep it from reapting based up what the condition was that produced the previous voice over sound effect.
-I had to look stuff up on google alot to find keys because there are SO MANY controls, there are controls for your controls! The control edit needs a form input search element to search through available controls quickly! This will be extremely usefull and save alot of time for beginners! Most people will be customizing thier controls. I am using keyboard and mouse and hated the default layout. I went from bad to pro once I changed all of the key controls and practiced for a while.
-If you run in between two colliders it will bounce your around until you clip through into the interior of a station or a ship. It has happen to me many times and had to retart because your cant clip out from the interior. You need to control the unrendered side of your verticies and add a program
to remove the physics colliders from the non-rendered side.
-Your bounce" physics on colliders needs to be toned down
date: so that clipping is less likely.\n- Also sometimes ships in your fleet clip through objects and get stuck
recommended: then I believe your fleet will bug out if that ship is within its group. Your fleet wont travel through gates if a group member is stuck. Mabey I'm wrong but
hoursPlayed:
I had a ship clipped in a station and my fleet would not travel through a jump gate within any time frame. It seems the bugs I have encountered are more or less related to kinks that need to
be worked on in your physics engine. You guys are awsome though for what you have made with such a small team.

I'm sorry that I was so mad
voteText: I did not realize the scope and the work that is needed to make a game like this until I actually became a game developer myself and learned c#. You guys should of just\ndelayed the game another year and avoided that mess and you would have made ALOT more money. Does'nt your CEO get that? Seriosly

votesFunny: it will\nbe amoung the top space sim games ever made if not the best single player space sim every made.\n"

reviewText: I've played several of the other X series games and, while difficult to learn, they turned out to be enjoyable. This one however is certainly not worth the time or money.  EGO took everything cool and fun about the previous games and threw it away. The breathing taking views of space, planetary bodies, and ships are still there, but they added trivial mini games like the space hightways, ugly NPCs and horrible interior areas that make the game tedious and not worth playing. Spend your money elsewhere.\n\nUPDATE (9-12-14): Ego has released the 2.5 BETA 7 patch as an opt in. I've noticed that the patch has improved stability, the menu system, and I can talk to vendors and other NPCs without boarding. Patch details show that its supposed to fix a bunch of other stuff too, but I haven't gotten to those yet. I've still managed to get the game to crash a few times, and you are still stuck in a single ship (we knew that at purchase), but overall, I have to give EGO credit for their efforts in improving this game.

reviewText:
--------------------------Edited June 23rd, 2014---------------------------

Happening back across Rebirth due to the Summer Sale, it seems (according to reviews), that much has been done to alleviate the issues of the original release.

I haven't played it since the release, or followed its progress at all, so perhaps another go is required.

My (Un)recommendation will remain until I get a chance to redownload/install Rebirth again, and see for myself how these months of changes have effected the game. But I'll definitely get around to it.

---------------------------Original Review Below---------------------------

Well, I should've followed the gut on this one, unfortunately it's definitely not worth the price. In hindsight, I wouldn't even pay half, or buy it at all.

I was a fan of X2 through to Albion Prelude, and heartily recommend them to those interested in that type of game...
But X Rebirth is just not anywhere near them at all.

Other reviewers have throughly covered the faults and bugs, glitches and crashes. All I've got is my personal disappointment.
voteText: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This game has some of the most amaizing visuals I've seen. Playing it you feel that there is great potential in this product.

That being said, this is not so much a game as an open beta of one. The entire game shows lack of polish and lots of bugs. This game has poorly optimized graphics, leading to constant lag. A lot of features are simply missing or have basic placeholders. There is poor ai, and very poorly designed station missions.

Finaly this game has a clunky and poorly desighned management interface: everytime you give an order you end comunication. To give a ship an order often requres multiple comunication attempts to first cancel their order, then give them a new one. Since dialogue can not be skiped this takes minutes as you hear the same scripted message over and over.

The poor desighn choices don't end there: as when the ming ship or a trade ship finishes there missions, they will imediatly go to your location regardless of what you are doing or where you are. So if you are in a major battle with a supper carrier: the poorly armed unarmored trade vessel will join in the fight and promptly get killed.

So you have to imediatley stop what you are doing, and tell them to stop their curent order and hold their position. This can take 2-5 minutes and if you are fighting, this is the plenty of time for your enemies to blow you up.

To sum up:
if you are a fan of this series, you might want to buy this game (99% likely ot already own it)
if you are not fan of the X series, DO NOT BUY THIS GAME

reviewText:
Terrible, badly designed game.

Clearly worse than the previous game in this series, and in need of a lot of development work that just does not appear to be getting done.

Avoid at all costs.

Examples:

*Interacting with stations is now done by flying around the station looking for icons that may or may not be the station service/person you're looking for. Stations can have multiple different docking locations, shops inside and outside docking locations, multiple levels inside docking locations, and NPCs are not easily findable. You often have to ask other NPCs to help you find the NPC you're looking for, and they will usually tell you to sod off (really, they do).

*Waypoint navigation is confusing at best, game suffers from the same limited-time missions as before, but now it's twice as hard to figure out where to go. I spent 4 of the first taxi mission's 5 minutes circling the area I was being told there was a docking location at. After the mission expired, I may have found one near, but in a ship not actually attached to, the station highlighted by the waypoint.

*Voice acting is bad, whole game is now voiced, you must speak to NPCs on a regular basis. One is on your ship.

*Needless walking from place to place with an half-♥♥♥♥♥ feeling first person mode.

*Pointless item hunting, suddenly space stations leaving loot in boxes everwhere, which you steal. Some hidden in airducts...because that makes sense. Entirely out of genre trope, and the trope doesn't really make sense in the correct games.

*Main questline still buggy - decided to quit after being told to sell energy cubes to a station, sold more cubes than the quest expected and it ignored it and expected me to go back and get more cubes so I could sell *exactly* 100 cubes to the target station...

reviewText: Too many bugs. The idea of the game seems fun and I'm really trying, but I have to fight the interface (worse than prior X games) every time I want to do a task. Missions are fairly broken as well, you will need to do save game editing to fix/get past some of them. In fact, I'm stuck on selling 300 Food to some station in Fervid something as they won't seem to accept any of the 5,000 Food I've picked up in my Construction Vessel nor a Lepton that has precisely 300 Food on it. Neither of those ships will complete the trade with the mission station. I've heard that I have to buy the 300 Food from a specific station, but the mission never mentions it and the mission briefs" are just that

reviewText:
This game is broken in almost every possible respect.

First of all, the game is shock-full of bugs, glitches, and design flaws that make playing a real chore.

Secondly, despite using Mass Effect style conversations for almost every aspect of the game, the voiceacting is terrible, the character models ugly beyond belief, and most 6-year-olds could write better dialogue.

When you are allowed to fly in space, the game looks pretty good as long as you don't get close to anything. Some scenes are actually quite beautiful. On the other hand, the fps will drop through the floor for no apparent reason.

If you can get past these flaws, you will soon realize that unlike other space sims" this game simulates nothing! There is no real economy
date: not a single ship is persistant or remotely connected to the world
hoursPlayed: nothing you do will ever be reflected in the world around you."

reviewText:
After 19 patches, I'm still unable to proceed with the campaign as there is still a 100% blocker (many users still have this one).
The frame rate is still aweful that it's not even playable (5-10 fps as an average) and I have a very good rig, I can run ARMA 3 at high with consistent 40 fps (60 at medium with textures at very high).

This is by far the worse game I've ever bought and I'm very upset to have pre-order for this. It shouldn't even have release with the current state of the game. And Steam nor Egosoft want to refund. That's a well wasted 50$.

reviewText: Even without all the bugs and performance problems, what we have is a very bad game that is poorly designed. It will take you hours upon hours of maneuvering through convoluted gameplay mechanics and glitches just to find out how shallow the game really is.\n\nIt has taken them 7" years to shovel this garbage out the door. A space sim(?) in which joystick/HOTAS support are held together with scotch tape
recommended: it feels like moving around in spectator mode from Counter-Strike 1.5)
hoursPlayed: no freelook (much less TrackIR)
voteText: no radar
helpfulPercent: no target filtering
votesHelpful: etc. In short - it is a big mess.\n\nSome might say it was a failed console game
votesTotal: and by Egosofts own admission they had it working on the Xbox 360 and would love nothing more than to have had X Rebirth as a console game. Instead
votesFunny: they vomited this out on to the PC. I suspect even Microsoft didn't want anything to do with it's poor quality and turned them down.\n\nI wouldn't bother waiting for it to get fixed
commentsCount:
either. X Rebirth feels like a "last hurrah" to cash out of the business before Star Citizen and Elite Dangerous carry the space sim genre for the next decade. And we will all be better off for it.

TRADE: Broken and cumbersome. Lacks information that should be easily accessible. Fly around convoluted space stations and pick up trade offers that only last an hour. Waterboard yourself as you wait 30 minutes for your transport ship to fly to the station and break while trying to complete an order.

FIGHT: Incredibly shallow. Fixed view to make you nauseous and you're unable to look around. Cockpit takes up 40% of the screen. No radar or target filtering of any kind. Not even going to go into the AI.

BUILD: Broken with an incredible lack of information letting you know wtf is going on or what you're doing wrong/how to do it in the first place. What can you build? AN EMPIRE!? Yeah

column30: that's only if you didn't tell one of the first ships to dock at the Ship Trader (you can only modify/sell ships to specific traders that know/want that type of ship) and repair itself
column31: only to find out that the ship cannot move to the repair dock because the engines are destroyed and the engineer won't repair it. Now that Ship Trader is "stuck" on that order and will refuse to do any business with you
column32: including selling any of your other ships. The only way to fix this is
column34: to edit your save game and remove the repair order or just delete the offending ship. Also
column35: you need Pilots to capture small ships (e.g. Fighters) and Captains to command the larger capital ships
column36: plus an engineer to (maybe) repair the capital ship
column37: but you may only carry a few (seven I think?) crew on your ship. You need a Marine Officer to even do the boarding
column38: so that's one down already
column39: so don't even bother with Pilots and trying to capture smaller ships. Best bet is to capture the ship
column40: destroy anything Yisha asks you to in order to help the boarding process
column41: and then immediately sell the ship. Don't try to fix anything. If you want a ship
column42: go buy one from a Ship Trader.\n\nSeven years in the making? I seriously doubt that
column43: or they spent all their time using developer hacks to do the fun events during QA and never played it like we mere customers would have to."

reviewText:
The only positive thing that can be said for X Rebirth is that graphically, it’s a beautiful game…
When in space.

Other than that, this game has no redeeming qualities.
Game mechanics that make no sense.
Some of the worst voice acting I've heard in a long time.
Very limited voice dialogue as it is.
For a futuristic game that features faster than light space travel, your computers are pretty useless.
Ai path finding is a joke.
Some bugs require you to hack your save file to fix.

Overall, this game feels like an early alpha release… with a very long way to.
Unfortunately, I suspect we will get a few more months of patches to fix bugs and then Egosoft will drop support for this game.

If I ever buy an EgoSoft game again, it will be after it has been released and reviewed as a good game.
Never again will I pre-order from them.

Rock bottom. I made a poor choice buying this pre-release.

reviewText: I've played several of the other X series games and, while difficult to learn, they turned out to be enjoyable. This one however is certainly not worth the time or money.  EGO took everything cool and fun about the previous games and threw it away. The breathing taking views of space, planetary bodies, and ships are still there, but they added trivial mini games like the space hightways, ugly NPCs and horrible interior areas that make the game tedious and not worth playing. Spend your money elsewhere.\n\nUPDATE (9-12-14): Ego has released the 2.5 BETA 7 patch as an opt in. I've noticed that the patch has improved stability, the menu system, and I can talk to vendors and other NPCs without boarding. Patch details show that its supposed to fix a bunch of other stuff too, but I haven't gotten to those yet. I've still managed to get the game to crash a few times, and you are still stuck in a single ship (we knew that at purchase), but overall, I have to give EGO credit for their efforts in improving this game.

reviewText:
--------------------------Edited June 23rd, 2014---------------------------

Happening back across Rebirth due to the Summer Sale, it seems (according to reviews), that much has been done to alleviate the issues of the original release.

I haven't played it since the release, or followed its progress at all, so perhaps another go is required.

My (Un)recommendation will remain until I get a chance to redownload/install Rebirth again, and see for myself how these months of changes have effected the game. But I'll definitely get around to it.

---------------------------Original Review Below---------------------------

Well, I should've followed the gut on this one, unfortunately it's definitely not worth the price. In hindsight, I wouldn't even pay half, or buy it at all.

I was a fan of X2 through to Albion Prelude, and heartily recommend them to those interested in that type of game...
But X Rebirth is just not anywhere near them at all.

Other reviewers have throughly covered the faults and bugs, glitches and crashes. All I've got is my personal disappointment.
voteText: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This game has some of the most amaizing visuals I've seen. Playing it you feel that there is great potential in this product.

That being said, this is not so much a game as an open beta of one. The entire game shows lack of polish and lots of bugs. This game has poorly optimized graphics, leading to constant lag. A lot of features are simply missing or have basic placeholders. There is poor ai, and very poorly designed station missions.

Finaly this game has a clunky and poorly desighned management interface: everytime you give an order you end comunication. To give a ship an order often requres multiple comunication attempts to first cancel their order, then give them a new one. Since dialogue can not be skiped this takes minutes as you hear the same scripted message over and over.

The poor desighn choices don't end there: as when the ming ship or a trade ship finishes there missions, they will imediatly go to your location regardless of what you are doing or where you are. So if you are in a major battle with a supper carrier: the poorly armed unarmored trade vessel will join in the fight and promptly get killed.

So you have to imediatley stop what you are doing, and tell them to stop their curent order and hold their position. This can take 2-5 minutes and if you are fighting, this is the plenty of time for your enemies to blow you up.

To sum up:
if you are a fan of this series, you might want to buy this game (99% likely ot already own it)
if you are not fan of the X series, DO NOT BUY THIS GAME

reviewText:
This is not X3 - and while the bugs may eventually get fixed, it will never be X3. The best way to describe the gameplay is this is an RTS that you control from a ship that you can fly around. While there are a few mini games you can play while flying, for the most part you order ships around.

Do not plan to do your own trading with the one ship you have, it does not do that. I found the game hardly bearable but when I found that I could not do my own trading, well that is where I gave up on this game. I want a space sim with a ship I can fly and with it trade, mine, explore, build and fight. This game did not provide that.

Hope this helps your decision.

reviewText: I really tried to like X:Rebirth. It has a beautiful engine, flying through space has never looked this good, even the ship's cockpit, which some call intrusive looks beautiful with the graphics turned up. Egosoft had an excellent game in X:3 but changed the formula somewhat, rather than being able to fly any ship in the galaxy, the player is stuck with one, controling the rest of the fleet through a series of awkward menus.\n\nX:3 had an excellent modding community and patches and expansions were released regularily, for many years after the game's release. One can hope that mods and patches will change X:Rebirth for the better in a few months. Until then, I wouldn't recommend the game

reviewText: This game comes from a franchize that chose to break down the barriers between space sims and RPG's with ground breaking dreams of everything from a stock market to station owning/building to fleet designing and controlles and the ability to fly very nearly ALL ship types in the game (or capture/steel the ones you could not buy).  Yes there were issues and hurdles that had to be over come here and there in previos versions and some that never got resolved; I had hoped that this would be the truth here too as a new direction in this groud breaking thought line.  I have been playing the last 4 itterations of the Xuniverse franchise (I got hooked with the original X2 big time).  I was hoping that maybe all the hype was just due to this being a complete revamp of the entire design, alas this is not completely right, yes it is a revamp but with the redesign I find it more fun to play any space game but this one including DarkStar One, which advertised the same but was a bit of a fun yet still a flop of a game.  I would argue that nearly 90% of the intelligence and aspects of what made the previous game difficult to develop and create were removed or cheated out (Ships would commonly fly THROUGH stations so they do not have to die by the station simply becasue they can not fly around it).  If you wish a list of items that no longer exist then please ping me any time I will give you far greater detail as the game is no longer A Living Economy" but now a totally fake and DEAD one
date: and I primise not to just wine because they changed the paint job
recommended: this game really does make me very sad that I spent the money to buy it.  I would have been better off spending that money on ANY other game including variants I do not like playing on PC

reviewText:
Never have I been so let down with a purchase.  I rank the previous X3 game one of my all time favorites. I played X3 modded outside of Steam so Steam doesn't show how many hours I put into it before this game.

This is a sad example of the future of game development:  release horribly designed games with lots of bugs and when consumers complain, tell the consumers to confirm they have the most recent patch, a patch which doesn't fix anything and makes the game worse.

There is still hope for this game because modders will fix it, but that is yet another reason why gaming quality is in jeopardy:  developers with a strong modding community know they can fall back on free labor" to make their game work.

Currently I don't recommend this unless you want to punish yourself."

If you enjoyed all the previous X3 games, then you are not going to enjoy this game at all.  X3 was about trading and empire building all of which are crap in X Rebirth.  X3 is still the best trading / empire building game so if that is the reason you are contemplating this game, then avoid at all costs.

Maybe if you are new to the series and dont know what has previously been offered, maybe their is a market for this game, but i was extremely dissapointed.

Why did they change something that wasn't broken?  All we wanted was an updated X3 but all we got was some terrible new style that simply doesnt work.

Do not buy

reviewText:
With another four to six months this game could have been excellent, but just like the release of X3 it was beyond broken on launch. After large amounts of patching, it is perfectly possible or even likely given the company's excellent track record with supporting their titles and listening to the community for future updates, that it will be fixed, balanced and fun, but as it stands it is not worth the price tag.

Do not buy this game in it's current state, you will regret it. Wait for it to be truly working before thinking about dropping £40 on it. It is not just buggy and not properly optimised, but also badly thought out in terms of gameplay and interface, hopefully in future the community help to correct this.

So wait for it and see, maybe this or one of it's many new competitors will give you the space sim fix you want :)

reviewText:
In this review I shall not criticize as too many have already wasted all of their energy at that. Instead I shall list suggestions which would make this game's experience fantastic because the original concept is indeed fantastic, but unfortunately not exploited. All I mention here is based on enough hours of playing and completing the whole campaign (thanks to the 1.24 patch).

Remember that Egosoft have already invested a lot of time, money and resources for the existing content, so do not expect much improvement on this project. They might decide to release DLCs but these are not solutions to existing problems, they are extensions of existing problems.

Here it goes:

__________________________________________
Hardware

-Make the game running smooth on the average modern PC

Controls

-Enable look around using numpad as in X3
-Split roll function in two button: roll right, roll left and assignable on gamepad as in X3

X Universe

-Add Boron and Paranid factions (it's unfair if they come in payable DLC)
-Add Pirate stations. If not directly visible give hints, indications that they might be somewhere near some zones and we'd explore for them
-Make trade/missions possible with Pirates

Graphics

-Make MPC characters look and act more realistic
-Stations/ships/objects should not be visible while outside nebula cloud
-Nebula cloud should be visible from any distance while in the sector, not just from its zone.
-Prevent ships going through one another or through stations as if hollow

Optional but doable cool and practical graphical suggestions

-Make it possible to dock in stations manually with animation of opening hangar and docking procedure (if enabled by player   in settings)
-Make it possible to travel in a station from one dock/area to another using a local train or something cool
-Make planetary descent possible (limited areas only if too complicated) for trade and exploration, alone or with party (yes it's possible, Evochron series have this fantastic feature with realistic atmospheric characteristics)

UI and cockpit

-Remove radial menu and replace with command/property menu as in X3
-Add radar display
-On info display, while targeting ships, add distance and velocity

In albion Skunk

-Disable/modify Ysha speech “Requesting permission to dock” when docking at own ship/station or Xenon stations
-Enable free walking around the cockpit when not seated
-Enable Click on pilot chair to be seated while free walking around instead of the control switch in the corridor
-Enable interaction functions with other tools/computers in cockpit for small routine maintenance/monitoring (engineer cannot do everything)
-Enable more speech with co-pilot and crew to kill the silence and stillness

Navigation & map

-Enable jump drive for Skunk: gate to gate and point to point (unfocused optional but cool)
-Enable zoom in/out in map, not just press sector/zone...
-Add written details on map for stations, ships and objects, not just clickable list o right side
-Enable filter map content for display
-Let us select our own speed in highways instead of following other crafts
-Have boost consume its own energy storage, not from shield or enable upgrade like energy splitter or something
-When docked in carrier/capital ship fix the “plot course” function, or provide clear instructions
-Add many more systems including our solar system

Stations

-Give traders appropriate stores/workshops, so that trade doesn't take place in a bunk or bar
-Give NPC more dialog variety and more casual
-Modify Ren Otani speech: “Show me your wares please”, to something more realistic, casual and add variety, not always the same sentence (appropriate the the service in question)
-Make NPC give small missions (e.g. “provide 20 units of teladianium paneling”, “ship this package at this station to this guy”...) which would affect on discounts and rep on faction.

Trade

-Enable more than 3 planned trading trips per ship
-When more than one trade trip is planned for the same station keep the ship docked till all transactions are finished
-Add button in trade menu to view/edit/delete planned trade trips in detail
-Add best buy/sell software upgrade (e.g. MK1 limited to sector, MK2 limited to system, MK3 for whole map)
-Add many more upgrades for the Skunk

Shipyards

-Enable command ship (all but Skunk) to go to selected shipyard for repair/upgrade without having to go there yourself first (with command menu X3 style this would be possible)
-Enable purchase of fighters (if there are I must be blind) to use them as wings

Combat

-Enable “Lock on Target”: when selecting a target it should be possible to press lock on target to stay locked on that target till it is destroyed or out of scanner range or you manually select another target. It should also be configurable in settings
-Don't make enemy fighters stick so close to station like flies on a light bulb

__________________________________________

Some details might have slipped my mind, however, feel free to add or modify this list. I believe we should put as much pressure as possible on Egosoft on this cause it's really a waste. They really can make a master piece if they want as they've already done an amaising job with the X3 series, they just needed to improve on those.

reviewText:
Never have I been so let down with a purchase.  I rank the previous X3 game one of my all time favorites. I played X3 modded outside of Steam so Steam doesn't show how many hours I put into it before this game.

This is a sad example of the future of game development:  release horribly designed games with lots of bugs and when consumers complain, tell the consumers to confirm they have the most recent patch, a patch which doesn't fix anything and makes the game worse.

There is still hope for this game because modders will fix it, but that is yet another reason why gaming quality is in jeopardy:  developers with a strong modding community know they can fall back on free labor" to make their game work.

Currently I don't recommend this unless you want to punish yourself."

reviewText: Now I realize my review will be just another grain of sand on the beach of Normandy that was the disaster called X Rebirth and that my voice will most likely be drowned out by the shouts and cries of those others who purchased the title alongside me. Close to countless reviews found on just about any gaming website can elucidate the extent of the problems this game presented. I just wanted to highlight some that mattered most to me.\nGiven that it's near impossible to get a game released these days without a slew of bugs and glitches, I don't want to spend too much time focusing on those errors. That said, it is worth asking how on earth a company as established as Egosoft could have possibly thought XR was worthy of release. A few glitches here, maybe a bug or two in that feature there, sure but what they gave us was just an utter shock. And you have to imagine that at some point, they sat down during some meeting just before launch and said well this is ready to hit the mainstream. We have a good product

reviewText: This game comes from a franchize that chose to break down the barriers between space sims and RPG's with ground breaking dreams of everything from a stock market to station owning/building to fleet designing and controlles and the ability to fly very nearly ALL ship types in the game (or capture/steel the ones you could not buy).  Yes there were issues and hurdles that had to be over come here and there in previos versions and some that never got resolved; I had hoped that this would be the truth here too as a new direction in this groud breaking thought line.  I have been playing the last 4 itterations of the Xuniverse franchise (I got hooked with the original X2 big time).  I was hoping that maybe all the hype was just due to this being a complete revamp of the entire design, alas this is not completely right, yes it is a revamp but with the redesign I find it more fun to play any space game but this one including DarkStar One, which advertised the same but was a bit of a fun yet still a flop of a game.  I would argue that nearly 90% of the intelligence and aspects of what made the previous game difficult to develop and create were removed or cheated out (Ships would commonly fly THROUGH stations so they do not have to die by the station simply becasue they can not fly around it).  If you wish a list of items that no longer exist then please ping me any time I will give you far greater detail as the game is no longer A Living Economy" but now a totally fake and DEAD one

reviewText: Well gotta admit I'm a major sucker for games that let you fly around in space and actually support the use of a joystick! Sadly thats the only good thing about this game even after so many so-called patches and a revamp with extra missions. The controls are buggy as hell. Docking is buggy as hell (Some stations I even gave up on trying - it's like a mini-game unto itself in the style of an old hidden object game)\nGripping storyline? I've seen more grip on a lubed up stripper pole. And just like that last sentence, paying even half-price for this game leaves you feeling dirty and guilty.\nAs a $5 bargain-bin non-steam game? Maybe. But as it is AVOID.

reviewText: This game just wasn't ready to be published.  After 21 patches and a month and a half after release, the game is still riddled with bugs.  I'm going to wait about 5 more months to try again as the developers are going to need that time to fix the uncountable issues with the game.  I still can't make it through the campaign without the game asking me to transport someone to some non-existent space station.  The only way people seem to make it through is by modifying the massive save files.  This game is worse than a lot of greenlight games are.  As a programmer I understand building a dynamic universe like this is extremely complex.  There are a lot of complaints about unfinished games being released to early from Battlefield 4 to Diablo 3.  Those games had some understandable problems on release.  This game however, is not even close to playable and can't even be compared to the problems other games have had on release.  I don't blame the developers, I blame the publishers for releasing a game that quite simply is not ready to be played.  I really wanted to like this game and tried really hard to looks past the glaring problems.  I really hope they succeed in fixing the issues and get the game to a playable state.

reviewText: I wanted to like this game so badly and so I tried to push passed the flaws. There are so many bugs with the trade ships that I just could not do it after a while. Often times, ships would just stop out side a port where they had gone to buy cargo and never move again. Some times credits set a side for a trade would vanish and the trade never happen. The space combat is fun and can be really neat when you factor in drones and other ships into the picture but some times, for no reasone I could find, my FPS would drop to 2 untill I restarted the game and after reloading my save the same events would pass and every thing would be just fine. All this I could forgive if there had been Alpha warnings before hand but I could not  find anything like that. Then when I think of how much I spent on this game I cringe

reviewText:
Worst piece of crap ever released

******Update******

It's been a year since this scamdle was released and Egosoft has put some work into bug fixing. After a good retest of the game it has gone from utter ♥♥♥♥♥ to bland and average.

Trading is time intensive but uninteresting. Station building is kinda pointless, they take about a week of ingame time to break even. After getting 20 odd stations up, with haulers/fighty ships assigned to each one the game crapped out and my save file became worthless (200 hour save with no backup) grr

Fighting is easy even on hard, laughably so. There are no fleet commands that are worth it or that reliably work.

I liked the plot, despite the terrible voice acting. Hitting defries for the first time is breathtaking. I almost wish they had stuck to a rollercoaster game with a long plot and made the engine do that well :|

Don't buy this game it's terrible

reviewText:
I loved X2. Played for many hundreds of hours. X3... well a low ball estimate across the various games would be 1000 hours. This? Gave up on it after 2 evenings.

Its NOT an X game. Its NOT what we've all come to expect from Egosoft who are famed for being one of those developers who keep on giving to their players. One ship concept is ok... but in previous games you aimed to get bigger and better ships, then fleets, moving around them at will. You're bored in this one after an hour. Lack of SETA makes waiting for your capital ships... well boring. The map is utterly useless, I struggle to find out what the hell is going on half the time, the same 4 NPCs copy/pasted with different uniforms look awful, the same animations as you do the same tasks... gah... it would be mediocre for an Xbox game. Utterly worthless as a PC game.

Rename this one 'Death of a Spacesim' and start work on a proper X4. Pretend this one never existed.
voteText: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Do NOT buy this game.

Still seeking refund. I've spent more time trying to fix this game and tweak it to just get it running than actually trying to play it.

Extremely let down. Pre-ordered a lemon. Looking back on the other X series games I have played, this game will definitely not get fixed up to spec anytime soon. There are still bugs with their other games that the community had to create fixes for (through modding). This game is beyond and kind of patch.

Despite how ugly and badly designed the game is, if you can even get it to run, or continue running without crashing every other couple of minutes, my hats off to you.

Do not purchase this game. Even if it goes on some holiday sale for 75% off, it will end up eating most of your time trying to work around things. The trading system and other elements in the game that are main features are bugged or not working properly. It was unplayable. On a high end rig, this game runs like doo-doo. After one of the most recent patches, it actually dropped my fps in stations and made things even more unresponsive. Gave me a headache. Alt-f4.

Horrible.

Don't believe me?

==>>                                                   http://www.metacritic.com/game/pc/x-rebirth

I'm a big fan of the previous games, especially the X3:TC and X3:AP titles. I've played the hell out of them and they were awesome. I have games in the series in and out of steam.

This game is unplayable, buggy, dumbed down, poorly designed UI, bad AI (still), poor optimization for PC, way too expensive for what it is, unresponsive, extremely poor fps on a wide range of PC's to the point of making it unplayable, and has made the steam forum so congested with bad reviews/complaints that you cannot even find workarounds for bugs that the community  might have solved on their own. There are so many problems with the game that they can't be listed. Heck, the devs have a pinned topic on their forum with a list of current bugs and other things that are game breakers which span over two pages long.



Bottom line:

================Do not buy this game.================

reviewText: Never has a game been so beautiful, so deep, so luxurious in detail, and yet so boring.\n\nSometimes people hold up Elder Scrolls II: Daggerfall as an example of an amazing game with so much scope. It has the biggest game map EVER. The entire continent is created, thousands of cities and villages, 750,000 npcs. Yet for all of this, it feels completely empty. Why? Because there is no soul there. Everything is fairly barebones, most of it is cut and pasted from one point to another. You enter a red building at one end of the world and find a +1 dagger, then go across the continent to another city in another entire other race's kingdom, go into a red building and find the same dagger. This is a bit of an over-simplification, but X-Rebirth suffers from this same downfall. It's beautiful, has a lot of options, and yet feels entirely sterile and without a soul. It doesn't help the game has a kinda meh combat system either.

reviewText:
X Rebirth taught me a valuable lesson; to be wary of Pre-Orders.

I can’t call myself a long-term fan of the series, sense I was only introduced to X3 recently, but I heard about X Rebirth and I got excited. As the screenshots came flooding in and the press was so positive (at least from what I heard) I got even more excited. So I pre-ordered it. When the time came to finally play it, I was greeted with awful optimization, terrible voice acting, low-res graphics and a game breaking bug in the first level that persisted even upon reloading, restarting and rebooting.

Unless Egosoft makes some major changes to the title, I cannot recommend this game.

reviewText:
Very disappointed!

Avoid this train wreck. I had high hopes for this game having played X-3 Terran Conflict for close to 1000 hours. The fact you can only fly one ship killed any chance this game had of being fun for me. Half the fun of X3-Terran Conflict for me was owning a fleet you could fly. The the space stations are copy-pasted, the hud and asset controls are nothing like you would expect from X series. There is no external view or option to disable the cockpit that I could find. The storyline is hard to follow and very buggy. The game feels highly dumbed down from what you have come to love and expect from an X game. This game would require a massive patch that I doubt will ever come.

Clearly EGOSOFT was attempting to rework the classic X games into something new and evolved but lost their way from what made the X series awesome. The game feels like they ran out of time / money and shoved this (what feels like Alpha at best) title out the door with misleading and false advertisement.

I want my money back.
voteText: 7 of 11 people (64%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
So much potential, sadly wasted.

X Rebirth attempst to bring the X series universe to a wider audience but it fails on so many levels.

Aside from suffering numerous bugs, and generally having poor performance and low framerates, some of the basic design principles are flawed. The visuals are not particularly impressive (despite the deceptive screenshots and footage), the user interface (UI) is unintuitive and clunky, and the controls are less-than-ideal (not to mention requiring the player to memorize a lot of keys).

Some bugs will certainly be ironed out with patches but the inherent design flaws probably won't.

I hope EGOSOFT will do something about it (what else have they got going on? They only make X games!). It would be a shame to leave this game in this state.
voteText: 7 of 11 people (64%) found this review helpful

reviewText: I Have enough time in this game to honestly say It's still broken". There are a ton of great mods out there designed to correct some of the shortcomings and for that I am very grateful. It seems that from at least X3 to X rebirth the game has been left to modders to fix. I have a highend computer and still run into graphics issues in populated systems. The Trading is still very much in need of simplification and player control. Combat isn't to bad as long as you can do it in the middle of nowhere as to not lag out and die. The ability to build is nice but at the leisure of A.I. which is in no hurry at all. Ships still just sit with resources just out of reach and it takes days to build (left Comp on and active to try this ) anything worth having and still isnt completed after bringing them supplies myself. The content is shallow and unguided. Some of the needed missions for vanilla are still broken even after all this time. I don't know if theres still plans for future releases and fixes from egosoft or not but I'd recommend to not purchase until something comes down the pipe from either the devs or the modders about an aboslute game fix. And P.S. I also loved X3
hoursPlayed: and albion prelude. I gave this game a ton of chances before writing this review."

reviewText:
I'm an X vet. X Rebirth is NOT X3, just leave that thought else where. X Rebirth is a new direction on the X Universe.
There are many differences good and bad and some concepts are implemented a bit more simpler and some are far more complex.

You take the role of a single ship captain and view the universe from one perspective.

I think the latest version is extremely enjoyable, 3.53, far more so with use of Mods. If you loved the role of playing statistical manager from the safety of a itemized data screen then this game is not for you. The ability to directly control mass ships via a remote display map screen in X3 is not as easily, or not at all the same in Rebirth. Think of it as traveling through the universe in a single ship with emphasis on what is in front of you.

As a FPSS (first person shooter ship) this game is a whole hell of a lot of fun. It is easy to organize fighter squads under your wing and with a click order them to attack a target. This aspect of the game is wonderful.
Drones, missiles, and underlings are your path to survival.

Again look at it from a single point character as you fly the Albion Pride influencing the universe as you go. You can personalize the cockpit, or mod your own!, to make your ship more to your own liking.

For Trading I think it is far more satisfying than previous games. No, you can't personally captain the largest freighter in the universe. What you can do is have freighters in your squad and as you fly through the universe quickly assign them trade jobs. This is even made easier with trade software and you can do this all from a menu screen. Give a single freighter 4 or 5 trade jobs and go do something else, or dock on that trade ship and watch the action from the bridge.

You are not the captain, you are the Admiral, and Admirals don't drive, they command.

The campaign I find enjoyable. Much more simplistic than many missions in X3 but it serves as an excellent Tutorial which was greatly missed in prior X games. If you find yourself starting to see the short failings of certain aspects of the game CONGRATULATIONS you've made it further in this game than most do in the previous X3 games :P

With that said, no, Rebirth does not have the same Universe longevity as say X3 TC. You will hit that end game moment a bit sooner and find less to do, at least at the moment. Then again the X series has always been about what you make of it, so try something new, or mod.

In ending, yes I can now recommend X Rebirth as the game is excellent and becoming better and better each official release with amazing mods to make the universe remarkable. Has it overcome X3 TC/AP ? not quite, but it's damn close.

reviewText:
Edit: Much improved

Since release X Rebirth has come quite a long way. It was absolutely horrid at release, but I must say I can now complete the storyline, play sandbox with any start and have not had a single crash. Framerates seem to be a ton better where I hardly drop under 40+fps at the worst of times.

Egosoft have done a good job in continuing the support of X-Rebirth and have improved it ten fold. With another Xpack/Update 4.0 due soon, Now is a good time to grab X-Rebirth and give it a good run if this genre interests you. Dismiss the old reviews, they do in no way give X-Rebirth justice as it stands today.

reviewText: Good music and beautiful space vistas are the strongest aspects of X Rebirth. Unfortunately, that's where the good" ends and the "bad" begins.\n\nDespite all of the bugs and glitches (which have mostly been addressed in the 2.0 update)
date: there are fundamental flaws in the basic game design. The X series has been well known for its deep economy and combat systems. X Rebirth took most of that away. The X series has been touted for providing a large universe to explore and secrets to discover. X Rebirth took most of that away. The X series has been a staple in the space simulation genre for its meticulous attention to detail and giving the player immense amounts of freedom. X Rebirth took most of that away.\n\nAs you can see
recommended: X Rebirth is a mostly step backwards rather than a revisitation--or "rebirth"--of the series. I purchased the game on release day and have been regretting it ever since.\n\nThe biggest flaw that stood out near the time of release is the fact that you are limited to a single ship; to make matters worse they called it the "Albion Skunk"
hoursPlayed: a ship that was once known for its prowess (and went by a different name) but was later found in ruins and scrapped. Having only one pilotable ship should have been the first sign to me that this game would never live up to expectations. Because of this limitation
voteText: major mechanics that are considered "norms" for the genre
helpfulPercent: like trading
votesHelpful: are handled by pilots you hire who can fly other ships. This limits you to focusing almost completely on combat. There are a handful of missions you can run
votesTotal: but they mostly consist of bounty hunting.\n\nOne of the key aspects that was announced before the game released was the ability to step out of the cockpit and walk around stations. The concept was fantastic and it has rarely been done in the space sim genre. Sadly
votesFunny: X Rebirth failed to make that as exciting and innovative as it was made to seem. There are basically two types of interiors that you'll see. Every station uses one of those two layouts and tried to make them unique by blocking off certain sections for each station. It's fun and interesting to walk through the stations the first few times
commentsCount: but it quickly becomes frustrating when you have to go through a maze of corridors to get to your destination to talk to a vendor or mission contact. Additionally
column16: the stations are almost completely devoid of life. There are maybe 20 people in any given station
column17: and all of them stay in the exact same spot and do absolutely nothing. Which leads me to my next point...\n\nCharacter design is terrible! Other than the few key characters in the tutorial campaign (such as Yisha
column18: your copilot)
column19: every other person you see is just a copy. There are maybe four unique character designs: human male
column20: human female
column21: and roughly two alien humanoid species. They are then copied and pasted throughout the stations.\n\nThere are many other examples of poor design and rushed development that I could continue to list (such as terrible UI
column22: bad voice acting
column23: etc.)
column24: but I think my message is fairly clear already. X Rebirth essentially attempted to make the X series more streamlined and accessible
column25: but it seems like their answer for that was to make the game more casual-friendly by ditching fundamental space-sim mechanics and to change the focus on the series and genre completely (You don't even have 6 degrees of freedom! Everything has an UPWARD orientation which makes absolutely ZERO sense in space!).\n\nHowever
column26: X Rebirth doesn't fail completely. There are a few things that stand out and are worth mentioning. As I stated earlier
column27: the music is good and the space backdrops are gorgeous. Additionally
column28: activity outside of the stations actually makes the areas feel populated. Each stations will have hundreds of ships flying around
column29: traffic heading in and out of docking bays
column30: police ships scanning and chasing criminals
column31: military cruisers fending off attackers... There is no lack of visual fidelity when it comes to the station exteriors.\n\nUnfortunately
column32: the few things that X Rebirth does right are too few. With the space sim genre coming back to fruition with games like Elite: Dangerous and Star Citizen in development
column34: very difficult to recommend or praise X Rebirth."

reviewText:
To be honest I really wanted to like this game. I even got it against my better judgement to the thoughts of 'maybe it's not as bad as they say it is.' 'maybe they just aren't adjusting to the new way the game plays' and 'maybe it has improved over time to the point where it is as enjoyable as previous games in the series'. I am very sorry to report that this is just not the case.

In some ways, I would have prefered it if they simply copied and pasted the X-3 universe, tweaked it a bit by adding a few new systems and adding better economy and then just selling THAT as a new game. At least I'd of probably enjoyed that.

That's not totally fair though, they DID make an effort, they just got it terribly wrong. In absolute fairness, I found that the storyline by itself had improved from previous X-games. and even though the one ship deal did put me off playing for a while, I got used to that. But every other aspect about it from the way it looks to the way it moves and that way it performs just... irritates me to no end... especially when I know these people can produce games such as X-3 and X-2. Let that serve as a warning to anyone looking to buy. They have lost a lot of fan support because of this... including mine. Sure they all had their own faults too but simply put... I liked those games, I can play X2 and X3 for days, weeks, even months at a time, I can barely just about manage to force myself to put up with X-rebirth for maybe a few hours.

reviewText:
When X Rebirth was released, it was broken. Now it is playable and i was told from many people, who have never played a X Game before, that they realy enjoy X Rebirth for its depth and gameplay. I do not enjoy it, because X3 TC was my favorite game back then and it is just to different from the original X Games.

Pro:
+The visuals and audio is fantastic
+The story and lore of the universe is fantastic
+capital gameplay has been improved
+i like the new trading system
+empire building is still fun
+the stations seem much more alive and look fantastic
+very good support from Egosoft (even 2 years after release)
+very nice capital ship design
+mining is now a thing!

Con:
-the UI seems like a bad console port!!!! (WTF Egosoft?!)
-only one playership
-ugly character design
-walking on stations just sucks
-sub capital ships have almost lost all their purposes
-no ship classes ( i realy liked the ship classes of the old games, they were one of the best things in x3)
-to easy



I have to give credit where it is due and the dedicaton and support of Egosoft for the game is amazing, but i expected that from them. X3 Reunion was not half as enjoyable as X3 TC and i have faith that the sequel from XR will bring in features, that veterans would have expected from XR in the beginning.
Egosoft has a history of crappy first releases, but they always manage to build up from it and create a wonderfull experience.

I think that my 50 Euros were well spend, because they supported Egosoft and i am sure that X Rebirth 2 (or what ever they call it) will bring back the Veterans and supporters of the first hour.

reviewText:
The game is, for the moment, completely unplayable.

Even if we ignore some of the controversial changes when comparing X Rebirth to other games in the series (such as the inability of ever piloting another ship), in its current state the game cannot be considered anywhere near complete. We will even ignore design decisions such as police ships with sirens in outer space.

Issues with this game range from low performance, buggy animations, buggy AI, terrible voice acting (I cannot stress this enough, it is by far the worst voice acting I have heard in recent years), game breaking bugs that make finishing the campaign impossible, crashes and corrupt saved games.

The latest patch even introduced a new bug that completely disrupts trading in the game (and thus almost all production as well). Hopefully this issue will be patched soon enough. If you are considering purchasing this game anytime soon, I'd recommend disabling automatic updates and only allowing the game to patch after you've checked the forums for any major new issues.

While Egosoft does have a good reputation for supporting their games for a long time and adding new content over time, that cannot excuse the extremely poor quality of this release.

reviewText: TITLE :  The worst game I've purchased (never again).... I really want to love this game. Its got a great feel for those first minutes of looking around and familiarizing yourself to the interface. This feeling is short lived though. The interface seems to be geared to consoles, but even for a console interface this is terrible. Unecessarily nested menus within menus with littel instruction or guidance in to how anything functions or is being operated while you go through trading or any other function. It feels like a alpha at best. The voice acting is laughable and models are just as bad. The space stations are all the same inside and show no creativity. Space combat also feels stale, the mouse control are sluggish and make for slow combat with little feeling of any risk to your ship. I found myself aggroing entire space stations and everythign I could find just to see if I could be killed. Eventually yes you do find enemies with more firepower but other than it being visually cool the AI is just terrible.   Almost every mechanic has some sort of bug, although that is being improved.   I do feel in a year or so this game might be worth its then to be heavily discounted price with enough modding, but thats completly up the community and ego soft...

reviewText: It happens about once a year: A game I'm really excited about, because, on paper, it looks incredible... turns out to be a disappointment. X Rebirth is one of those games. They lured me in with the promise of a galaxy to explore, a ship to upgrade, people to recruit, an economy to manipulate. They got my $50 before it even arrived, and I stayed up late just so that I could dive in as soon as possible... Well it just so happens that the pool was empty. Marred with a litany of bugs and technical flaws, and quite possibly the most consistently bad frame rate I've ever experienced, X Rebirth seemed more like X Abortion. Even turning all the settings down didn't help. Oh and, I could barely get 20 minutes into the game without it crashing multiple times.\n\nMaybe they can patch it. Maybe it'll turn out great and my $50 will not have been wasted... But pyramids ain't built with maybes. I'm not holding my breath for this one and neither should you.
voteText: 10 of 17 people (59%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Do not buy this... abomination. It will be months, maybe even years before all of the glitches, bugs, Artificial Intelligence, framerate, and interface issues get resolved, if ever. Bugs can be patched, AI can be fixed, but even then, the game still might not be salvagable. It is the core design choices built into the game itself that is the real problem.

1) The entire UI needs to be completely scrapped and redone from the ground up. It is just that bad.
2) The System:Sector:Zone map scheme is absurdly frustrating, to say the least.
3) Nearly all of the gameplay elements Egosoft has spent years introducing, refining, and polishing in the X series have been scrapped. No more SETA to speed up tedious portions, no more jumpdrive in the ship you actually pilot, no more autopilot, no more sector/universal traders, no more realtime monitoring of commodity prices using a satellite network, no more customizable keybinding, no more hotkeys to cycle through targets (you literally have to click on a ship w/ your cursor to highlight them and get aim-assist).

As many others have said before me, this simply isn't an 'X' game. They should have called it 'Y'. As in Y the hell would anyone play this?

It pains me to write this. I know Egosoft is comprised a a dedicated bunch who have a long history of commitment to thier customers. Few companies come to mind that are as noble as Egosoft when it comes to taking thier fanbase seriously. I want to extend them every benefit of the doubt, but good intentions will only go so far. This game, right now, as of November 25, 2013, is complete garbage. Complete garbage produced over a 7 year period a team with years of experience designing space-sims who really really REALLY should have known better.

Here's to hoping the modding community can fix what Egosoft has broken. My heart.
