reviewText:
Don't play it..just don't. The video trailers are completely misleading, as were all the hypes and promises made by EgoSoft. The voice acting is terrible, sounding like someone reading (for the first time) off a script with little to no emotion. The NPCs are all static and don't move anywhere around the cut-and-paste station interiors. No matter what the station looks like on the outside, it'll probably look pretty much the same on the inside.
Combat is clunky- the first bit of combat where you fight a couple of drones, your ship maneuvers like a stoned whale, so you can barely hit them, and from what I've seen from others, this doesn't particularly improve.
While the universe, artistically, is gorgeous...the rest, not so much.
If you want to travel from point A to point B, you'll have to fly manually the whole way, often using the weird space-highway system. Having to circle a station for 5-10 minutes to find where you're supposed to dock adds to the frustation.
As does suddenly losing a chance at being liked by an NPC due to some sort of (completely unexplained) conversation minigame coming up and disappearing before you know what's happening.

Your supposed crew members looking after your ships have all the intelligence of a sub-average brick. They have to be told exactly what to do (and sometimes still won't do it) through a maze of menus and submenus. Your co-pilot is worse- she throws random lines out here and there which make no sense whatsoever, her voice acting is terrible and cliched, and she provides no extra purpose to the game beyond being an annoyance.

OVERALL:
While the space-graphics are pretty, and there's a lot to potentially do....the game is fundamentally fubared, with some parts completely ambiguous, others blatantly and utterly broken, and the majority of it frustrating.
Conclusion:
Don't buy it, like I did. I'm really wanting to ask for a refund.

reviewText:
X rebirth in its updated state is by far one of the most interactive and approachable X game to date, no its not as complex nor does it have the same sense of customisation as previous titles but it is able to be picked up from the start without the need for large amounts of cash grinding or endless travelling back and forth through sectors as seen in previous titles.

Combat to is much more approachable as the controls feel much more responsive and streamlined to a point where you actually want to participate in fights rather than just rely on the autopilot.

Trading and empire management are the defining elements of any X game and whilst rebirth had a rocky start and still has a few problems rebirth by far has the best trading system to date. once trades have been unlocked all available trades can be accessed through the one screen and available ships can quickly be swapped to as needed, additionally trade requests can be qeued up to be conducted automatically (autonomous trading mods are available to bring back stuff like galactic traders)

The most important thing to note is that rebirth has a live economy which is generated on your pc (not some silly cloud computing) meaning that blowing up trading vessels or stations can have a big impact on the economy (without SETA however this can take real human hours to notice), additionally trades are conducted automatically between stations within each zone through the use of mass traffic (no its not just FPS eye candy).

Stations too have improved apon the old complex system getting rid of the spidersweb of stations seemingly linked together through a bunch of string with individual parts of the station being assigned to raw materials (e.g steel plates) final products (e.g drones) or effeciency improvements with the option for station defences to be constructed (so you no longer need a fleet to protect your stations.

All of this can understandably cause a few problems (my game for example loves to chew almost 8gb of RAM) or result in some tradeoffs (First person mode is not all that exciting after awhile) but for a game that tries to achieve the best of both worlds (space shoot em up and economics management) Egosoft did (and is still doing through regular updates) a pretty good job and where it feels lacking you can often find a solid mod to help you out.

In conclusion Rebirth is really a game that depends on your tastes, if you just want to shoot stuff with lite trading elements try Elite dangerous or if you want a full on space trading sim try picking up x3 Terran conflict. But if you want something a little more involved that isn't too steep a learning curve then give rebirth a shot

reviewText:
A terrible, terrible game, and a massive disappointment.

X games are always rough on release, filled with bugs and all kinds of problems. But at the core, they offer a deep and rewarding space sim sandbox experience. The clunky UI and sheer scope of the game overwhelms most first time players. But when you finally overcome all obstacles, you're in for a real treat which might consume most of your social life. With all that in mind, i pre-ordered this game. It was supposed to be a PC exclusive, hardcore space sim. It was made by seasoned developers with years of experience under their belts. And man, look at those graphics! What could go wrong here?

Pretty much everything.

X Rebirth is pretty. The space cities look amazig, they're richly detailed, there's plenty of space ship traffic around them, and the game looks really nice at first glance. The backdrops are simply stunning. Every sector has its own unique look and feel. It's by far the best looking space game to date. And that's the end of the positives.

The interface has been overhauled, supposedly, to be more accessible. In reality, we get something both newcomers and old time veterans will have hard time getting used to. The UI is once again unintuitive and badly thought out. Half of the stuff you could do in previous X games has been thrown out of the window. There's no radar. The world map is unreadable. You can't give out basic orders to ships under your command. You can't tell if they're moving or not. You can't see their destination, speed etc... But if that's not enough, you can't even switch between your targets with the keyboard! In a god damn space sim! You can't rebind most of the keys either. And every time you want to check something on your ship's computer (the main UI window), you're forced to watch an annoying animation.

The game is filled with pointless minigames. There's a minigame for pretty much everything you do. From flying through space highways or walking through space stations (in search for random containers filled with loot and free credits), to gathering collectible points for shop discounts or scanning your nearest vicinity for random junk floating around in space. They're pointless, tedious and repetitive. And they definitely don't belong in a space sim.

You can now walk freely inside the space stations. A nice idea - in theory, but in this case it's just another chore this game didn't need. There are 3 different space station layouts. Do i need to say they get old pretty fast? And they're filled with butt-ugly, lifeless NPCs, which are nothing more than a visual representation of the trading/ship managment UI. The voice acting is as bad as you'd expect from Egosoft, except, it's actually even worse. Prepare to listen to your main protagonist repeat the same lines over and over again, making the infamous Bethesda arrow in the knee" or "i saw a mudcrab the other day" lines look fresh and original.

The game world is small. That's the cost you have to pay for those pretty graphics. And the persistent
date: reactive world we were promissed was a lie. Rebirth's world is filled with constant traffic. There are hundreds of ships
hoursPlayed: moving through space. But most of them are there just for show. For example

reviewText:
I wanted to like this game.  I wanted to get immersed into a space simulation, make money, build a fleet, become a mega-trillionaire and then just sit around in my space-station (or solid gold planet) all day throwing money at strippers.

Okay, concede that on release the game was a buggy pile of excrement.  It was woeful.  Let's not get distracted by that.

My thoughts park all of the history to one side and look at the game today (feb 2015).

It sucks.

You're confined to one ship, can own others, hire people to pilot them, etc, but basically almost everything I can think about this game is unintuitive, broken, or ugly.  How could they screw it up so bad ?  Even the area where they could truly shine (graphics) - they make the obtuse decision not to have a vanity cam, so I can drool while free-mousing around my ship.  Oh that's right, I can only fly one ship .. so what's the point ?

Game is just bad.  Buyer beware.

Hello there,

I have never written a review before so this could be a little
bit amateur.
first a word from the game...

Problem signature:

Additional Hang Signature 6:	d769
Additional Hang Signature 7:	58063b2f42eedb1b0b2467899abedba6

I believe these problems are all fixed now.

I recommend playing this game:
-One) After you have played the other X-Universe games first.
Because the earlier games set the scene, the continuing story is
brilliant and worth being part of. It will make you want more
up to this point.
-Two)Playing the earlier games will give you an appreciation of
what may become.
-Three)Rebirth is very different to the others. It is more
picturesque. It Makes the earlier games graphics seem dated
Its one of the most stunning, graphicly, space sims I have played.
I have a few.

PROS:
-X-Rebirth is beautiful. (full stop) the burning sides of capital ships
as pound laser into them. The wondrous asteroid fields to drift in.
-Nice sound tracks
-Piloting in and around the space stations with little rewards for
simply exploring is refreshing and fun.
-Its a great space sim.

CONS:
-You have to compare it to its predecessors and it lacks any to
all the depth of game play, variety in ships and items and freedom of
the early games. It seems a very pretty but empty shell in
the face of its foundations.
-If you had never seen the earlier games X-rebirth would make you
very satisfied but the wonderful story and history of the X-universe
is what makes it rich as a universe. You will end up playing the earlier
games and wonder what happened.

So. Again the first things first, and dont be in a hurry, its a big universe
an X-universe. I hope that helps.


I will now rant to add detail.
I must say I have in the first play of the Rebirth
experienced many bugs and issues. Freezers, crashes, lost ships...
(Thats fixed now)
But..
I kept going, the past 'X' incarnations had bought
me far to much to joy and inspiration. I really can
not discribe how much I enjoyed all the 'X'-universe series.
The only word that comes to mind is devotion! I even have the novel
Its really good!

Even more devotion was obvious from the developers of 'X'
to innovation, originality, fun, real progression and all the detail that no other games
deared to have. My experiences of the X-Universe are breath taking.

For the memories and mutual devotion I pushed on and would not
give up on 'X' rebirth'. Playing saving and waiting for
the inevitable freeze. I had to find the fun for two main reasons.
It was worth looking for.

Firstly I trust EgoSoft and our wider community to over
time fix and improve.
It is in a lot of ways the proof of progress and courage to change.
A vision of the future.
I entrusted in the egosoft developer community with hours or near
years of my escapist time, to thier creativity and hard work.
I believe it was time well spent and many out there would be happy to play
X-Rebirth in the same way.

Secondly I started to take a lot more notice
of what was there in the game rather than
what wasn't there.

I had thought if this was my c64 and the
data set had just stop squeaking to reveal
X-rebirth on the screen, I would have wept
at the beautiful art work that is stunningly
stylized, music, physics and the collective ambiance
is like awaking from one dream in to a better one.
This is a beautiful game. But just a baby
new born, reborn.

I had been pretending that I am
traveling in a damaged ship that has lots
of issues and its system crash a bit.
Like a game freeze is life support power loss
dead in space again.
Which seemed fine because its an old ship?!

For the first time I / We are not alone. Theres the co-pilot
which for me seems awesome. To be in a
virtual way sharing the journey which will be
epic and should be shared. I really like the co-pilot feature!

So. The x-universe has been reborn, this is 'Elite' on your 64
bidding to grow up to be fronter then beyond and beyond some more. The cycle
is starting again better bigger.
We are here to help it watch and guide its growth. A bit of trust and
investment and the rewards will be there. Give X-Rebirth a chance

X-Rebirth, I like it. But cant wait for whats to come.
How about you?
Regards,
Nathan

reviewText:
X Rebirth is the marriage of an economic simulator with an arcade flight sim. The basic gameplay centers around completing various missions for pay and reputation with different factions. Inbetween these, you manage your other assets, including myriad capital ships, freighters, mining vessels, and space stations.

Combat sends you against marauding fighter bands and massive carriers, hostile space stations and shoals of drones. Shield energy powers your boosters, meaning the player must choose when to fight and when to run, and guessing wrong with leave them naked and stranded under fire. Enemy fighters dogfight with the player and each other. Huge capital ships can wreak havoc, but their engines, turrets, and shield projectors are vulnerable to damage. The weak AI is an issue, and larger targets can seem rather bullet-spongey for a player with few resources. Still, disabling and capturing that troublesome destroyer near your new factory is very satisfying.

On the economic side of things, the Great Material Continuum flows like a river from station to staion in the form mass traffic, cargo vessels, and large frieghters. And it is constantly under attack from pirates and other hostile forces. This means there are plenty of opportunities for would-be tycoons. Materials must be mined. Food must be grown. Parts must be manufactured. Freight must be transported. Ships but be built and supplied. Stations must be constructed and defended. And everything needs staffing. It's a lot of fun to plan out your installation and manage its construction and operation. Oddly moreso when you've screwed up something and have to rework everything on the fly.

While I recommend the X Rebirth, it's certainly not for everyone. It's a trainset of a game, crossing into simulation territory just enough to be intellectually stimulating, while still providing the visceral thrill of arcade space combat. It's a casual-friendly game that lets you dip your toes into the deep end of the pool.

Happily Youtube has come to the rescue of the scrutinous. Mylo-s did a fairly thorough playthrough of the gameplay mechanics. While there are some plot spoilers, the plot itself is just an overgrown gameplay tutorial.

reviewText:
After the 3.1 update, this game finaly is what it should be since the release. Egosoft fixed a lot of bugs and its finaly good enougth to play and you wont have any more problems, I promise !

I pre-ordered the collectors edition, on release date I skipped school just to play it from the first moment. After the installation I sat down with my can of redbull and chips, I was hyped to Albion and back, I was so ♥♥♥♥ing hyped, I was the hypetrain itself. BUT after the first 2 hours of gameplay I just sat infront of my PC, tears in my eyes, clinching my teath. My body was shakeing, I was angry, so angry. You had failed me Egosoft, I spend hours of my life playing your games, I played X: Reunion around 800 hours and X: Albion prelude around 500. I was so disapointed, you failed me, YOU *UCKIN FAILED ME !

I didnt touch the game, or just rarely when they released new updates...but after some time it came to my mind that you, dear Egosoft, builded a new game from scratch. You left the old X behind, you made something truely new, something unique, something fantastic... after this reaisation I wasnt mad anymore... you build a new game from scratch, with a new engine, with a new AI and with new graphics/ships/stations, it took a lot of work, a lot of willpower and a lot of blood to create the basics...but you did it. It wasnt finished, but it does not have to be. You Egosoft, you care about your games, and this is what came back in my mind. The first X3: Reunion build was buggy as hell, the skripts didnt work the halft time and ships constantly crashing in my stations and jumpgates...but you fixed a lot in the first months/years...

AND you did the same with X: Rebirth...after a year its finaly that what it should be, a masterpiece...and I know there is much more to come, because Egosoft, you CARE about your games and I just can tell every player/owner, buy/play this game, it is worth it. Its playable, dont listen to the people who are trying to badmouth it. X:Rebirth is complex, its difficult to programm and you should give it a try. Its good money and you spend, I know but its worth every penny, because Egosoft gives you free DLCs and Patches, Fixes and content for the next years.


Now to the game:

Gameplay:

Massive changes to trade/build/fight/explore-content, you only own a single ship now, the Albions Pride/Skunk. Many people see this as a downside but I like it. You can change it to your likeing (new engines, cockpit, weapons, etc.).
Also tradeing and building got more time consuming and rewarding, because you realy feel like you have archived something. Missions realy pay out now, not the crappy 20k for fighting fregatts or whole fleets, now you can easily earn millions with one misson (it will be a difficult one, but fun) so yes...overall a little bit more difficult.

AI:

Meh, there's still room for improvement, but thats normal. You have nice fights but you mostly will get beaten because of the mass of the enemys fleet.

Soundtrack:

A.W.E.S.O.M. 'nougth said !

Graphics:

WAY better than X3: XXXXXX"s Graphics. Nice improvements - still its hardwareconsuming
date:
so watch out. Maybe Egosoft will reduce it in some more patches.


Fazit: solid 8.5/10 from the current phase
recommended: maybe a 9 for the free DLC
hoursPlayed: thx for that :D"

reviewText:
I have finished the plot and have 65 game hours on the clock. I sit looking at the screen thinking “now what?” Put the bugs and performance issues to one side for now (I am reasonably confident they will be dealt with), this game appears to have nothing in store but tedium now the plot guidance has disappeared.

I need to make money in order to progress. The prospect of either long range scanning, or constantly flying around huge stations to try and get missions or establish what is for sale/wanted fills me with despair. Especially as I have yet been able to establish how I get my freighters to refuel. Is the only way to do this be by ordering them to buy something then telling them to buy fuel first when they tell me they have no fuel? (that has yet to work BTW). I have the trading software and even though I have traversed from the end of the plot to Far Out, I bring up the trading menu and there seems to be little that I can buy, what little that is available I cannot sell as I am an enemy to most of the stations that require the wares (PMC). What am I progressing to? Is my purpose solely to get the economy going? Can you order a cap ship to attack something?

That station I built, due to bugs and not being able to find freighters that held the required materials for building the various sections, was mostly completed by hacking the save. It has yet to produce a single item for sale. Modular station design seems to be a good idea, only being able to select and build one module at a time seems bizarre. Especially when I cannot seem to be able to contact the architect remotely (I can’t even comm the captain and ask them to go and get the architect). Backwards and forwards again and again, why would I do that for more than the required station? Please tell me that it is different for a construction ship that isn’t part of the plot.

I have mixed feelings regarding the use of shield energy to boost speed, if I knew how many enemy ships were close, trying to kill me and what type of ship they were it would be a good idea (I can make a judgement call and run if need be).  But as I can only see red triangles at the edge of the screen I do not have enough information to know when to run.

“Shut up Betty” was funny the first time. The highway mini game was was fun the first few times. Hacking while your co-pilot seems happy to let the ship get blown to pieces is ridiculous. Hacking in general is ridiculous once you throw the mini game into the equation along with some hacking points being many km’s apart. I am not going to comment on the small talk mini game. A mod has put paid to “shut up Betty”, I refuse to play the highway mini game anymore and I had no choice with hacking.

Clusters are too small, the distance between them is too large and I am loathe to jump out of a highway on the off chance that there may be something interesting.

Writing this wall of text has allowed me to determine what is wrong, in my mind, with the game. All of the fun, mystery and potential sense of achievement has been removed. I don’t want to micro manage on a face to face basis. The saddest part is that now I have finished the plot I don’t know if I want to fire the game up again.

Maybe the complete lack of any useful game information (how to, what is, why does etc.) is keeping me from the best gaming experience of my life. I may never find out.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
DO NOY BUY!
Do NOT buy this game, at first I thought it didn't run because of my computer but then I found out my computer should be able to run this game fine. Then I found out that even the best computers loose their framerate on the most performance orientated settings. And that bugs make some parts of the campaign COMPLETELY UNCOMPLETEABLE. This game also has terrible voiceacting and your stuck in a begginership that has all combat orientated around you being PERMANTLY stuck flying the starting ship.
Also it has horrible bugs (32 pages of troubleshooting in fact) that may even require editing game files to fix. The bugs aren't like other games where they are entertaining like Skyrim and New Vegas, alot of these ones prevent you from moving forward at all in the game (Like the broken Dead Money ending where only the console can end the world's second biggest dissapointment, X Rebirth being the first).
Better yet they give us free DLC for the fifty dollar game that DOESNT WORK! Why make DLC when the vanilla DOES NOT WORK!
DO NOT BUY!"

reviewText: I've Where to start.  Firslty, it is very clear that this game was not finished at release.  I've been waiting until around a few days ago to give it a try.  Egosoft has still not come through with the patches they promised.  The trading is completly bugged and if one thing is done wrong it flat out does not work.  The navigation system is not only confusing and buggy but is near impossible to find the information you need/want to know.  Combat can be fun at times.  It feels a little slow to pace and from time to time you simply explode for no reason.  The game has a good look to it but the cockpit feels completly worthless and has almost no value as far as mechanic.  And lastly, not only do you have to leave the cockpit to talk to your crew but the ship only has one room on it.  Somehow with one room (that has nothing functional in it) can fit you, your co-pilot, an engineer, eight marines, and a marine captain on it.  It has a few very cool festures like how to scan for long range.  the station landing feels very dry and unpolished as well as the fact that your ship can be attacked while you are docked and can plainly see it on the landing pad.  The game feels like it was the test system the quickly slapped some polish on and said That's good enough
recommended: I wouldn't recomend this game to anyone until Egosoft fixes most
hoursPlayed: if not all of the problems with it.  Personally
voteText: I feel that I have been scammed by Egosoft and they should be ashamed of themselves for even releasing this game."

reviewText:
I had written a long review which never went through.
Long story short: unbiased players and newcomers might want to give this game a shot once it has been properly fixed by Egosoft (I have been using the 1.17 patch thus far, which has solved some issed and introduced others) and the price has dropped a little (30 $ maybe?).

The obvious shift of pace from the previous X-series will have long-time fans (like me) with a bittersweet sensation of unwelcome change. But long-time fans (like me) probably bought this game before it was even released, and have had time to complain a lot in forums and the interweb alike (unlike me ;) )

If I were to give it a score, right now, I'd say 6, but I do not recommend buying until later.

Crashes, etc.  It seems like a fun game (albeit I think it was originally for a console because it seems pretty dumbed down for a PC game), but I can't recommend it (or enjoy it) until Egosoft fixes some of the crap.\n\nOtherwise, even though I'm not an EVE player, it seems a bit like a one-man EVE online.  Hoping they get their ♥♥♥♥ together and make this game playable with patches soon.

reviewText: I played every other X game there is and i tried playing this one for 4 hours, i was lost the whole time. I gave up, i don't understand why you would change a game so much when all the other ones before it were so popular. Why change it to the point that a gamer of 20 years can't figure it out? i mean look at the meta score... 33 how? how does this game suck so bad when all others were so fun. I am just so down about this game, I preordered and waited for what i thought would be a tweaked out version of an x series game, this isnt even close to an x series game it sucks.

reviewText:
I have finished the plot and have 65 game hours on the clock. I sit looking at the screen thinking “now what?” Put the bugs and performance issues to one side for now (I am reasonably confident they will be dealt with), this game appears to have nothing in store but tedium now the plot guidance has disappeared.

I need to make money in order to progress. The prospect of either long range scanning, or constantly flying around huge stations to try and get missions or establish what is for sale/wanted fills me with despair. Especially as I have yet been able to establish how I get my freighters to refuel. Is the only way to do this be by ordering them to buy something then telling them to buy fuel first when they tell me they have no fuel? (that has yet to work BTW). I have the trading software and even though I have traversed from the end of the plot to Far Out, I bring up the trading menu and there seems to be little that I can buy, what little that is available I cannot sell as I am an enemy to most of the stations that require the wares (PMC). What am I progressing to? Is my purpose solely to get the economy going? Can you order a cap ship to attack something?

That station I built, due to bugs and not being able to find freighters that held the required materials for building the various sections, was mostly completed by hacking the save. It has yet to produce a single item for sale. Modular station design seems to be a good idea, only being able to select and build one module at a time seems bizarre. Especially when I cannot seem to be able to contact the architect remotely (I can’t even comm the captain and ask them to go and get the architect). Backwards and forwards again and again, why would I do that for more than the required station? Please tell me that it is different for a construction ship that isn’t part of the plot.

I have mixed feelings regarding the use of shield energy to boost speed, if I knew how many enemy ships were close, trying to kill me and what type of ship they were it would be a good idea (I can make a judgement call and run if need be).  But as I can only see red triangles at the edge of the screen I do not have enough information to know when to run.

“Shut up Betty” was funny the first time. The highway mini game was was fun the first few times. Hacking while your co-pilot seems happy to let the ship get blown to pieces is ridiculous. Hacking in general is ridiculous once you throw the mini game into the equation along with some hacking points being many km’s apart. I am not going to comment on the small talk mini game. A mod has put paid to “shut up Betty”, I refuse to play the highway mini game anymore and I had no choice with hacking.

Clusters are too small, the distance between them is too large and I am loathe to jump out of a highway on the off chance that there may be something interesting.

Writing this wall of text has allowed me to determine what is wrong, in my mind, with the game. All of the fun, mystery and potential sense of achievement has been removed. I don’t want to micro manage on a face to face basis. The saddest part is that now I have finished the plot I don’t know if I want to fire the game up again.

Maybe the complete lack of any useful game information (how to, what is, why does etc.) is keeping me from the best gaming experience of my life. I may never find out.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: This game is not worth the time or money. I purchased it in late Feb 2014 hopeing that some of the issues would be resolved. For me the game is unplayable with grapics bugs all over. The screen is broken into 16 little boxes and its like looking at the environment through the eyes of a fly. 50 dollars down the drain thankyou very much STEAM and EGOSOFT for ripping me off.\nWhats worse is tech support or the forum for tech support dont give a S#@T. AVOID THIS GAME AT ALL COSTS.

reviewText: I've Where to start.  Firslty, it is very clear that this game was not finished at release.  I've been waiting until around a few days ago to give it a try.  Egosoft has still not come through with the patches they promised.  The trading is completly bugged and if one thing is done wrong it flat out does not work.  The navigation system is not only confusing and buggy but is near impossible to find the information you need/want to know.  Combat can be fun at times.  It feels a little slow to pace and from time to time you simply explode for no reason.  The game has a good look to it but the cockpit feels completly worthless and has almost no value as far as mechanic.  And lastly, not only do you have to leave the cockpit to talk to your crew but the ship only has one room on it.  Somehow with one room (that has nothing functional in it) can fit you, your co-pilot, an engineer, eight marines, and a marine captain on it.  It has a few very cool festures like how to scan for long range.  the station landing feels very dry and unpolished as well as the fact that your ship can be attacked while you are docked and can plainly see it on the landing pad.  The game feels like it was the test system the quickly slapped some polish on and said That's good enough
recommended: I wouldn't recomend this game to anyone until Egosoft fixes most
hoursPlayed: if not all of the problems with it.  Personally
voteText: I feel that I have been scammed by Egosoft and they should be ashamed of themselves for even releasing this game."

reviewText:
Biggest franchise killing dissapointment to date. I'm not sure even the robust and long term X universe modding community can bring this thing back from the dead.

It is the perfect example of why solid games should never be designed with console as the base system and how marketing claims are at the end of the day just an excuse to print money.

This game is nothing more than a pretty engine with a very shallow everything backing badly designed game mechanics and a story I was unable to get involved with.

reviewText: Do not even think about buying X:Rebirth unless you are reading this recommendation in 2015 or later. By which time patching and modding will have made this a good game.
voteText: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I'm sorry to say, but this game was clearly not play tested before it was released.  I'm a big fan of X3, and was so looking forward to this addition to series.  I just wished I would have waited until it was on a steam discount deal before I purchased it.  Game performance is verry slow, even on the lowest settings.  I'm able to run games such as Skyrum, Bioshock, Warthunder, all on extream graphics settings with no problems, and adiquit frame rates.  But X Rebirth is very choppy at the lowest settings.  Not sure what kind of graphics engine they are using, but it's horible!  And the bugs are to numerous to count, hell there is a bug that just teleports you out into the middle of no where?!

Now, with that being said, I will give the programmers credit, they have been comming out with patches on a regular bassis (almost weekly) in an attempt to do damage control, they have made some minor improvements to FPS problems, so there is hope for X Rebirth yet.  So I would recommend that you not purchase this title at this time, give it about a year, wait for it to be on a Steam daily deal, get it at a reduced price, by then hopefully they will have most if not all of the bugs fixed.

So for now, I'm not going to recommend this game, hopefully I can change my recommendation at a later date.  (keeping my fingers crossed)
voteText: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful

reviewText: This game is absolutely horrible!  First of all it was released as a finished product which was in its Alfa stage at best.  It's nothing like any other game in the X-series, all of those games were outstanding.  This game doesn't deserve that namesake.  The one bright side is the constant patching the developer does....at least once a month or so.  I will note that it's a very expensive game for which I'd like a refund on.  I spent $60.00 on it and purchased it the day it came out.  Months later it still isn't playable.  This is the worst experience I've ever had with a game period.  I would strongly advise against purchasing this game...ever since it was advertised very deceptively.
